Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle as adult education portal
Post description: We have use Moodle as educational portal in North Carelian province, Finland. Site's main purpose is to provide information about adult education, organized by local educational institutes. Site contents are made in cooperation with several institutes, as well as local labour administration. Site is also used as a our project's intranet. In our website planning (links, texts, navigation) we have modified some of Florida State University's user- and need-based website planning guidelines (Sampson et al. 2001, Panke et al. 2002; see http://www.career.fsu.edu/techcenter/ ) for user-friendly site structure. Site itself has been builded using Moodle's courses, modules and blocks. Moodle courses has been used as "user profiles" to provide different contents and links for different user groups. Expect intranet, all courses are open to guest user - logging in is not needed. Most of Moodle's functions are hided to keep user interface as simply as possible. In front page and inside side each profile (course), most of the contents has been made by Nwiki. Nwiki provides great blocks like content block and search block. There has been some technical problems in Nwikis backup/restore in Moodle 1.6.x, but otherwise it's a great tool for our purposes. We have reported these problems to Wiki discussion as well as to Moodle Tracker . Our Moodlesite called Akkuna (a Finnish word for window) is http://www.akkuna.fi . Unfortunaly, it's in Finnish only... Please feel free to add any comments here or with email jani.lemmetyinen@joensuu.fi

Forum Post: 
Post title: Seeking Guidance: Tracking Attendance in SCORM with Embedded Streaming Video (HLS) – Without Forcing User Actions
Post description: Hello Moodle Community, I’m reaching out for help regarding an issue I’ve encountered with tracking attendance for videos inside SCORM when using HLS or embed stream links from a third-party video hosting service. The Issue I’ve noticed that if I embed a video stream link (HLS or iframe) from an external video hosting service (e.g., Bunny.net, Vimeo, AWS S3) inside a SCORM package, Moodle does not track whether the learner actually watched the video. The SCORM package seems to have no way of detecting: •If the video was played •If the learner watched the full video •If they skipped or fast-forwarded Since the video is hosted externally and not inside the SCORM package itself, SCORM only tracks whether the module was opened, not the video completion. What I Need Help With •I do not want to add logic conditions like “Click to Confirm Completion.” •I only want the video to be watched, and SCORM should automatically mark it as completed when the video ends. The Dilemma: Should I Upload Videos Directly into SCORM? To ensure proper tracking, one option is to upload the video file directly inside the SCORM package, instead of embedding a streaming link. However, this raises concerns: •LMS Performance Issues: Large video files inside SCORM may slow down Moodle. •Storage Consumption: Hosting videos inside SCORM increases the size of backups and restores. •Streaming Performance: SCORM loads the entire video, unlike HLS which streams efficiently. Questions for the Community 1.Is there any way for SCORM to automatically track video completion when using an HLS streaming link? •I do not want students to manually click any “I’ve completed this video” button. •I just want SCORM to detect when the video ends and record it as completed. 2.Should I upload the videos directly into SCORM, despite performance concerns? •Will Moodle handle large SCORM packages efficiently if videos are embedded directly? •How do other users manage video-based SCORM tracking without affecting LMS performance? 3.Are there alternative methods to track video completion while keeping the SCORM structure intact? •Has anyone successfully used xAPI/Tin Can API for tracking externally streamed videos? • also I don’t want to integrating an H5P Interactive Video inside SCORM be a possible solution I really appreciate any insights, solutions, or best practices from those who have tackled this before. Thanks in advance!

Forum Post: 
Post title: course format
Post description: Hi there
in Moodle 1.9 I was using a course format called simple course. To me it was the best format designed on pedagogical principles. I am working with a school and I want to show them this format but can't find it. Could someone please help me?

The format was more topic based. It presented the content in pages with back and forward buttons that allowed you to work in it more like a book. An added advantage was that as you built up the learning activities on each page, a menu on the left hand side was generated. When the student worked through the activities, the relevant page title on this menu was highlighted so they could see where they were. The menu allowed students to work through each page or go directly to the page they wanted.

Each 'page' could support video and all the course activities could be added. I liked that learning could be presented more flexibly and sequentially to assist with scaffolding, revision, etc.

Hope someone can help.

Andrea

Post title: Can I get your advice about choosing a course structure?
Post description: Hello, I am preparing a 14-hour course in Moodle. I have learned about the resource Book and wonder whether to use Pages/Quizes/Assignments or Books instead. Could anyone share their feedback on these two alternatives? With using Pages, Quizes, Glossary, and Assignments Currently, I have the following course outline that looks a bit like the following (I won't repeat the lessons, but there are 10 lessons). Module: Course introduction Page: Welcome to this course Page: Learning objectives Page: Most asked questions Glossary: Terms you will read about Module: Lesson 1: XXX Page: What you will learn in this lesson Page: Introduction to X Page: History of X Page: How to use in practice Quiz: Test your knowledge Assignment: Put X in practice (The lessons repeat 9 more times) Module: Course closing Page: What you have learned Page: Next steps Quiz: Final quiz Page: Course certificate With using Books The same course structure could look something like the following when using Books. Module: Course introduction Book: Chapter for (Welcome to this course; Learning objectives; Most asked questions) Glossary: Terms you will read about Module: Lesson 1: XXX Book: Chapter for (What you will learn in this lesson; Introduction to X; History of X; How to use in practice) Quiz: Test your knowledge Assignment: Put X in practice (The lessons repeat 9 more times) Module: Course closing Book: Chapter for (What you have learned; Next steps) Quiz: Final quiz Page: Course certificate Could anyone share their feedback about structuring courses, also when deciding between using the Book resource? How would you structure the courses? Thank you !

I just need a way to assign them a random piece of info that they need to use in their lab. Post title: learning pathway based on a choice or question response for content access
Post description: Hello, Basically looking for a way for students to make a choice or answer a question and then based on that answer they would have access to specific content. Ideally, being able to set-up a Restrict Access based on a Choice decision would be ideal but that isn't possible. Forum Post: 
Post title: best module to use...
Post description: I am trying to decide which module to use for the following assignment. I am teaching an environmental science course and want the students to each create an "executive summary" about a person, place, organization or issue of note in env sci. I would like the students to post their summaries to moodle in such a way that they can all view all the summaries. I envisage them creating their summaries as word files or powerpoints ( they will likely contain images). I was looking at creating a forum for them to post their summary to, perhaps with an overview in the posting text and then the rest of the document as an attachment. This would allow me to rate each summary and for the other students to comment on and/or discuss the summaries. Is there another tool that would work better? Any other suggestions?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You could consider using a Database activity - you could create a template that defined a structure for each student representing (for example) the title, some text (for the summary), one or two images and a generic file attachment if they want to upload a ppt or similar. Students can rate each other's work and leave comments, teachers can rate posts, but there is one catch - the grades don't automatically go into gradebook in v1.8 and earlier. This is resolved in v1.9 ( http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-9970 ). Hope this helps!
Comment 2: You have two other possibilities: a. use the glossary: it allows each user to post a definition (this could be the summary you're talking about) and the user can attach images, files or audios to it. Every student can see the works of the others and evalutate it. You as teacher can evalutate each posting and the whole. b. use the netpublishing module, which needs to be extra installed. It works like a cooperatrive magazine, where the teacher decides the different parts (titles) and each user/student posts his/her contribution. It works fine.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Automatic release of resources with a predefined maximum
Post description: Hi everyone My students are put in groups and have to work together to solve questions. Each (physical) lesson in class they get a playing card. I have a collection of videos with solutions to exercises that are hidden. When they cannot solve a particular question, they can give me a playing card to 'pay' for a video. Is there a way I can do this in Moodle? Now I just add the group to the resource using the 'restrict access' functionality, but I want this done automatically. There are much more videos available than playing cards, so in essence it comes down to this: say I have 5 videos and the students have 3 playing cards. How can they view only 3 of the 5 videos? Any ideas are appreciated! Kind regards Tom
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tom, You could have a look at some of the gamification tools in Moodle, such as Stash and Stash availability. These may add the functionality you're looking for.
Comment 2: Ok, thanks! I will look into that.
Comment 3: Hi Tom, Another solution would be our credit plugin(s). With enrol_credit and availability_credit, you can require students to pay with a number of credits for courses or activities /resources.
Comment 4: Super! Thanks! That seems to be exactly what I need! Kind regards! Tom

Forum Post: 
Post title: Relative Start/End Date [2.7]
Post description: I have a course for new hire orientation that I'd like to remain open as employees come on board. There is a final assignment in the course that should be completed within two weeks of starting the material- is there a way to set due dates relative to course enrollment date?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Frances, I do not believe this can be done with core Moodle, ie set due dates wrt the course enrollment.. We are looking to do something like this for an induction process. We considered the certificate module, but it is a bit slow to be upgraded at the moment. https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=mod_certificate We have considered cohorts, one a fortnight, with manual checks each week to look at progress.  On this line of thinking we thought of getting a custom report made to provide a report each Friday for managers. Of course Totara LMS has this sorted with their learning plans. http://www.totaralms.com/feature-a-benefits/89-learning-plans (I have no association with Totara) Another simple way would be to use the checklist plugin. https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=mod_checklist This is one of the plugins you can rely on with upgrades, with a new version not coming as a suprise to the coder With core Moodle, manually watching the Activity report (Course administration > Reports) is also quite good if you choose your activities carefully to limit their number.  You can then carefully have some dependencies and just have a few to check.  There is no decent image in the ehlp, I can post one if you like. Just my 2c worth, and I'm sure there is a better way. -Derek
Comment 2: I find it hard to believe that there isn't a simpler solution to this kind of issue without resorting to a Totara implementation.  I am looking to do exactly the same thing (new hire induction) with milestones set for  times relative to the start date. Anyone know of plans in the works for a plugin or core feature to enable such a thing?
Comment 3: Hi Mark, If you use self-enrollment (Site administration->Plugins->Enrollments) for this course, you can set the enrollment duration to two weeks with an email notification before the enrollment expires. So whenever the user starts, the enrollment period starts as well. You can set the action when the enrollment expires to "keep user enrolled." If you unenrol the user, you will lose all data in the database . With kind regards, Hartmut

Forum Post: 
Post title: Messenger: should students create own groups?
Post description: Messenger tools replaced forums and email in the students world. We all know that facebook groups and whatsapp are a problem. Corporates installs internal messenger tools to simplify group building and communication. The Moodle messenger is on the way to offer similar opportunities. One aspect is missing. Why cant students create own groups in the Moodle messenger? School wide groups are course related groups for communication and collaboration. Moodle started with a social concept of learning. What are the pros and cons for such a feature?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Remember seeing this topic coming up earlier. I repeat what I always say: schools should not try to be everything, for example not to be communications providers..
Comment 2: Fair enough when we're talking about schools. But I think Moodle is used widely also in corporate and adult learning (as I intent to use it), where I'd agree to Ralf that it would be a usefuly feature.
Comment 3: While the messaging component is interesting from a communications point of view, it is not per se part of the 'learning realm' of a Moodle instance. It might be considered a good means to facilitate 2-way communications between users, but it can't be directly monitored or moderated by a teacher/instructor as part of creating a safe learning environment for the end users (teachers as well as students). If you were to enable group messaging in a course context , you should be able to also do that with groups selected through the Group choice activity. I don't know if I'd allow my students to use the Group Self Selection activity and have the 'allow group messaging' setting there.
Comment 4: Hi Joost, I think in scenarios of self organized learning. We have something like this in different contexts: primary schools uses often free learning time (see Montessori concepts), in Vocational Training Schools who have up to 50% of the learning time in self structured processes and in corporate training in similar way. The typical group model in courses is helpful sometimes, but its teacher structured. Ralf

Post title: Grading assessments
Post description: I have a number of assignment activities which are just on line text responses from the students. I have been trying to figure out how a teacher can go in and manually grade each assignment as complete and then have course completion indicate when the course is completed when all the assignments have been graded to finish the course. I have beet trying to use Activity Completion in the course without success. I am unsure as to how I set the Gradebook up to give a complete (or however I need to set the gradebook up to achieve it) to make the Activity Completion work. Any help gratefully received .. !!)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Are you basically asking how to use Activity completion and Course completion ? Those links will take you to the documentation pages. With activity completion enabled you can set each assignment to be marked as complete once the teacher has given a grade. Then with course completion enabled the course as a whole will be marked completed once all the selected assignments have been marked complete.
Comment 2: So Mary, Can I ask you how to automatically send a pass grade for a quiz that has an incomplete/complete scale atached to it and that is in turn linked to an outcome?
Comment 3: You might also consider setting up a custom scale that has two values, complete and incomplete, if an actual grade (point) isn't necessary.
Comment 4: Thanks Lynn That's a great idea...

Forum Post: 
Post title: no borders
Post description: After a year of successfully running a Moodle server for my four classes off a dusty (but beloved) Mac in my living room, I changed up this summer to moodle.com and invited my colleagues to offer classes from my site. Now we're running with 430 students (with courses being fleshed out for another 200 students) and are working across borders (connecting classrooms from independent schools in Michigan, Minnesota, and Maryland). I realized this cross-border approach was possible after I carried on more frequent and successful conversations with Martin (who is on the other side of the planet from me) than I had with any of my department members down the hall. In one school, teenage students are using Moodle all day long at their "compu-desks" (individual work desks with computers inside), at another school older students are using Moodle on "smart-boards." In my classroom, I just use a projector to throw the image of my laptop on the wall, but I think all of these different configurations are appropriate to the tool. Although my school is still paying for and serving Blackboard, the Moodle site will surpass their users and usage in the next three weeks. The price difference between the two is pennies on the dollar. I spend approximately three minutes a day "administrating" the site (fixing a password, offering a tip), and the rest of the time I enjoy the collaboration of peers. Alongside the regular courses the site offers, we created a "faculty" room for teachers. This course offers the chance to share classroom ideas and to share tips (like "Using Moodle"). We are now engaged in the process of developing a few "no borders" courses that will allow cross-enrollment from the participating schools. I wonder what else we could do? Out of the excitement this project has generated, I have former professors as well as former students (currently grad students) volunteering to be guest teachers (by contributing assignments or by facilitating one or two activities ). I know my planning as a teacher is more thoughtful now that I'm using Moodle courses. I tell my students that the interactivity of the courseware requires both the teacher and the student to be more accountable. In the past 15 months, I feel that using this software has broken down walls between classrooms that will probably never go back up. Students that enjoyed Moodle in my courses last year have been the ones that convinced their new teachers to come aboard this year. With the help of the Mark Kimes Library module, I feel as if the classes are also gathering shared resources that will be stronger and stronger each term. The Library is not a dusty filing cabinet in the department office. Good ideas get recorded there and saved for the future.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: My, Tom, how things have taken off since 2003! -- Art

Post title: Can I restrict and hide a section from other teachers in the same course?
Post description: If it is possible, how do I do this as I can only restrict and hide from students, but not teachers?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Not really  -if a teacher has editing rights in a course then it is difficult for another teacher to hide a section from them.
Comment 2: Hi, Mary. I used to do that until Moodle release 3.2. As a course manager, I could restrict some sections to a teacher and some other sections to another teacher, using groups. Just changed capabiilty moodle/course: viewhiddensections to 'deny'. The section restricted to the other group used to become hidden to the editing teacher. Now, after release 3.3, this is not working anymore. Even with that capability set to 'deny', all teachers became able to see all sections. Do you have any idea of how that could be achieved now? Thanks in advance!
Comment 3: I wonder could you create version of a non-edting teacher role where these "non-editing teachers" could only see content that was available to their groups. You would have to change other elements of their roles to make sure that had the other necessary teacher privileges. It may be worth a try. I know that we restrict our tutors to only see their own set of students so maybe with a little bit of tweaking you could get what you need

Forum Post: 
Post title: Video editing software
Post description: Is there anybody who can suggest a software for video editing that works online. It should be possible to uploasd videos, cut them, add new audio takes and use picture in picture features. Ralf
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Camtasia comes to mind-but not sure if open source...might be worth a look though. Cheers, Dawn
Comment 2: Hi Dawn thanks for your answer. Camtasia needs a local installation and is not running online. Ralf
Comment 3: Hi Ralf, Have you tried Youtube's video editor? https://www.youtube.com/editor Video editors installed on your computer generally require a powerful 64-bit computer with at least 4GB memory (but more is recommended). And if you try to do a lot of video editing on a laptop, you'll eventually "burn out" the graphics card, which usually costs more to replace than a new laptop, and/or the DDR memory cards (cheap and easy to replace yourself). If you don't have sufficient hardware, an online option if definitely a good idea. I hope this helps!
Comment 4: All video editors should upload online. Do you mean edit as on download an editing software to your desktop? Then you can upload to anywhere you want to. That's what I would personally prefer.Theres a few links below that are open source. http://ubuntuhandbook.org/index.php/2014/04/install-the-latest-avidemux-2-6-8-in-ubuntu-14-04-lts/ http://www.openshot.org/ If you really do mean editing online, a google search is flooded with them. To me they simply appear to be wannabe family social networks like facebook, which is not to my taste. I'd rather direct my contacts and my videos to my own site, and not somebody elses. http://www.magisto.com/
Comment 5: Hi John thanks for your suggestions. I think my description was not clear enough. The videos are from university lessons. They arre using two camera soften and they have to edit this raw material to an attractive new video. This means some scenes have to cut out, To make it more interesting it should move from one camera perspective to they other and sometimes it will be required to show the perspective 1 (lecturer) as a small area into the main perspective (presentation slide view) - picture in picture mode. The editing process is team work. The team members are working from different location. That means that the raw material has to be upoaded to a web portal and the team members get access to it for working on the same project. The raw material and the final result is not for public. Only students will get access to the video in a Moodle plattform. Hope you can understand better  what is required. Ralf
Comment 6: Hello Ralf, If I understood correctly, you want something like GoogleDrive--which allows people to work simultaneously in a document--but for video. I don't think there is something like this. Video is definitely more complex that regular documents (be them, word, excel, etc.) and editing requires more resources (e.g. memory, processor speed). As I see it, the team should use a cloud service like dropbox, sugarsync or related ones, so the video can be shared to everyone, eventhough only a group could work on it at a time. Then, they could use skype or a similar service so while one group is actually editing, the screen is shared to the whole team and so everyone can suggest about the edits to be done. If two groups were to open and try to edit a particular video at the same time, the cloud service would create two different physical versions, just as it happens with regular documents. GoogleDrive is a similar but different concept, and that's why GD allows simultaneous editing, but not for video, at least not yet. --- edit Not exacly what you need, but it may cover part of your requirement (i.e. just the editing part, not the collaborative one): http://www.videotoolbox.com/
Comment 7: I recommend Video Editor for people who have no idea about editing and looking to join. Thats what most editors like me use.
Try the trial version and if you don't want to play there are many torrent availabl
Comment 8: Janet, When I went to research Video Editor, I found a number of different products called "video editor".  Which one are you specifically referring too? Thanks! Peter

Forum Post: 
Post title: First Time Moodling
Post description: I'm a first semester PhD student in Ed. Psych and I want to use Moodle for a class project.  I just downloaded the software for the first time last week and have only started playing with it. I need to provide a Math lesson using pre-existing online math content to two 8th grade classes.  I would like to conduct a 5 day training session as follows: Day 1: Walk-through of logging in and performing Moodle activities Day 2: Divide the class into groups of 2 or 3 and have them perform the pre-existing online activity (math game).  Instructions and Link from within Moodle. Day3: Have each group create a Wiki using a provided template explaining the how to win the game (ie. explain the math strategies necessary to win). Day4: Have groups review other groups Wiki's, posting comments about what was helpful and what could be added. Day5: Have the originating group, evaluate feedback, update Wiki, and submit to teacher as final. My question is ( and it is rather open ) is how to accomplish this using Moodle?  My thinking is to create a single lesson such that each topic contains the content for each possible Math game.  Each group can select their topic of interest.  It doesn't matter if they overlap - the Wiki activity will be separated by groups. If I take this approach, how do I make the Wiki's more public on Day 4?  Would each group have to export their wiki as an html doc and submit it back to a folder?  The downside of doing this is that the resulting html file is no longer a wiki. If they do resubmit their wiki as an html file, I could create a forum for them to discuss it rather than having them update it directly. I would appreciate comments from more experienced Moodlers.  Like most students, I am behind and need to get this done rather quickly. Thanks, bob
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, Bob. Welcome! Do you need the reviewing group to actually edit the wiki, or would posting their comments to a discussion forum be good enough? If so, you could set the wiki to "visible groups" rather than "separate groups". If it's set to visible groups, other groups will be able to see the wiki but not edit it. You could even set separate groups at first, then change it to visible groups when you're ready for the other groups to do their reviews.
Comment 2: Thanks.  I think I will use the separate at first and then visible on Day 4.  I wasn't sure if I was even approaching this from the right direction. bob ps.  I was look at your moodle sites - which are really nice - and your profile.  I too, have an MS in CSE and have just this semester become a EPsy PhD student.  I would be interested in hearing more about your experience (offline) and if/how you are using your computer science in this new field.
Comment 3: was look at your moodle sites - which are really nice Thanks! Most of the credit for the site design should go to my colleague, Doe-Hyung Kim, and to the designer of the "metal" Moodle theme.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Assessment for Learning and Moodle
Post description: I would like to use Moodle as part of our assessment for learning programme in school.  We are looking into the wiki for p2p assessment but I would like to add another dimension to AFL and I was hoping that a moodler could provide the answer. I would like to show students a topic list which they could then grade red amber or green according to their level of knowledge.  They would then receive an assessment which would show what band they are in and direct them through Moodle to learning materials to improve their grade.  They could then take the assessment again. This could be done using Access and then linking to Dreamweaver but I am keen to use Moodle.  I have looked at the questionnaire, survey and quiz modules but so far have not been able to produce anything suitable. Any possible solutions would be appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jeffrey, The workshop module is good for peer assessment The lesson module will allow you to give some information followed by a question so that pupils can select options to 'branch off' to new material/questions. This branching will allow pupils to access different levels of work which could be determined by correct/wrong answers to your questions. Hope that helps, Vinny
Comment 2: Jeffrey, what you describe would really lend itself to the workshop module. Workshop is an excellent tool for self and peer assessment. Irecently used it with Year 7 who worked on a project to create a leaflet. They decided on the assessment criteria themselves, developing them it using a wiki, they then produced a leaflet according to the assessment criteria. I created a workshop activity and the associated rubric from what distilled through the wiki, and they assessed each others' and their own work via the workshop. For next time, with more time and a tad more planning, I would run the different elements of the workshop at different times - they need time to reflect on their own assessment of their work and on the comments that others make when their work is assessed, and to then have the facility to make amendments and have a re-grade. Unfortunately the National Curriculum doesn't leave a lot of time for this! Another great AFL tool is the blog . I use both the Moodle internal blog and external Wordpress blogs (which allow commenting) for pupils to reflect on their progress and invite constructive comments from others. The RSS feed block allows the feeds from these to be included in individual's courses or My Moodle pages. Elsewhere in Moodle, the Lesson module allows for creation of individual learning plans based on level of attainment, as a module of lessons can be prepared that create an individual learning pathway from the responses the student gives. Quizzes give opportunities to give feedback on wrong (and right) answers so that the student giving an incorrect response might be shown a url for the resource that they need to look at to get the question right. I have found it useful to look at the logs after a quiz to see who actually spent time reading the feedback and acting on it, rather than just quickly having another go at the quiz in the hope that they got the answers right the second time! Inevitably, those spending more time to research their incorrect responses get them right more reliably the second time. Hoping this helps, drop me an email if you'd like to discuss this more. Best wishes Dale
Comment 3: Thanks very much for the suggestions.  I've looked at the workshop and lesson modules but I don't think they will do exactly what i want, howver your suggestions have made me think about alternative approaches.  I will look again at the outcomes I want and see if they can be achieved another way.  Thanks again will certainly contact you if I need further help.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Student can bypass course?
Post description: Hi all. I'm looking for a solution to a problem. I have set up my online courses as follows: Topic 1 - Play Course Topic 2 - Take Quiz Topic 3 - Get Certificate Users are able to by pass Play Course by clicking on it, watching 5 or 10 seconds, then going to the Quiz. Is there a way to lock it down where they have to watch the entire presentation before going to the quiz?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Are you saying "Play course" is a video they must watch? If so then put the video in a Lesson activity and use Restrict access so that they must stay in the lesson for the length of the video before it is marked as complete. Then they won't be able to do the quiz until the length of the video has passed. Now - that doesn't mean they will watch the video but since they have nothing better to do, they might as well! There is an old screencast here (of an earlier version of Moodle ) that might be useful:
Comment 2: I like this idea but the files are .html files. It's an articulate file technically. The .html doesn't seem to play in the lesson. What type of file should I be using for this?
Comment 3: Hi Lisa, Another way would be to put a password on the quiz and provide the password at the end of the presentation.
Comment 4: I really like that idea Helen.
Comment 5: There is also this technique to force students to watch a video: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Clockwork_Orange_(film)#Psychology
Comment 6: Is there a text version of the video?  Is there are corresponding "textbook" that has everything that is said put into a traditional text version?  Do you give the students the choice to either read the material or watch the video?  Is there some benefit to actually watching the video as opposed to just reading an article about the material? The reason I am asking is that I am also assigning videos to my students, but each video also has a corresponding "textbook" chapter.  If the student wants to just read the textbook and looks at the examples in the textbook, then personally I do not really care if they watch the video or they don't watch the video.  I just want them to absorb the material and demonstrate that they know the material through their homework assignments.  It does not really matter to me how they absorb the material. Unless it is something where the material really can't be presented in a traditional paper version, then I do not think that watching a video should ever be a requirement.  If there is something in the video that can't be presented in the same way in a paper version (for example, listening to the original "I Have A Dream Speech"), then you need to explain in the description the benefits of the video over just reading the text, and why you believe the video is a benefit over the just reading the text. How many times do you personally go on a news site and just read the text of the video as opposed to watching the news article?  I almost never watch a video on a news article site.  I am just saying this to present a counter argument to requiring the student to watch a video. Melissa

Post title: Serial Evaluation of Tasks
Post description: Good day dear Moodle community, Is there any possibility (on Moodle) to grade tasks continuously; using the rubric tool multiple times without overwriting the end result of the previous attempts? The aim is to show the learning progress by having the students work on a task repeatedly until they are able to complete the task achieving 100%. Currently one can rate the tasks as often as desired, but the result of any previous attempts are automatically overwritten. Is there any way to save the percentile rank of each rating/attempt and thus show the continuous learning curves? Kindly regards!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I would say that it depends on the task. I do know that this is possible if it is a writing task, by using the Diary plugin set to use maximum rating. The automatic grade recommendation can always be overridden by the teacher. Without knowing what the tasks are, I cannot think of anything else.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle quiz
Post description: Hello, This is my first time preparing quizzes using Moodle and I'd like to post two questions. The first one is that I'd like to know if it's possible to edit a quiz once is done because, even though I've tried to do so, I've had no success. It's quite tiring because every quiz I've done is, at least, three pages long, and so I don't have the time to post it all, I know I have to begin all over again the following day. My second question has to do with the type of exercises the quiz allows us to prepare. Is there any demo or pdf where they show us how to? I've only been able to work the multiple choice option so far. Thank you very much. Leire.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Leire A quiz can't be edited anymore once it is attempted by the student. if you want to edit it you need to delete all the students attempt. There are various types of question which can be created in quiz. Please refer to this documentation http://docs.moodle.org/24/en/Question_types
Comment 2: Hi Leire, There is a LOT of stuff out there on the Internet to show you how to do things in Moodle, as well as the documentation right here on the Moodle.org web site. Here is a link to a YouTube video that introduces you to Moodle quizzes. It is the first of four, I think: Here is a link to MoodleBites Moodle tutorial movies on YouTube that has a bunch of tutorials: http://www.youtube.com/user/hrdnzmoodlepartner Hope this helps, AL
Comment 3: Hi Leire, I use quizzes a lot and find them very tedious (too many clicks), but this is the down side of so many powerful features. Until Moodle provides built-in quiz "templates" for common (useful) configurations, I (sort of) created my own. I make a blank quiz (with no questions) that has been configured the way I want. This can take a long time to configure (trial and error), as there are so many options. You might have to add one or two questions to see how you want it to work. For example, I like my students to get feedback immediately after they answer a question. I have limited time quizzes with limited tries (best score is the one that counts). Once you have that working the way you want it, think of that as your "template" in Moodle. Keep the "template" invisible on the site, since you don't want students seeing/taking it. You can copy the quiz to a new quiz and use that one for the quiz the students will take. This method saves me a lot of time (although I lost a lot of time to get to this point!). Good luck!

Post title: Calculated questions
Post description: Hi, I'm trying to write math exercises for my smaller kids... I need to generate exercises adding up to less than 100, but without having the digits passing 10 OK: 23 + 16 (because 3+9 < 10) NOT OK: 26 + 16 (you have to carry over the 10) I can't find a way to do this using the math type questions. Currently I'm falling back to just generating 50 of them by hand. But I'd like to know if this kind of things is possible.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Adding a descriptive heading in a Rubric
Post description: I want to create a rubric that includes 'empty' criteria that are descriptions for groups of criteria. Example: Complete Improvable Incomplete Assessments Medical History Dental History Vital Signs Implementation Local Anaesthetic Selective RCP Sealants etc The bolded terms in the left column are category headings, and I want them to appear in the rubric, but not to have any levels associated with them. Is this possible? Moodle complains if I create an empty criterion
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I guess that's because a rubric may look like a table with headings, but isn't. The whole idea of a rubric is that you'd have more of a description for each quality level / criteria row. In that way, Medical History - Complete would have to contain some sort of description, for the students to understand what is expected of them to achieve.a complete mark there. Using rubrics is a very good way to provide additional information to foster and improve 'notion of quality' among your students. At least, that's how the scholars in Formative Action approach rubrics for feedback and assessment. A description should be concise, clear and unambiguous. One thing a rubric isn't: a basic checklist that will leave the assessment process in its blackbox process as with simple direct grading.

Post title: Showing different students different units within course
Post description: Hello, I would like to achieve this and I can not find anything to help me out. We have a full year enrollment program so a student can start a course at any time. For this example lets use the course English . Student A enrolls tomorrow into English and he wlll start Unit 1 Student B has been enrolled in English for 3 months and is at Unit 3 How can I hide the other units for Student A (so he doesn't jump along) but keep them visible for Student B . If I hide those unit that student can not progress. Any help would be appreciated I am using Moodle 3.1 thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello. I suggest you read about Restrict access and Activity completion so you can set your course so that students only see the activities they haven't yet done and progress at their own individual pace/
Comment 2: Using the toggle visibility feature for Restrict Access rules (with the 'eye' icon) also helps a lot: this way a student only sees the activities he should have access to, and not those that are still unavailable. From a user's perspective, the course keeps growing and advancing, without the teacher having to manually manage availability of activities.
Comment 3: I would make it so that the student needs to pass a quiz with a certain grade at the end of each unit.  When they reach a passing grade the next unit is revealed.

Post title: 2.3; Core & Elective units to be used with completion?
Post description: I'm not sure of the best way to structure my courses or topics, and need some suggestions. I have fairly simple courses - they are really just topic containers that link to reading notes and a quiz. Completing a quiz with a given score percentage completes that unit. Completing the required number of units completes the course. However, we now have to throw in electives. i have a client who needs to be able to base a course completion on completing core topics + any X of Y elective topics; e.g. 5 core plus 2 of 5 electives. The course itself is then used as a conditional requirement to taking other courses (e.g. you have to either have done a cert3 course to start a cert4, or otherwise marked rpl). It seems that some people set these up AS courses themselves. But I don't see how that works to give you a "completion" record, which is for a given course. So I don't see how you would base the requirement of starting a cert4 course on the completion of multiple other courses. With elective units, the learner can open them and then take a look to see if that's what they want to do, and choose to start it or not. As long as at the end they have a completion against the X of the Y of these electives then that's considered part of the completion - even if they start unit 1 then choose to skip it and do all of unit 2 instead. Is there going to be a way to set up completions for a course that can be based on "all n of this list" plus "any n of that list" rules for objects?

Post title: Using Usernames for assigning roles and enrolling for courses
Post description: hi, I think this is a custom requirement for using username more frequently (and with more dependability) for assigning roles and enrolling for courses, instead of Full Name and Email. Open to house.. to comment and solutions??
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Azhar - Generally it is considered a slight security risk to unnecessarily exposure a username. Once a cracker has the username then they only need to guess the password. For that reason, in Moodle core you will not see usernames used in many places as that is a deliberate decision.  If you want to use the username rather than the user's actual name, you could look at the fullname function in /lib/moodlelib.php and see what you want to do. I might be tempted to add an optional parameter (for example, username) to the fullname function. When username parameter is true, then print the username instead of the user's full name. Otherwise, behave normally. That way you could do a grep of the code and see when fullname is being used and simply add the additional parameter to fullname function and get what you want. In any case, that is just one idea off the top of my head. As I said at the beginning, it is not really recommended. Peace - Anthony

Forum Post: 
Post title: Final Grade of a Course - How to
Post description: Hello everyone, I have a course with 14 topics and 1 quiz per topic (14 quizes), and at the end of the course there is a global quiz with questions on all topics. I want the calculation of the total grade of the course to be as follows: 40 % corresponds to the average grade obtained in all 14 topic-quizes. 60 % corresponds to the grade obtained in the global quiz. How can I do it? What formula should I write? I tried = sum (average ( III.1 , III.2 , III.3 , III.4 , III.5 , III.6 ]], III.7 , III.8 , III.9 , III.10 , III.11 , III.12 , III.13 , III.14 ) * 0.4 III.Final * 0.6) But it does not accept it .. Thanks in advance.. Regards,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Pablo, The best way to configure the grade book is by using weights instead of writing formulas. Since Moodle version 2.8, there is a flexible grade aggregation method named Natural. I configure many grade books and have found Natural aggregation to be the best way to implement any grading scheme.  Refer to https://docs.moodle.org/34/en/Grade_aggregation#Natural In your case, I would create a grade Category: 'Topic Quizzes'.  Move all the topic quizzes into the Topic Quizzes category. You don't need a separate category for the Global Quiz since there is only one item. Set the Topic Quizzes category weight to 40 and set the Global Quiz weight to 60. Done! No formulas needed. Floyd
Comment 2: Hi Pablo, As already has been suggested, I'd use the Gradebook setup to get this to work. Here are the steps to follow to make this work. In site administration > Grades > Grade category settings make sure to have the following aggregation methods enabled: Mean of grades Weighted mean of grades Simple weighted mean of grades In addition to the natural aggregation that was already discussed. Then go to your course, open the Course settings menu and go to Gradebook setup. At the top of the gradebook setup table, there will be a folder icon and your course name. To the right of this, you'll find an Edit link with a menu. Edit the settings at this level to set up the proper aggregation method. I'd select Weighted mean of grades. Then use the Add category button to add a grade category sub folder, to move the 14 topic quizzes to. Set the weight of this sub folder to 4,0. Next, set the weight of the global quiz to 6,0. This will result in the following: The average grade of the 14 topic quizzes will be counted 4 times, the grade of the global quiz will be counted 6 times. 4 * av grade Topic Quizzes + 6 * grade Global quiz / 10 = course grade -- All in all, setting up the gradebook is quite a challenge, but I hope this will help you. In any case, refer to https://docs.moodle.org/34/en/Grader_report for all information on this very interesting topic.
Comment 3: Done!! I followed the steps you told me: 1. I modified the Course folder aggregation method to "Weighted mean of grades", and max grade: 10.00 2. Then I created one subcategory: Category name: Topic Quizes Aggregation: Mean of grades Maximum grade: 10 I moved the 14 quizes inside that folder and set the weight to 4.0 3. I weighted the global quiz to 6.0. That's it!! It was easier than I thought! Thank you for your help!

Post title: Preventing course changes from affecting the grades of past students
Post description: I am using Moodle in a self-serve, corporate training environment. As such, we don't really have "classes" that start and end on particular dates. Everyone signs up for a metacourse, which enrolls them in all of the courses, which are available to whoever wants to take them, whenever they want. As a result of this, anyone who has ever signed up is perpetually treated as an active student in the course. This poses a problem because it means that if I add a gradeable activity (like a quiz) to a course, it immediately lowers all of the previous students grades. What I want is some way for students to take a course, and then have Moodle know when they are done, and "freeze" their grade so that it isn't affected by subsequent changes to the course. Forum Post: 
Post title: Course Version Control, Course Runs & Program Management
Post description: Hi everyone, I have hit some road blocks and was hoping to get some help in creating courses. I teach Course A, which runs every quarter. Q1 Is there a way to create one course i.e. Course A and have 4 runs of the same course and enrol 4 totally different batches of learners. Q2 In addition, these 4 runs could have minor changes i.e. some topics/ contents are updated and outdated as time passes . Any suggestions on how to do version control? One of the solution to the above 2 problems will be to create 4 independent courses. However, it wasn't so desirable since I still deem the learners from the 4 runs having completed the same courses. Any ideas on how else I could configure them? Q3 Lastly, if we have course A, B, C & D, is there a way to sequence & bundle them together and create a Programme/ Curriculum X out of it? These courses could also be part of other Programmes/ Curriculum Y, Z etc
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi I face the same issues. You can duplicate courses, and choose whether to copy user data to the new course (you wouldn't). You could name the first course "Course A - Q1 - 2020" and then duplicate for Q2. In the Q2 course, make your changes. Duplicate Q2 to make Q3 etc. Students will be associated with the course that they did, and their grades will be linked to that course. "I still deem the learners from the 4 runs having completed the same courses" You could create a course called "Course A - Master". Students who complete Course A - Q1 etc are then enrolled in Course A - Master using a plugin. You then manually enter their grade for their Q1 course as their grade for Course A - Master. Over time, all students who complete Course A will be listed in Master with their final grade. The details of their participation will still be accessible in the course that they did. Programming a learning path and dependencies can be done using plugins, but the viability strongly depends on how much automation you hope to achieve, and the logic of how students flow from one course to another. You'll have to be really clear about your workflows and rules, and then investigate using plugins. Regards Brendon
Comment 2: Hi Brendon, Thanks for sharing. Was wondering if the plugin your mentioned is Meta Course? I was reading the other posts on this forum and meta-course seems to be a promising function to manage the courses and course runs. I will be trying out to ascertain if it works. If you have used it, would be great to hear more on your experience. Separately, I will also check out learning path in Moodle. Thanks!
Comment 3: Unfortunately, I haven't tried Meta-courses.

Comment 1: Hi Tina, I don't think there's any front-end setting to change where the feedback to a question within a Lesson is displayed. It is at the bottom under the question, as you've found out. One way to prevent students from getting confused is to keep a question page small. How about including only the question and the response choices? This way the feedback (after the question is attempted) can probably be seen even on a laptop screen without the scroll bar. I think keeping a question page small is also good for reducing cognitive burden, compared to presenting students with a lot of content and then a question all on one page. Ravi
Comment 2: Tina -would it help if you used content pages for your questions instead of question pages (if they are simple multiple choice questions)?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Need Moodle advice: How to export grades that clearly distinguish 'Absent' (never accessed course) from 'Free' (completed course but no final exam) without manual Excel filtering"
Post description: Hi everyone, I manage a training platform where participants receive one of four possible statuses: Approved – Passed the course and final exam. Failed – Completed the course but didn’t meet the passing requirements. Absent – Enrolled but never accessed the course. Free – Completed the course content but never took the final exam. The challenge comes when I download the grades and try to upload them to Moodle. Currently, I can’t find any way for Moodle (or my platform) to clearly separate Absent from Free in the exported grade file. Both categories end up mixed, and I have to run a time-consuming manual process: Filter the list of participants who never accessed the course. Compare them one by one in Excel with the “Duplicate Values” function to identify the correct category. This manual comparison works, but it’s inefficient, especially with large groups. My question: Is there any way in Moodle to export or process grades so that these four statuses appear clearly (Approved, Failed, Absent, Free) without having to manually filter and compare in Excel? Thanks in advance for any tips, plugins, or workflow suggestions!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As you imply, you don't have any problem between "Approved" and "Failed." Students get the grade that they get. Of course, you still need to set the "failed" grade. In my case, I use letter grades. Any "F" means that the student has failed. This is usually a final grade below 60%. For absent, you would still need to define it. What if a student does the first week assignments, then nothing else? You might want to define this as a grade below 5% or 10%. If the registrar need more information, you might have to look at the student's last access date, which you would see in the participants listing. That "free" category is the tricky one. What do you do with these "free" students? I don't use a free category like this. If a student doesn't take the final exam, they get a "0" for it, and it is weighted into their final grade. I don't try to get into the students' heads to figure out why they choose not to take the final. But I teach adults, and I expect adults to be responsible. I normally need to export grades into Excel to prepare them for uploading grades into the university's system. So if I had to do this, I would incorporate some Excel logic that says, "If final exam grade is null, then final grade = N/A (or something like that, whatever your system uses). I don't use Moodle's "course completion" features. I just use the grade book. My school wants me to document why a student "failed." For these students, I just send the Registrar a copy of the student's grade book and let the grade book speak for itself. Again, I don't try to get into the student's head.
Comment 2: Hello! Thank you for your kind response. As you mentioned, my issue is not differentiating between a student who has passed or failed, nor the subsequent entry of their grades, since that is specified in each student’s final status when they are graded for the course. The organization I work for specifically requires these two distinctions between “absent” and “free” (i.e., those who did not attend or attempted the exam). If it were up to me, they would all be grouped the same since they are still considered failed students. These are short self-managed courses that provide immediate certificates afterward. I am looking for a way to differentiate those students who did not enter the course or never took the final exam in Excel, so that it is easier to load their grades accordingly.
Comment 3: Can you post a mock-up of what an ideal Excel file would look like for these four groups?
Comment 4: Maybe OP can use SQL or Custom Reports to generate the report he needs. This will depend on what version of Moodle they are using and if the final grade is posted as Pass/Fail/Absent/Free.
Comment 5: never mind - Moodle already most elegantly provides this functionality in the Grade/Export report, if the letter grade values are Pass/Fail/Absent/Free.

Post title: Articulate support moodle ?
Post description: My client have Articulate  package, and want to execute in course resources/activity. I have try to run this with Scrome and other activity resources. But I am still fail to run it. Please advise me, how to run with moodle
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The issue seems to be that Articulate does not always create fully SCORM compliant resources, or perhaps the Articulate SCORM packager includes things that do not fit well into Moodle. This discussion goes into some issues, and they may be related, if they are using Articulate Storyline
Comment 2: Dear Lokesh Jain , I'm using articulate with moodle more than 4 yrs now, so  you have to check the setting in the articulate first before start to publish the package, You must be sure that you publish to LMS, and also the way you want to track the package below you will find the steps i hope it will be useful for you: Articulate
Settings: From
within your Articulate Presenter project, access the "Publish"
feature. Select
LMS as the publishing option Click
on the SCORM Reporting and Tracking button Enter
course description on "Reporting" tab (Optional) Click
on the "Tracking" tab and set the project to track slide views
or a quiz score. Slide
views - Best used for Presenter projects that don't include a quizmaker
or Learning Objects quiz. Quiz
score - Best used for Quizmaker and Presenter projects that include a
Learning Objects quiz. Click
OK and Publish After
publishing, compress all of the published files into a compressed Zip
folder Moodle
Settings: From
the Moodle course site in Editing Mode, add a "SCORM/AICC"
Activity.  A common mistake is to use the "Link to file or web
site" resource. After
selecting the "SCORM/AICC" activity, you will be able to upload the zipped folder of published articulate files. After
uploading the zipped folder, click the "Choose" option. From
here you will be able to adjust the rest of the settings to your liking. Once
you have all the settings adjusted you can go back to the course site and
test your Articulate project.  After completing the project your
grade should show up in the grade book on the course site.
Comment 3: You may also want to try using the TinCan or experience API approach, though I must say that there is still work that needs to be done here in getting data back to Moodle to make this option fully attractive.

Post title: Setting up a reflective journal
Post description: Hi All, I am looking for different ways of setting up a "reflective journal"  on each course. The course would have up to 30,000 students enrolled. Here are the few things I am hoping to achieve. 1) Students can reflect on the courses and add entries. 2) The Teacher can filter the students in a course to find their entries and accordingly add feedbacks to it. Any other ways to have a reflective journal in moodle courses ? Thanks, V.
Comments associated with the post:

Create instances of this activity and then you can filter the entries of students by going into the "view all assignment". This will let you see the entries and add comments to it.

Post title: Students Create Flash Resources
Post description: This is not terribly sophisticated, but some may find it useful: 1. You create a forum in which you list vocabulary items related to a topic you're teaching. I teach German, so I could provide a list of words that can describe people, for example (nett = nice, freundlich = friendly, gemein = mean, laut = loud, and so on). 2. Have students go to http://www.spellmaster.com/ , where they may create simple, interactive vocabulary practice activities in Flash. 3. Students then upload their Flash activities to the forum, so that other students may access them. 4. Students may provide feedback in the forum about the activities. Of course, there are other modules that you might prefer to use for this. I just really like the forum module. At any rate, it's a fast, free, easy way for students to become content creators and for everyone to practice vocabulary.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to offer the same courses repeatedly
Post description: Hi there! I am very new to Moodle. My asking is how to offer same courses repeatedly after each semester for different group of students. Let's say some students have finished one semester and are allowed to register for other new courses, how do we deregister him/her from the previous courses. Will it affect the overall grading of the students for those courses? Or after the course duration being finished, all students will be deregistered. Please advise.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ataur, And welcome to Moodle! There's a variety of strategies for re-using courses and activities in Moodle. See: http://docs.moodle.org/26/en/Reusing_activities
Comment 2: Hi Ataur, Here's what we usually do with our courses. At the end of a term, we Hide the course. This way, students can no longer see the course and teachers can still access the records if a student questions their grades. We keep the course in place but hidden for at least one more term. Then, we download the backup and archive it offline. If the same course will be used in the following term, including all resources and activities, then we make a Backup of the original course shell and Restore it as a new course. This gives us a "fresh" course shell for the teacher to use. Why don't we re-use an existing course shell? If we re-use the existing course, then we no longer have easy access to logs from the previous term. We may need such access if a student questions their grades. We sometimes have a student who re-takes the course because they dropped out or did not complete the course in the previous term. If we enroll that student into the course shell, then all of their previous work and logs show. I hope this is helpful.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Show-Your-Work to Discourage Students Cheating Online
Post description: Is there a way for Moodle to timestamp student's work, to show they took notes and prepared drafts over a set period of days or weeks? The idea would be to get students out of the notion they can just do work shortly before a deadline. I realize I could scaffold the work and chop it up into little assignments and other tasks, each with deadline, but I don't to be that prescriptive. Also I considered a Wiki, as that has time stamps and version control. But Moodle's wikis do not appear to allow binary attachments.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you considered using the Diary plugin?
Comment 2: Hi Tom, Is this a matter of finding the right tool, or creating the right instructional design and learning tasks? To me, it would make sense to break your design down into smaller portions that you could release on a time/date or completion condition. Something like this: Prep task 1 - Read ==> complete if viewed Prep task 2 - Reflect on reading (using a forum) ==> complete once posted and replied to peer Prep task 3 - Quiz (formative assessment) ==> complete once grade received Final task - Assignment, access condition Prep Tasks have to be completed Shouldn't be too hard to create, and this would help you have some control over what your students are doing. Also, the activity completion report would give you some idea of which students would need additional support.
Comment 3: In the analogue days we had the concept of one's own summary of what he has learned. Ideally done as the course progressed, naturally on paper. Often students were allowed to take their own summary to the exam - in extreme cases, it was the only document allowed during the exam. Are you looking for the digital equivalent? AL's suggestion is the one-to-one translation. Here the summary becomes an activity of its own. The method Joost proposed is the modern "instructional design" approach. It eliminates the "journal" alltogether, but forces the students to do those tasks through https://docs.moodle.org/en/Activity_completion .

Forum Post: 
Post title: How can I create a hot spot in Moodle?
Post description: I am interested in a kind of test where the student has to identify an element on a picture. If I would the student to learn the parts of the body, arm, head, finger , a way culd be a picture where the student can click and by this click on the picture identify the (correct) element. How can I create a hot spot in Moodle?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Install this add-on: https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=qtype_ddmarker
Comment 2: Thanks
Comment 3: Jan, The drap-and-drop labels questions (there are two of them) from OU are very good.  However, they are not hot spots.  I use them but wish there were a hot spot question type because labels can very quickly crowd an image.  They are also difficult to use if the thing you want your students to identify is small. For example, I sometimes teach geography and use the drag-and-drop questions for labeling continents and oceans.  However, I cannot figure out how to create a question that requires students to identify all 50 of the United States.  Even doing a small subset of the 50 states quickly clogs the map with labels and it is difficult to label small states like Rhode Island and Delaware. One work-around is to label your image and then ask students to match the labels on your image to items from a drop-down list.  In my case, I could label California as 'A', Texas as 'B', and so on.  I would then ask my students to tell me (matching, multiple choice, short answer) which state was labeled 'A', which was 'B', and so on.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Forum dilemma
Post description: Setup 1 forum 10 groups of students What I'm trying to achieve: A student should be able to post to all groups A student only receives a notification when something is posted to his group. I have been playing with several set-ups, but can't get the above to work. Separate groups makes that the student can not see the other groups. Visible groups make it so that the student can see other groups, but not post to them So then I went with the permissions structure. There seem to be 2 permissions: moodle/site:accessallgroups mod/forum:canposttomygroups However, if I grant the above two permissions to a student he can post to all groups... but he also receives notifications from EVERY post. Anyone know if there's a solution to this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I don't think that this is going to work at all. Forums are designed for open participation, once enrolled. I suspect you will either have create 10 forums and enroll individually, or create 10 new courses with a forums and enroll accordingly.
Comment 2: 10 courses is no solution I think. How many courses can a student and a teacher participate in? For a student i would say around 10-15 at the same time. For a teacher this might even be a lower number. Then 10 forums might be an option.
Comment 3: There is no limit, effectively, to the number of courses a Student can be enrolled in, same with a Teacher. The only limit is, really, practicality and institutional practice. It might be a practice that a Student is enrolled in X number of courses in semester 1, but X - 3 courses in semester 2. Or they may be enrolled in 2X - 3 courses all year, spreading them throughout the whole year and not on a semester basis. The next year, they may continue enrollment in those courses for the first semester, but also be enrolled in Y courses at the same time. In this instance, if you have 10 groups with 10 participants in each group then 1 forum and 1 group in each course is not impractical and maintains complete security as the only person to move between each forum is the Teacher. Having said all that, there is also an option of using Groups within a forum , this Moodle Doc might give you some insight into how you might be able to manipulate forum users  so you can get it to work the way you want. You might still have 10 forums, but in one course.
Comment 4: Some of this can be handled with optional or initial subscription, in the sense that a student has some tools to manage what he/she receives notifications from, once he/she has posted something in a forum discussion, much in the same way the Moodle Community Forums have been set up to be. Maybe forced subscription isn't the way to go for this scenario, so try the other two.

Forum Post: 
Post title: AUP
Post description: has anyone devised a VLE AUP or written a section in their acceptable AUP policy ? any pointers or samples would be greatly appreciated David
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'm working in a primary-aged school, so this may not suit your particular context , but we made things fairly simple, along the lines of 'you behave online as you would in the classroom'. Here's what we say: The key idea is that you behave in this Virtual Environment just as you would in a normal lesson . This means: You concentrate on the work! So our focus is on this to help us to learn, although we can have some fun occasionally too; You
treat everyone with respect: you really mustn't write anything which
might upset anyone else, or that you wouldn't mind seeing written about
you yourself; You join in, so post entries to the glossary, reply to other people's questions etc.; You ask for help if you're not sure about something, or are challenged - the homework discussion is a good place for this; You respect others' privacy, so don't use someone else's username, or let other people know your password; and You look after shared resources, so try not to break anything! Whilst
we should be the only people able to use this, I don't want to take any
chances, so don't include your phone number, address or anyone else's
in anything you write here - the same applies to any other website you
visit! Above all though, enjoy using all this and make the most of it!
Comment 2: We have one for a K-12 school at the link below...feel free to use anything you may find useful. http://www.modellabschool.com/online/mod/resource/view.php?id=3#internet Steve
Comment 3: In our high school district, every teacher who wants to use moodle must first follow the attached lesson plan.  Among other things, it requires students to read the District's computer/network AUP (which does not make specific mention of moodle).
Comment 4: thanks for this, it has given me a lot ot think about, thanks again for the samples, david
Comment 5: You might also be interested in Drew Buddie's work at Royal Masonic , in which his students use Moodle's wiki module to construct their own AUP. How's that for social constructionism ?
Comment 6: what a great idea ! I might actually give it a go for a VLE specific AUP. David
Comment 7: What is AUP? Rich
Comment 8: Acceptable Use Policy Steve

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle only for examinations
Post description: My college doesn't use e-Learning at all, and we do everything the good old way. Now I want to introduce e-Learning, and I came across moodle during my search for a solution. As there really is no e-Learning system, everyone will show resistant to adopting new approach, and I can only convince others, if I can show how e-Learning will REALLY help them (teachers and admins). The best way seems to be online exams, as currently, teachers and admins are too much overloaded with exam works. Then, I will gradually add (or start using) other functionalities. So here is the workflow I propose, and would like to know can moodle handle this, or rather, can I handle this using moodle? There are six semesters to be cleared for a degree (B. Sc.). There are 4 subjects. Physics, Chem, Bio, Maths. Students in Semester 1,2 will have 3 subjects out of above 4, in each semester. Students in Semester 3,4 will have 2 (from previous 3) subjects, in each semester. Students in Semester 5,6 will have only 1 (from previous 2) subject, in each semester. The number of papers will vary from 4-6 every semester. Respective subject department will conduct tests for their subject. Now, with this background I expect the following workflow. 1. Student will enroll/register when he/she enters Semester 1. His credentials won't change until he/she gets degree. 2. Student will use his/her login credential only for online exams, which will be open for a limited period say 3 hrs, and conducted within campus on intranet (college LAN) 3. After each exam, a collective mark-sheet of all the students who took the exam can be obtained from moodle stats/reporting. 4. Students can be promoted to next semester upon completion of required grades/credits in all subject papers manually or automatically. I don't wish to use any other moodle functionality, except student registration and exams/automatic grading, for time being. Can this be done with moodle?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Mitesh Yes, it can be done via moodle. For more help you can check Moodle docs http://docs.moodle.org/24/en/Main_page
Comment 2: Hi Mitesh, The quiz module in Moodle is a powerful tool with many settings that will probably cover all of your needs. http://docs.moodle.org/24/en/Quiz_module However, before you consider rolling out Moodle for such large-scale assessment, you need to think about the administration and quiz creation work involved. A couple of years back I campaigned for Moodle to be introduced in the international development charity I worked for, and I was successful - but since then administering our Moodle has become a big part of my job (but I don't have any problem with that). If you don't have access to any Moodle system, you can install a Moodle package on your own computer (a local installation - won't be on the Internet), and you can play around with the different features. You can show your colleagues a demo from your computer. Best wishes, Ravi

Forum Post: 
Post title: Multiple Enrollment Methods
Post description: Happy Tuesday Moodlers! Are there any issues with having a Learner enrolled in a course twice with two different enrollment methods?  Not going to go into how this happened - it just did and I am wondering if I need to remove the duplicate enrollment method. Version of Moodle - 3.10 Enrollment methods - self and manual Thank you in advance for any assistance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: no problem as example , i use self enrolment and make it for 1 hour as a trial for my courses , and when user want long access , i may use manual , cohort , credit ...... according to what i want . you will see that the same user is inactive regarding to self enrollment , and active without editing gear if enrollment via cohort , if he active with one methode and inactive voia othe , the active status is the real staus
Comment 2: It's not a problem and you don't need to remove either of them if they are not interfering with any other reports etc. It's not uncommon for this to happen with multiple enrolment methods active eg A student may be directly enrolled on a module, but may also be enrolled on it through a cohort link, or meta-link A user maybe automatically enrolled with one role, but manually enrolled with a different role They are still a single user on the course, so there is no conflict with them having multiple enrolment methods as far as gradebook or participants lists etc are concerned. If you feel you need to, you can remove one of the enrolment methods, though
