Post title: Course Certificate Not Updating
Post description: Good afternoon, We are using WP 3.10; we migrated course completion information from legacy system; certificate was created with date user completed course in old system; user completes the course (one SCORM module) today in Moodle but new certificate is not issued.  Completion shows on dashboard as today but certificate is from last year. I expected the certificate to be updated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jackie, Have you tried contacting the Moodle Partner your organization's working with to facilitate the Moodle WP? Not many members of this community will have hands on experience with the intricate nature of WP, as it is only available through Moodle Premium Partners...
Comment 2: Hi Joost. I don't believe that there is anything different with the way Moodle WP handles things for functions like course enrollment updates and certificates. This is not a WP-specific question. This appears to be the standard reply if you mention WP. UGH!!!
Comment 3: Hello again Jackie. Can you confirm the type of certificate it is? Because I remember that you recently posted in the Certificate forum about the custom certificate ( a plugin) rather than the course certificate that you are mentioning now (which originated in WP and is now available as a plugin for standard Moodle)
Comment 4: Hi Mary. We are not using a custom certificate. You had moved my post to the Certificate forum because of the way I worded my post. We are using the standard course certificate. This issue isn't really about the certificate. At the time I posted, I had unenrolled a user in a course and the previous certificate did not go away. I have since found, through a lot of digging, that Moodle does not delete a certificate when enrollment is deleted. In order to get another certificate issued, you must manually delete the original certificate from the database .
Comment 5: Hi Jackie, I'm sorry if you feel I'm using a 'standard reply' for anything Workplace related. Let's cover all the generic open source Moodle questions you can use to troubleshoot the issue: Have you checked whether the access restriction for the WP Course Certificate was set up properly? Have you checked whether the participant qualifies for the new WP Course Certificate (i.e. does he/she meet the requirements set up above)? Have you set up the WP Course Certificate to automatically release a certificate when a user meets the requirements? If you haven't, the user is required to open / click on the activity to receive the certificate. Have you checked whether the maintenance scripts are running properly? As far as I know, these are the steps to follow to troubleshoot the issue you're describing. The reason for my original reply is that you pointed out you're working on a Workplace instance of Moodle, which is not available to all users in this community and is always facilitated and supported through a Moodle Premium Partner.
Comment 6: Hi Joost. No need to apologize. I'm going to quit indicating I'm using WP when I post a question. So much of WP is standard Moodle as in this case and pretty much every time I have mentioned the version of Moodle I'm using, I get the answer you provided no matter what the question is.  And, of course, there is no documentation or Forum for WP. I can answer 'yes' to all your questions. This is a rather unique situation as we are migrating courses, completions from another LMS and having some issues. What I found after a lot of digging in the database is that Moodle does not delete or flag the certificate when you delete an enrollment. So, a user could not be enrolled in a course but have a certificate of completion for the course. To get the result I was looking for, I had to delete the certificate in the certificate table and then delete the enrollment. I do appreciate that you did try to help - thank you!!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Is anyone using Moodle for high-stakes math test preparation?
Post description: I recently posted this on the Mathematical Tools forum, but didn't get any responses. I know there are math teachers who participate in this forum, so I'm trying again here. This will be my one (and only!) cross-post. ----------- I would like to hear from K-12 math teachers in the US who are using Moodle to prepare students for high-stakes math tests, including SAT and ACT (college entrance exams) Advanced Placement (AP) exams State-specific tests mandated under No Child Left Behind ( NCLB ) I am especially interested in the NCLB tests and how you have used Moodle to raise the scores of at-risk students. I have done some work in this area, and I will be glad to share my ideas and experiences with you. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'm surprised not to hear from anyone on this. Preparing kids for high-stakes math tests is big business. Teachers are doing it during school hours, and companies are doing it in after school programs. At the high school where I taught, every 9th, 10th, and 11th grade math teacher's lesson plan was required to have an NCLB component. There were actually teachers (such as myself) whose entire job was preparing the at-risk students for tests. There are over 500 companies providing "supplemental educational services" (funded through NCLB) in after-school programs. Is it really possible that none of these is using Moodle? And if so, is it because Moodle (and its social constructionist philosophy) is at odds with accountability-based ideas about education? Or is it because Moodle's technical feature set does not lend itself to this application?
Comment 2: is it because Moodle (and its social constructionist philosophy) is at odds with accountability-based ideas about education? John, I would not be surprised if this were the case. A
Comment 3: We built a separate course called "AP Science/Math Test Review", and made all the science and math faculty its teachers.  They then posted documents, weblink, PDFs, etc., as resources in that "class" prior to the AP exam.   This includes both subject-specific information as well as general test-taking tips.  Teachers then remove items just after the exam. This is admittedly not particularly creative, nor is it using fancy Moodle features; but it has proven helpful for students and easy for faculty.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Turning child courses into metacourses?
Post description: I am sorry if you have seen this post twice, I think I may have posted the original in the wrong place. I have been looking for a way to use the metacourse function to enroll a single group of students in 24 separate courses (each course being a single weeks module of a 24 week course.) I had added all 24 courses to a single metacourse, thinking that each child course took the student enrollment from the parent metacourse. Now I have realized that the opposite is true, the metacourse takes the student enrollment from the child courses! My problem is how to turn the child courses into metacourses. I have deleted the single metacourse but the option to change the child courses into metacourses is not available, I get the following message: Is this a meta course? No - This course already has normal enrolments. The message still appears even after I have removed all users. I do not want to start adding courses from scratch again, so does anybody know of a way to change the child courses into metacourses please?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Might be a long process over 24 courses, but if you backup and then restore the courses, then during the restore process you are given the option of making the new course a meta. If you don't have student enrollments in the course yet then you can restore and replace courses. If you do have enrollments then I'm not sure how you could make it work because restore/replace removed existing enrollments.
Comment 2: Thanks Darrel, I tried that but when restoring the course the metacourse option is unavailable, it says that the course has enrollments already, even though none of the enrollment was backed up. I have had to rebuild all the courses, but at least I have got the hang of the metacourse idea now! Though I must say, it seems to me that the logic of child and metacourses is back to front. Robin
Comment 3: Hi Robin, I also replied to your question in the other place that you had posted the same question.  Please check it out.  I have had success with changing my metacourses doing them this way.  Hopefully it was explained okay to make sense. Good Luck

Forum Post: 
Post title: Use the Calendar to Assign Resources?
Post description: Hi all, I'm trying to figure out if this is possible. If I plan on teaching a course and I only want my students to see the calendar and what they're supposed to be doing, how can I accomplish this? I know i can set up a "weekly" format, but then everything is just pushed in that week, similar to a topic. Basically, I have 21 different HTML pages that are integrated into moodle as Day 1, Day 2, Day 3, etc. I wanted to have a course that starts on April 1st and that when they login, they will see their calendar (Day 1) on April 1st. Then, on April 2nd, Day 2 will be released and so on and so forth. However, I don't want them to be able to advance a day without it actually BEING that day (if that makes sense). I need them to be able to go through the course as I design it. I know, technically, a way around this would be to just add an even to the calendar on April 1st with a LINK to the HTML page and do that for 21 days, but that's not even using the system at all. To sum it all up, I'm looking for a way to assign certain resources to certain days of the week. End of story lol.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I've been trying to think of a way you may achieve this but nothing obvious is jumping out at me. You could do it manually by hiding resources and making them visible as necessary but this will be time consuming and only really work if they all sign up on the same day.

Forum Post: Post title: Design Post description: Hi, Wondering who else is using these design tips and trick in moodle... Cheers Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Hi François, Good of you to share these examples of how some HTML / CSS / Bootstrap knowledge can help create more interesting courses. It would be really nice to see some of these available directly from the ATTO editor, by using the Generico tools set for instance. One remark though on the use of FontAwesome in Moodle. Somehow the '' tag in HTML is still being used, where a would make more sense from an accessibility point of view. The Brickfield tool (and others) will incorrectly identify the '' tag as an old-fashioned way to refer to text in italics, and recommend using the '' tag instead. Comment 2: Hi Joost, Thank you so much for the insight about . I planned to talk about the "aria" part in my next "accessibility" video, but I didn't see the problem with . I placed myself in the shoes of teacher doing just a "copy and paste", but indeed, span and aria should be recommended. 👍 Another accessibility issue is about colors. It seems some tools do manage perfectly "bootstrap variable names" and successfully change the whole page into white on black, even if primary or secondary was in the code... On the other end, some other tools are definitely not bootstrap ready/friendly (although boost and classic themes rely on bootstrap since version 3 I think). For accordion, I have mentioned the bootstrap long explanation on accessibility under my video... but visitors rarely unfold the description on youtube. *I just added your remark on in the description of the "icons" video* Thanks for your answer. Comment 3: These will scroll out of the forum shortly. Do you have another link for these videos - and for anything more you create? Good stuff. Comment 4: Hi James, Thank you for your message. Everything is available on Github, with a creative common licence: Moodle Design (here is an example of link turned into a button, with an icon). Hope this helps. Cheers Comment 5: Hi François, If you'd make the button open in a new window, it'd be even better ;) Comment 6: Hi Joost mmmm, on this one I think it would be not accessible to change the default action of a link. I would let the user decide what is best for him / her: same window with click, or other window / tab with cmd+click or ctrl+click, or with context menu via right click. Never tried if ATTO or TinyMCE accept target blank... or if it gets erased. Cheers Comment 7: I must have missed something as my copied accordion code is not interactive. Are there some preparatory steps? Comment 8: Hi James, No preparatory steps: only remark, you have to take accordion from version 4 of Bootstrap. What can go wrong: you use a moodle text editor like Tinymce which erases more code when saving than ATTO your theme designer made a theme that conflicts with Bootstrap included stuff (for example here) you have put multiple accordion on the page and the id used makes another accordion change (or a menu if your theme designer used the same default ids for the menu). Better to put it in a assignment where it is alone. you took the code from bootstrap version 5 or more that is all I can think of. Hope this helps Label:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Can moodle be setup so that different students progress through a course at different rates
Post description: Hi Everyone, We are seriously considering using Moodle as the learning system for a study course. But we have some key questions that need answering. If anyone could help, we would very much appreciate it. The questions are: 1. Can Moodle courses be setup so that individual students progress through the course at different rates? i.e. Student A starts the course in March and is confronted only with lesson 1, they complete lesson 1 then lesson 2 becomes available to them. Some time later Student B joins the course. We need it to be that Student B can only see lesson 1 (until he has completed it). Is this possible some how? Student A and Student B both need to be able to see each other on the course and communicate in common forums. 2. One of the course templates in moodle is a weekly view. How do you configure moodle to release each weeks content at the start of that particular week? i.e. when it is week 1 the students should only be able to see week 1, and as soon as we move into week 2, week 2 becomes visible. 3. When a student submits something to an assignment the teacher then is able to comment on that submission. That's great, but is there a way for the student to be able to reply to the teachers comment? In other words how can there be a dialogue between teacher and student on each assignment.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Maybe this will help: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Adding_activity_locks Many activities can be set to not be accessible until a certain date. We have our site set up so each topic is its own "course". And we only release the enrollment key on the first of the new week. It takes a bit of organization, but you can keep a handle on their progress.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Allow students to write and answer their own questions
Post description: Part of an internship I'm doing for my masters program is helping the teaching faculty do online teaching more effectively including use Moodle in more dynamic, creative ways. A professor I'm collaborating with asked me if there was a way to create an 'anticipation guide' so as to orient students to think ahead of the course material/lecture. Specifically, she would like students to be able to 1. Type in questions they think they have or will have about the content, 2. Have them watch pre-recorded lecture, and afterwards, 3) Their original questions are shown, and they are able to answer their own questions they asked at the beginning. One person suggested it might be possible to use make a link to a google form for them to write their questions and have that automatically turned into a spreadsheet. Then for the second prompt, pull the questions from the spreadsheet and create a 2nd form where they could then answer their own questions. I've been playing around with that as well Lessons and H5P, but I haven't had much luck into seeing if this is possible and, if so, how. Any advice would be greatly appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Try the add-on StudentQuiz https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_studentquiz .
Comment 2: Your activity is a variation of the KWL-technique, and this is quite simple to implement without automatic features: a worksheet where students write manually their questions and answers. In this case, you cannot monitor or see what they wrote. But I like it and I don't think online learning should kill the old and good handwritten note-taking a personal wiki, one for each student. A glossary would also do. Visvanath's proposal is another alternative. This has the advantage that, at the end of the activity, you will have a nice pool of questions adapted to the level of your students. This activity can also be the last step of the task if you use some of the previous techniques.
Comment 3: Hi Beatriz Although StudentQuiz is technically better for the teacher, it runs the danger of low quality responses - depending on the "setting".
Comment 4: Yes, I absolutely agree with you, Visvanath, I wouldn't use the created questions without reviewing them first, which is a lot of work.😓
Comment 5: ' I wouldn't use the created questions without reviewing them first,' Absolutely!. However even low quality questions can give an impression of common mis-understandings of a topic.
Comment 6: Hi Tyler, You might want to see about using the Content Pages (iContent) plugin. Effectively, it allows the teacher to create an activity that looks similar to a slide show. Students can save notes on each slide and can also ask questions. Slides can include questions from the question bank, but not all question types can be used.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Colour an image within an activity
Post description: Hi all, I hope you could spare a moment of your time to help me out with the following: I am looking for a way to make it possible for students to draw in an uploaded file. Here's an example to explain what I mean: Let's say, I have the world map, and I would like my students to give Europe the color ''Blue'', The US the color ''Red'', Latin-America the color ''Green'', and so on; How could i make this possible? I have tried using Sketch, but this does not allow me to see an image or the like... Any thoughts on this? Thanks a lot in advance for thinking along! Kind regards, Menno
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi DaVinci, Coloring a picture can be done with Poodll Assignment Submission. There may be other plugins to, but I have no experience with them. You set it up as an Assignment with submission type of, Online Poodll, with Poodll Rec. Type of, Whiteboard, and a Poodll Whiteboard Background of the picture you want the student to color in. You also need to set the Poodll Whiteboard size to fit the background picture size. When each student clicks, Edit submission, they see the whiteboard drawing editor with your picture already there for them to color in. The picture remains even if they need to erase part of their coloring. I know this works with png backgrounds, but will probably work with others, too. This works pretty good with just a mouse, but, much better with some kind of tablet and pen. The only downside to all this is that Poodll Assignment Submission also REQUIRES Poodll filter and Poodll filter DOES cost money. When I was actively still teaching, I just paid for an annual subscription out of my own pocket. However, you can do a 30 day free trial to see if it does do what you want, before committing to any payment. Just don't be shortsighted enough to think the money is not worth it for your students to color one or two pictures. The whole set of Poodll plugins that you get to use with the filter is simply staggering when you figure out and see what all you can do with it, especially when it comes to audio and video capabilities for teaching a foreign language, such as English. Along with the whole set of plugins, there are literally DOZENS of widgets available for use to enhance your site, lessons, quizzes, assignments, etc. A simple for instance, you can add a user or username filter that will personalize your site so each student is greeted by name when they log in. The Poodll developer, Justin Hunt, is active here in the forums, and is always quick to help, if you have any questions. What always impressed me the most, is that he is also quick to respond to feature requests, if at all possible. I can remember once making an idle remark, "It would be nice if......," (can't remember exactly what I wished for) but four hours later there was a new version out with the new capability. https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=13 https://poodll.com/plugin-poodll-filter/
Comment 2: Hi Al,
Comment 3: If you don't want to install all those Poodll plugins for a thirty day trial, I can give you access to a course as teacher and you can play with them there. Just send me an email for details if you want to. drachels at drachels dot com

Forum Post: 
Post title: Question about forums
Post description: I am the "help" person on my campus when it comes to all things Moodle. I've had two instructors who have set up courses who have the same question regarding forums: When they create the forum, and then create several discussion topics within the forum for students to reply to, we notice that whichever discussion topic was most recently responded to rises to the top of the list. This instructor wanted for each student to respond to each discussion topic in order. But the order keeps switching. I suggested to the professor that he number the discussion topics so that students would at least have a visual clue about the order in which they were meant to read and respond to the topic. But the instructor hoped there would be some way he could control this function. Any ideas? Dena
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Dena, Have you considered creating three separate forums - one for each question? This would nail down the order of the questions within the course. The instructors could use the "single, simple forum" type so that their question would be immediately visible at the top and so that no one else could generate a new topic ... if that's of importance. Susan
Comment 2: Thanks for the response Susan. That is actually one of the things I suggested to him, but he wasn't crazy about that idea, because he felt the forums were topically and thematically organized and the discussion questions fell under each general forum for each week. I'm glad to know I was sort of on the right track, though.
Comment 3: Dena - You were definitely on the right track. I like your idea of carefully naming the discussions to help the students know in what order they should respond. Generally speaking, having the discussions ordered by the ones with the most recent activity is considered a feature. The data is not stored as to when the discussion was created so to do a hack would involve modifying the forum_discussions table in the database and adding a field. It would not be too difficulty of a hack to allow for folks to choose between the sort methods (but it would be a hack). Which version of Moodle are you using? If you are interested, I suggest you submit a feature request in the tracker and reference this discussion. Good luck in responding to the teachers with their Moodle questions. Peace - Anthony

Post description: Hello I search about tools about disability in moodle and how enable or download , i review accessibility block  but it is not useful . i find letter about tools enable users to control it in profile.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, I don't really know of specific tools for disabilities in Moodle. Perhaps you could tell us what type of disability you want to accommodate and we might be able to come up with  ideas and methods of using Moodle that might work for what you need.
Comment 2: Moodle should not require specific disability tools. Users with a disability should be able to access Moodle using the same assistive technologies that they use to access other web sites.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Tool for creating non-online training materials and courseware
Post description: I've been training in the volunteer and corporate world for 22 years (the first I love, the second pays the bills).  I've used canned curriculum for most of that.   Now I'm going to start developing short seminars, workshops, and even just 1-hr presentations on several topics.  Any given topic, say Open Source Software (one of my current topics), I'd have a 1-hr speech/presentation, a 4-hr seminar, or a full day workshop .  Most of these are in-person, live presentations, so I don't need Moodle yet (getting there someday!). The question is, does anyone know of any good Open Source (or real cheap) software that will help me develop the courseware, handouts, workbooks, etc?  If it also had Insructional Design guidance for designing the course itself that'd be cool too! =Steve Thomas=
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Steve, sounds like Powerpoint would do most of what you plan to do. I would suggest using Moodle to house your different versions either as a class or as topics within a class. If you were to for example teach OSS and Basketweaving, you could have 1 hour workshops OSS Basketweaving Full day OSS Basketweaving Or you could arrange it by topic Basketweaving 1 hour All day
Comment 2: I really like eXe from exelearning.org. Open-source Greg Porter

Forum Post: 
Post title: Need to create database driven lists
Post description: Dear all, I have been using Moodle 1.9.2 (Build: 20080711) for teaching in University. I would like to develop some lists of hyperlinks leading to papers and lectures which would be available for download .  The list should be dynamic, meaning that I would need to frequently edit the contents of the list. So far I have used just html blocks linking to the documents, but this is a clumsy way and takes lots of time. Is there any function which I can use to create database driven lists to organise papers and documents which will be available for download on the frontpage? many thanks NIkos
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Nikos It would help to know how many you envisage listing, and how often you would add or amend. One simple way would be to list each one on an external blog and upload it there, then have a simple news feed block on your moodle site. This way the blog entry would be a short extract or summary, and clicking on it would reveal a full description and download button. Admitedly it is not a totally moodle-driven solution, but it is simple, cheap or free to set up and very simple to put the feed block where you want it. Good luck Ed
Comment 2: look at the database module. i think it can do what you want. one of the field types is link. if the downloadable files are within the same moodle, you can also use this module but a set of folder resources might be enough.
Comment 3: I would echo Robert on the Database Module. It also has a file upload field as well so this could work quite nicely for you.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Course Completion vs. Activity Completion
Post description: Using Moodle 3.10.  Is it advised to manually mark a course complete via the Course Completion Report or should you manually mark the activities complete and let Moodle mark completion at the course level.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jackie, Just out of curiosity, why would you want to do it manually when Moodle has a very good activity completion criteria feature? If you set it up correctly the activities and the course will mark completed automatically.
Comment 2: Happy Thursday, Giovanni, and thank you for your reply. I don't do manual completions using the Course Completion report, however, there are people in my organization that somehow started doing that. What I would like to know if this is a good idea and what, if any, repercussions there might be from marking the course complete and not the activities.
Comment 3: Hi Jackie, That would depend entirely on what your aim for the course is. If you'd require an instructor to sign off on a participant's work, in addition to recording the completion of course activities, you could set up course completion so a designated role can mark it completed. If you don't require an instructor (or multiple ones for that matter) to sign off, you're okay just using the automated course completion settings.
Comment 4: Happy Thursday, Joost, and thank you for your reply.
Comment 5: Hi Jackie, One of the situations where I'd expect a sign off be required, is when the course itself was taught by a trainer (non-editing) and a senior staff member has to validate all the results and outcomes of the course before marking the course as complete for a participant. This would be particularly interesting if completing course A is a requirement for access to courses B and C. The automatic bit I wrote about, does refer to the combination of activity completion and course completion. You can only add activities with completion enabled to your list of activities to be tracked for course completion. If your courses are marked as complete without a proper justification, I'd say an evaluation of that process would be more than just a nice to have. Are the conditions for course completion valid in these courses?
Comment 6: Happy Monday Joost! I hope you had a great weekend. I understand what you are saying and that was my thinking, however, we are currently using Reports, Course Completion to manually mark completion for users who for some reason did not get a completion because the SCORM module did not set completion as expected. Is it a 'Best Practice' to always mark the activities complete and let Moodle do its thing and mark the course complete? I am seeing situations where the course is being marked complete but not the activity. Does Moodle ever mark the activities complete based on the course being marked complete? I'm not aware of this.
Comment 7: course will marked complet , but not immiadtly , when the cron jop run , moodle will do it

Forum Post: 
Post title: Substitute teachers
Post description: Hello everyone,

I am a first time user of moodle and I am curious about how other people use moodle to organize their courses.
The installation itself went well, but now I have to think about how students and teachers communicate each other.

I can create courses, assign teachers and add students to courses. The internal messaging works fine, but not for all use cases.
(At least I am not aware of a solution for my problem)

Imagine a teacher A is teaching his language course for a certain time. She can easily exchange messages with her students, give advice to single students or inform all of them about urgent dates. Fine.

But what happens, if she abruptly is absent for a certain time. You need a substitute teacher. How can the new teacher be assigned to her course and read all the old messages and get pending messages addressed to the original teacher. I am fine with the internal message system. For us there is no need to setup our own mail server .

How do you manage this use case? I am a programmer from Germany, not a teacher. So I might miss the obvious solution.

Thank you in advance
Enno
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Enno, A new teacher would have a new account and therefore would not have access to user-to-user communication between the previous teacher and the students. If you'd want to have some sort of in course communication between teacher and individual students, you could consider the Journal activity . This allows all teachers to access communication between teacher(s) and individual students. It has been removed as a core module, but is still available as a plugin.
Comment 2: Hi Joost,

Thank you. I will give it a try.

Enno

Forum Post: 
Post title: Single course for various organizations
Post description: What would be the best practice for the following scenario. I have a course which will be taken by students from various schools. School X has 30 students from Grade 2A and 20 students from Grade 2B. Both Grade 2A and 2B have their own homeroom teachers, lets say Teacher 1 and Teacher2 School Y has 35 students from Grade 2A and 30 students from Grade 2B Both grades ave their own homeroom teachers, Teacher 3 and Teacher 4 What is the best way to setup my course so that both Schools can be registered with me and their Teachers are able to manage only their own grade pupils. Should I create multiple copies of my course and enroll the students and Teachers into their own courses or can I use the same course and somehow segregate the view of the Teachers? I know Students will not be able to see any data of another grade but how would I control the Teachers so they only see their own pupils?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Faisal, Should these teachers also be able to edit the content, or are you comfortable with assigning them a non-editing teacher role? There's a permission in this role that has been disabled, called 'accessallgroups' if I'm correct. If you add the teachers to their corresponding groups, and use Separate groups (forced) at course level, every group will appear to be the only group in the course, except for users with roles that would allow them to see all groups.
Comment 2: in addition to Joost Elshoff - perfect solution i think that make 2 courses will give your teachers a more space, they can add their own activites, padgs, themes ....... if the student from each scool will not share some thing , i think separte courses is better

Forum Post: 
Post title: Practical Assessments
Post description: Hello, I will be setting up Moodle for assessment marking and feedback for this academic year. Whilst we do have some written assignments, for which we intend to use the Turnitin plugin, the vast majority of our assessments are practical, and therefore we want to use Moodle purely to record the fact that a student has completed a practical assessment, assign marks and write feedback for these assessments. Any advice on the best way to set this up? Thanks in advance. Elizabeth
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Elizabeth, You can use the regular Moodle Assignment activity to do what you want.  When setting the Assignment up, remove the check marks for Submission types so students do not have to submit anything. Also set Submission setting so that students do not have to click a submit button nor do they have to accept the submission statement. It is up to you to pick the Grade type and Grading method that best fits your situation.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Course activity to facilitate this unusual forum-like use case
Post description: Hi all, We're building a course where our use case is super specific, and we're stumped on what plugin/activity we could use to make it work. Within our course, the re will be a certain number of people we identify as experts (this can be via a new role or they can be added as facilitators). Regular learners can enter an " Ask the Expert " style section on the course and ask a question. Any expert is able to view the question and reply to it. Learners cannot see each others' questions, or answers to other questions; only the ir own threads. In other words, our use case is: Students can submit a question/create a thread Questions/Threads are visible to all experts but not to other students Experts can reply to the question/thread Could we use the existing forum activity for this? We've looked into it and it doesn't seem to support anything this specific, but maybe we're overlooking something? Or is the re another existing plugin/activity that would help us with this? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Vedant, Using Forum you can do this if you set it to use Separate Groups, then create a group for each student and add all the Experts to each student group. Then the experts can see all the student posts but the students can not see each others. That's a lot of work to set up but it will work. (You can use the Upload user tool to create and manage such groups . Have you looked in the plugins database for something like this? I would think that someone may have a plugin to do this sort of activity.
Comment 2: Hi Randy, Creating the individual groups might be a last resort, but considering we'd likely have students continually added to the course over time this isn't a feasible long term solution.
Comment 3: Use the database activity. The trick is to enable approval for entries, but never approve entries, because not approved entries are invisible for other students. Your experts could then use the comments feature to „answer”. If you need more detailed instructions or a proof of concept, let me know! Hope this helps! Stefan
Comment 4: Ah, also you could do something similar with Glossary: just never approve the entries but allow comments by teachers. Glossary does not have the ability to understand Groups. But if your Experts are all in the teacher role or have the relevant permissions, it would work... As long as they don't approve entries, which if they do, will be viewable by all the students. The advantage of Database for this is you can create the data structure you want, if you need to do that. The advantage of using Glossary is you can just use one of the predefined formats and structures it has already.
Comment 5: Hi Stefan & Randy, I need to check that it is acceptable from a user experience standpoint, since the text in the plugin might be confusing, but I'm happy to report that functionally it meets our needs. Thanks a bunch!
Comment 6: For posterity: Rather than compromising on the user experience we are going to compromise on the "users can't see each other's posts" part and just use a forum (with students having replies disabled). Thanks to everyone for helping!
Comment 7: Hi Vedant, big thumbs up from my side for posting what you ended up doing! All the best Stefan
Comment 8: The community plugin Dialogue may also be of interest: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_dialogue
Comment 9: Hi Joost, Thank you for your suggestion. I'll definitely keep this in mind because we might need this plugin for another project we're working on. Unfortunately for this one, it doesn't quite meet the use case because a student would need to pick out an expert to ask their question to rather than posting as an open question (if that makes sense). Cheers!
Comment 10: There is also the Journal plugin as well: https://docs.moodle.org/400/en/Journal_module . I haven't used it recently, but it still looks maintained and has been around a long time. AL Rachels also maintains the Diary module which is similar but with more featurs: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_diary
Comment 11: Unfortunately these still fall in the zone of accomplishing the task but confusing our learners along the way. I think we're going to stick with the forum compromise, but it's good to know that these exist for future reference. Thanks!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Learning Pathways
Post description: Hello all, Trying to wrap my head around this. I have created competencies. I have created learning plans. That all worked. I am the administrator in a public sector agency with 2100 employees. What we want is to be able to have multiple learning paths for different sets of competencies. For example, supervisor competencies, leadership competencies, all employee competencies, job specific competencies. But, we don't need a supervisor enrolled in all of the courses we offer because they may have taken them already, they may have evidence of prior learning to show that they meet those competencies. How does one create a list of courses that has the competencies in that course, so the learners can go in and enroll into the courses that meets their needs? I hope this makes sense. I am currently on 3.11, but with the plan to upgrade here soon. Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This may be challenging as there are few reports to competencies and learning plans using SQL - ad-hoc contributed reports. So when you are trying to provide evidence or look at progress or provide employee guidance we do not have that functionality. If employees must have the competencies in the Leadership learning plan, instead of making them find the course and self-enroll - enroll those employees in those courses. They will complete the courses and achieve the competencies related to the course. Otherwise, you will need to educate your employees - each one to look at their Learning plans (I use the excellent, visual Monitoring of Learning Plans plugin - https://moodle.org/plugins/report_lpmonitointring ) which adds a block on each employees Dashboard page with access to their Learning Plan(s). Without this plug-in the employees would have to navigate to their Profile>Learning Plans page. For courses that we offer for self-enrollment (skills buildings courses), I add to the competency "select this link to self enroll in the ABC Skills course" with the appropriate URL to the course. Perhaps visit the Competencies forum - https://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=8266 Kind Regards
Comment 2: Hi Scott, What if your employees had a course catalogue in which competencies are listed for each course and employees could search for/filter by competencies? Maybe even with a smart filter like „courses that teach competencies that I need“?
Comment 3: Hello Stefan, YES! This is exactly what I wanted. Sad to hear it is not a system capability yet. It would seem like something that would be built into the core system by now. Unfortunately, my current budget won't allow me to have custom programming done. But thank you for the reply. I will look for another method. I know you can pull up the courses linked to the competency in the learning plan. So maybe my only option will be to teach the employees how to do this.
Comment 4: Hi Scott, I was not implying that you’d need to pay for it. If you want, feel free to book an online session at bdecent.de/schedule and we can discuss what I have in mind and check if it meets your expectations/requirements. If you have questions, feel free to contact me directly via our chat at chat.bdecent.de Happy Friday! Stefan

Post title: How to set time gap between two activities
Post description: Is there any settings using which I can set a time gap between two activities or lessons so that we make sure that the student do proper practice before starting the next topic and don't do all of them in one go. In restrictions, it is allowed to restrict using a particular date or some condition based on previous activity done or marks score. But as different users are enrolled in the same course and at different time, so  starting date may be different so we can not fix a particular date for each activity, just want to give some time gap according to the topic. Kindly guide me and give your suggestions for the same.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I haven't tried it, but there is this custom plugin https://docs.moodle.org/402/en/Reengagement_activity which can be used to enforce time between 2 activities.
Comment 2: If you're comfortable working with the Topics or Weeks format, there's an experimental feature called Course relative dates (admin shortname enablecourserelativedates, found under Site admin > Development > Experimental settings), which should enable you to set a number of days between activities, based on a participant's enrolment start date. It hasn't been fully implemented (it's still an experimental feature), but it may be useful. Moodle Docs on the topic: https://docs.moodle.org/402/en/Course_relative_dates

Post title: Blended Learning Travel Experience: How long before and after?
Post description: I'm going to be running a blended learning experience next summer that will combine a weekend in Chicago to visit the Tutankhamun exhibition at the Field Museum as well as two other local museums with Egyptian collections. The students will meet online first and have a follow-up period after. The question arises, how long should these pre- and post-trip periods last? I want participants to have plenty of time to do preparatory reading before the weekend and get to know eachother a little but don't want to have to spend a huge amount of time leading discussions beforehand. Likewise, I want to allow for sufficient time afterwards for follow up discussion online (and sharing of photos etc.) but need to take into account the fact that most participants will probably spend a day or two extra sightseeing in Chicago on their own before returning home so I can't assume that post-trip discussion would pick up immediately. On the other hand, I don't want to drag these on for a long time as this is a short trip (and I will hopefully be running much longer trips to Egypt itself in the future) and in order to make my fee reasonable and in proportion to the amount the participants will pay for the hotel, entrance fees, transport and food (I am currently working with a tour company to arrange a package) I don't feel I can run the course for too long. How would you handle it? Perhaps stagger the pre-trip portion? Open up the reading material somewhat early and then allow for discussion only in the period immediately before the trip (like 1 or 2 weeks)? And how long would you allow for follow-up? I may actually wind up running more than one of these trips a month or less apart if the first one fills up quickly so I don't want to run the risk of overlapping the online portion of the course and be too busy or worse yet, have an online portion of one course going during the weekend when I will be running another tour and be too busy to monitor what is going on online at all. You can read more about this trip here , but be aware that you will need to register at my site to view the description.

Post title: Science teaching
Post description: I am setting up a science-based Moodle site (my College is yet to see the light, but I am working on it!), and would like to discuss how other science teachers are using the tools to improve their teaching. My most pressing aim is to persuade the other members of my department to put in the additional effort to get the course up and running, so examples of ways of using Moodle would be greatly appreciated. My favourite uses so far have been: 1. using the Workshop module to prepare students for practical coursework. 2. including rotatable 3-D molecular structures in Lessons to explain about isomerism. 3. getting students to contribute suggestions for additions to Glossaries.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hiya, can I guess from your profile you're at Hills Road? There are the obvious things: links to the websites that students go to over and over, uploaded documents your colleagues has been using for years, carefully selected NLN packages using the object module. Have your colleagues already invested time in a website or intranet? The glossary remains my favorite tool in moodle; you may find it useful, if mercenary, to tailor your definitions to the kinds that appear in exam mark schemes. I developed a moodle course for A level physics (information and communiction) which can be found on the LSDA Q projects round 2 DVD, that should have made it into your college; that included lessons, quizzes, hot potatoes quizzes. [ I've got another project on the next disk (developed primarily for using Access in A level computing) that should be in colleges some time in the future - ask your eLearning manager. In the farther future, I'm developing materials for a physically realistic car racing game (Racing Academy), which will also be a free moodle course] Wiki's are great for group research tasks - e.g. energy resources in physics is a good area for a task to share between a group a students I've written a few sequences of resources/ activities that draw in material from a number of sources: e.g a recent one in physics had an intro (a web page), part of an NLN package to study, followed by a short assignment on it; then the rest of the NLN pack; a simulated practical using an applet on a website;  a discussion forum to post the results and a final assignment, being a report (that could potentially be Key Skills evidence). Hope this helps Andy D
Comment 2: Hi Andy, I am, as you surmised, at Hills Road!  I will track down your contributions (and am looking forward to the Racing Academy). I had already decided that the Glossary would be a very useful tool, and like the idea of linking a topic using various different modules.  I haven't quite known how to use wikis or blogs, but will try and find bits of the course that might get discussion going - possibly CFCs and the ozone layer. Post title: Research paper: Effects of Feedback Providers’ Positive Emotional Tone and Gender on Learning From a Multimedia Lesson
Post description: For anyone who might find this interesting or useful: Zhang, Y., Zhao, F., & Mayer, R. E. (2025). Effects of Feedback Providers’ Positive Emotional Tone and Gender on Learning From a Multimedia Lesson . Journal of Computer Assisted Learning , 41 (3), e70052. https://doi.org/10.1111/jcal.70052 Abstract Background and Objective : The positivity principle states that students learn better from instructors who display positive rather than negative or neutral emotions in multimedia lessons (Lawson et al. 2021a). This study extends this work by exploring the role of affective and social cues displayed by feedback providers, such as their emotional tone and gender, on multimedia learning. Method : In this between-subject study, 160 college students received a five-section video lesson on human vision, with two practice questions inserted after each section. After each question, students received explanatory feedback videos presented by either a male or female feedback provider who displayed either positive or neutral emotion through gesture and voice. Results : Students who received feedback from providers with a positive emotional tone rated the provider higher on perceived positive emotion, supportiveness and competence, as well as on their own feelings of positivity. However, the emotional tone of the feedback provider did not impact posttest scores. Additionally, female feedback providers were perceived to be more negative, less supportive and less competent than male feedback providers, but the gender of feedback providers had no effect on posttest scores. Conclusion : This study expands the positivity principle (Horovitz and Mayer 2021) and the cognitive-affective model of elearning (Lawson et al. 2021a) by showing that positive emotional cues from feedback providers enhance learning, similar to the impact of the instructor's emotional cues in presenting the main lesson. These findings highlight the broader role of positivity in creating engaging and supportive multimedia learning environments across contexts. Summary What is already known about this topic ○ Feedback is one of the most powerful influences on learning and achievement. ○ The instructor's emotions impact learners' learning experiences and outcomes. ○ The instructor's gender can affect how students perceive and evaluate instructors. What this paper adds ○ This paper examines how feedback providers' emotional tone and gender affect learning. ○ The emotional tone strongly influences students' emotions and connection with providers. ○ The gender type affects students' negative emotions and connections with providers. Implications for practice and/or policy ○ Positive instructors are viewed as more supportive and competent. ○ More strategies are required to address gender biases related to female instructors.* ○ In-person learning settings are more effective than unsupervised online settings. * This has already been shown in multiple studies to be an issue for organisations that attempt to evaluate teacher quality via student opinion polls. They discriminate strongly in depressingly predictable ways!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Re: "○ In-person learning settings are more effective than unsupervised online settings." - At least on the affective dimension, there's an interesting workaround for asynchronous feedback on students' work; The teacher makes a video screen recording of themselves reviewing the work & narrating their assessment of it as they go. Any notes that the teacher makes on the document during the recording can also be viewed by the student when the document is returned as part of the feedback, e.g. in the Assignment module. Students reported that they felt it was like having their teacher leaning over their shoulder & speaking to them while giving the formative assessment. Studies have also shown greater uptake of feedback, e.g. more likely to redraft & resubmit, & more engaged in subsequent assignments. However, few studies measured the difference in effect from screen recorded feedback vs traditional written feedback (Typical written corrective feedback has many issues & that's another important topic for discussion*). Those that did returned barely significant effects so, in short, great for engagement but little evidence of effects on grades. *I suspect that if combined with more evidence-informed (i.e. effective) formative assessment practices, there could be a measurable, perhaps even worthwhile, effect size on students' learning & therefore future academic performance.
Comment 2: This is a very useful study, Matt. Thank you for sharing.
Comment 3: Yes thanks Matt - I also found it very useful and interesting, although I did wonder about any differing cultural backgrounds of the students and any effect that might have - then I read in the limitations that the participants were college students from a single university. It would indeed be interesting to do the study again with a variety of institutions in variety of cultures.
Comment 4: Yes, it's important to point out the WEIRD* phenomenon. There are other studies that show similar biases. In all cases, there's a bias against female teaching staff; an important consideration in all cases, to at least some degree. *WEIRD: https://www.apa.org/monitor/2010/05/weird

Forum Post: 
Post title: Yearly course, same people. Update content or new course?
Post description: This is just an advice question. I appreciate all thoughts on the pros and cons. I have a yearly event with lots of volunteers. We train these volunteers with a series of videos contained in a Moodle course. Love it, provides tracking, competition etc. Every year, some number of the videos get updated and need to be viewed again. Of course, there are a lot of volunteers that come back each year, but we always have those that are no longer active and those that are new. So the question is, would you create a new (duplicate) course with the still current and new videos, or would you just update the videos in the current course? If you suggest the latter, would you make a new activity for the new videos, or just update the video in the current activity and use the update student notification, to alert them of the new content? This brings up another question, which admittedly I have not researched. If I update the content of a video what happens to the "completion" flag? Does it get reset to off, is that something I get to do myself? Thanks for providing any thoughts you might have on this. Just working thru how I want to update the course content for this coming year and years ahead. Ken
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ken - There are different ways to approach a solution, and I think this is how I would do it: I would set up a group in the course for each annual group of volunteers. I would make the videos available to the current group of volunteers using the restrict access feature . Once the current group has gone through the videos and the volunteering work has ended, I would download the activity completion report and any other relevant data for this group. Then I would remove access to the videos for this group. I would then update the videos and any other course materials -- whatever I have to do -- before the next group of volunteers signs up. I would give access to the updated videos to the new group. This group may have people who have volunteered previously, but that's not a problem. All volunteers in the current group can access only the up-to-date materials. With this approach, I wouldn't have to maintain multiple copies of videos on the course homepage, keeping the course layout light and manageable, and there's no risk of current volunteers accessing old videos. However, past volunteers won't have access to the videos they once saw. If you want past volunteers to have access to the old videos, you'll need to use a different process. Anyway, with groups and the restrict access feature, you can do a lot of creative things.
Comment 2: Thanks. That gives me some ideas to think about. I don’t want to require folks to watch a video they may have already seen, as some videos don’t get updated every year, but sounds like the restrict access might have what I need. Along with groups. appreciate it!

Post title: students submitting without uploading a file
Post description: Our students have an optional status as "Eligible for sensitive marking" when submitting coursework with an uploaded document or other file. This signals to markers the student may have dyslexia, for example. The problem we are having is "Eligible for sensitive marking" status means students can complete submission without uploading a document or other file. Our in-house IT support say Efsm is treated as a submission type, therefore those students can submit without uploading their work. This puts them at risk of disadvantage. Ironically, some of these students have more need for support when submitting via Moodle. Is this unavoidable? Is there really no solution to this? PS I am aware the teacher can Revert submission to Draft -- I need the student to be unable to submit without uploading a file in the first place.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Can you post screen shots?
Comment 2: What type of, "document or other file," is involved? Could you maybe use another plugin that might help prevent, "submission without uploading a document or other file," being left off? Maybe a plugin where the student work is done within the plugin, especially for instance, if it is some type of writing assignment.
Comment 3: Perhaps you could have two assignments, one for students with Efsm and one for those without. Create a restriction on each assignment based on an interaction prior (or over) to accessing the assignment. That interaction would dictate whether a student should be submitting to assignment for Efsm or assignment without. It could be two Text and media area (text would be I'm a student with Efsm or I'm a student without Efsm ) with manual completion where students either manually complete one or the other (you can set each to have a restriction must not have completed the other one). Then you set the two different assignments to be available only to the students that completed the corresponding Text and media area. Hope this helps!
Comment 4: Another option would be to create a group in your course, label it 'Eligible for sensitive marking'. With groups in an up to date Moodle instance, you can hide a group membership from view in such a way that only group members themselves can see it. You can then use this group to filter submissions (or non-submissions) in the same assignment, or to add group overrides for different deadlines etc.

Post title: Bulk distribution of scanned handouts
Post description: Hello, Still searching if there is any "easy " way to make a bulk distribution of scanned handouts in Moodle. I did publish a quite cironvulated way to do so  here : https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=381427#p1537545 , but not very satisfactory. Let's say my students did in class some paper work that I scanned afterward : then I would like to give them access in Moodle to their own scanned paper (that I may have digitaly annoted meanwhile while renaming the scans files). Any idea ? Any plugin which may help to do so ? Thanks, D.BODIN
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Dominique, Would a redesign of that process be workable? If so, you could: Set up an assignment with file upload submission and Annotate PDF enabled. After the class or session, you'd ask your students to take a picture (or pictures) of their work and upload these using the Moodle Mobile app directly to said assignment. By the time your grading and feedback should start, you open the assignment and annotate the work directly in Moodle. With the 'notify students' set to Yes, the students will receive your annotations and feedback as soon as you're done. And, using the grading workflow bit, you can even make sure to bulk release all the annotations at once, so you don't get the 'Have you checked my work yet?' questions from students.

Forum Post: 
Post title: rotisserie discussions?
Post description: Has anyone experimented with rotisserie discussions?  As I understand it,  a moderator first posts a question and a deadline, individuals respond but their responses aren't available until the deadline is reached.  The system then assigns each of the answers to another member of a forum to respond to.  Posts can also be rated but apparently, raters have only a limited number of points to hand out, so they have to choose carefully.  It seems like a combination of Moodle's FORUM and WORKSHOP modules.  I only came across it today, so I'm curious if any moodlers have explored this or if people are doing something similar with Moodle's discussion module.  Harvard's H2O project has made the code for the rotisserie mechanism available.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: We used to do something like this in the original Moodle classes, using a combination of a Journal activity and a Forum. Students would reflect in their journal, getting feedback from us teachers, then at some point we asked them to copy their entry into an "each person posts one discussion" forum.  Everyone was then encouraged to respond to at least three other texts in that forum. One could use the ratings in the forums, too.  We used the standard Connected/Separate learning scale but it could be anything.

Forum Post: 
Post title: 1 Teacher scale Installation of Moodle in a Philippine College
Post description: Merry Christmas Everyone! May I humbly offer my experience with installing, running and teaching in a one-teacher, 105 students, 2 subject installation of Moodle in our college.  Apologies in advance for grammar or whatever.  This paper is for my own use and has not been presented to a panel of experts yet (aside from you), and has not been edited by another person except myself. Following is its abstract: An exploratory study on use of the Learning Management System Moodle to two social science subjects. By installing a one teacher-105 student scale LMS, this research was interested in the LMS management and teaching experience it would provide. Furthermore, it intended to survey the students' level of participation, and factors that affect students' acceptance of online courses. Three classes in the College of Arts, Sciences and Teacher Education at Philippine Christian University participated in this study. Online activities were given in their subjects "Life and Works of Rizal" and "Economic Philosophers". Findings showed that one teacher can install, manage and teach in an LMS. It was affordable, easy to use, and easy to maintain. Problems can be solved with existing documentation and help from a community of Moodle users around the world. However, teaching online involved additional workload. It was also found that student participants had low participation in the online courses mainly due to lack of computers and internet connection. Furthermore, most students had a negative attitude toward stand-alone online courses because of a perception that it lacks reality. This attitude was found to be associated with ownership of landline telephones. It was conjectured that landline telephones may condition students into accepting virtual reality and thereby accepting online courses. Improvements to the course were proposed to increase participation, and further study on the conjecture regarding telephones, virtual reality and acceptance of online courses. The full text of the paper can be found here: http://tagalog.ws/mod/resource/view.php?id=335 Roel

Forum Post: 
Post title: Using Metacourses for Program Assessment
Post description: We are looking for a tool for program assessment and I am trying to figure out whether metacourses might provide a solution. Programs are interested in identifying courses at the beginning and end of the curriculum to use for assessment. Students in these assessment designated courses will be asked to complete assignments to be assessed by program faculty All students in these courses will complete the assignment A selection of these assignments will be chosen at random for assessment A panel of program faculty will assess these assignments against a standard rubric My thought is to create a metacourse for assessment. For example, if Psychology 101 were designated as an assessment course, we could create a PSYCH101_Assessment metacourse with all the Psych 101 sections as child courses. We could then embed the assessment assignment in the metacourse. The assessing faculty would be the instructors in the metacourse. Is it possible to embed the assessment assignment as an activity in the child courses? This would be ideal so that the students do not need to go to the metacourse to complete the assessment activity. Now to complicate matters a bit, we would like to have this assessment "trickle" up. That is, we would like to use the assignments for assessment at the departmental, college, and university levels. Is it possible to have metacourses where the child courses are, themselves, metacourses (Social_Science_Assessment with PSYCH101_Assessment, SOC101_Assessment, etc., as child courses)? If so, is it possible to have assignments completed in these child courses also available for assessment at the next level up? Thank you in advance for your thoughts.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Lack of computer access
Post description: I'm interested in hearing from folks about any experiences involving lack of computer time during the school day, or lack of computer availability outside of school hours.   Perhaps, suggestions for running your class when the kids may not be able to get online regularly....
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Take a look at this discussion: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=7980
Comment 2: Hi, Amy.  How long have you been a Moodler?  I have wrestled with various levels of computer availability for the past 3 years that I have used Moodle regularly.  I teach in a very small high school in Gary, Indiana.  The poverty level is high and even public access through libraries is irregular.  I firmly believe in giving any access and exposure I can.   The time spent in a Moodle course or any other use of technology  in school is all that some of these kids will have.  I have at times done all of the following to help kids without computers at home and/or internet access: 1) scheduling computer lab time for the really important activities that I wanted the whole class to do by a specific time (like watch a video, answer a choice, forum, etc)  2) making the forum discussion a lesser grade than classroom discussion and combining both for the final grade for a unit, 9 wks, etc.  3) If it's only a few students per class, I have made my computer available for students when they are done with the classwork.  4) I made myself available before and after school so students could access the activities through lab/my room.  5) Provide  many resources and activities for your units of study and require students to do/access/read/participate with X of theml, then they have control over which ones and the student builds his or her own learning.  6) And, this year, I discovered that if a parent knows that internet access/computer access is an issue, they WILL help all they can to get that student to the library, a neighbor, etc.  SO KEEP THEM INFORMED ABOUT YOUR ATTEMPTS TO INTEGRATE TECHNOLOGY. Basically my best advise is, until the playing field is level and all players have equipment, don't base your whole curriculum on the Moodle course you create. Have fun exposing students to what is available.  Perhaps the more they get to do it, the more likely the parents will explore ways to help their kids get the technology. Whew, sorry I was so long-winded.  I hope my ideas help. Charlie Wierzbicki

Forum Post: 
Post title: External resource in pop-up window?
Post description: Is it possible in moodle to make an extenal resource, like a "Web Link", appear in a separate window? Thanks, Lars.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Offhand I didn't see any way to do this. However if it really is not supported, then it should be easy to cook up some hack along the following lines: add some flag to the URL . The hacking code would watch for this flag and then add the appropriate target attribute to that anchor. Zig
Comment 2: I'm relatively new to Moodle and so I haven't had a chance to snoop around as much as I would like but I have solved this issue on a per link basis in the HTML hard code. Basically, I coded the target for each link that I want to set to a new browser as blank ie: <a href="http://www.google.ca" target="_blank">. You either have to: when using the rich text editor, edit the links in the source code write everything up in HTML source in an HTML editor such as Dreamweaver - a good freeware one is http://www.w3.org/Amaya/ (click on this link and you will see the target="_blank" in action!) Note that in order to make the 2nd option easier, I disabled the Richtext HTML editor and just plug code into my windows. I find I have more control over my results this way. Cheers, Kristina
Comment 3: The way I've done this is to put web links in a small and otherwise plain-text page, it works well...like this: http://www.oxilp.ac.uk/ Otherwise, if I want a url behind a piece of text, I code it in html, and tell moodle to use html formatting, as in the example by Kristina above.
Comment 4: Bug added for a resolution Bug #315 - External resource in pop-up window?

Forum Post: 
Post title: "How can computer-marked quizzes help students learn?" Tim Hunt, 15 Novemeber 2023
Post description: How can computer-marked quizzes help students learn? A presentation by Tim Hunt as part of our series of workshop on "All about conducting on-line tests with Moodle" [1], 15 November 2023 (21 min) video1936226816.mp4 Abstract 1. As teachers, we cannot do the student's learning for them. All we can do is to provide scaffolding and feedback to help them. Online quizzes let you do both. 2. I want to talk about the two fundamentally different types of online questions: Selected response questions - like multiple choice - the student need only recognise the right answer in the possibilities given. Constructed response questions - like short-answer or formulas - the student must work out the answer without hints, but are harder to mark. 3. Different ways to use questions, like exams or practice. I think you covered this in a previous session, but I want to say it again. In this section, I will probably demonstrate our embedded question plugins. I will probably also highlight interactive with multiple tries behaviour. 4. Finally, I will talk a bit about academic integrity - which will start to move in the direction of what you will cover. Note that the above home for the video is temporary. Once the work finds a permanent home for the talk, we'll publish the new link here. Irrespective of that you are allowed, and encouraged, to download it and use it respecting the open license below. CC BY Attribute to Tim Hunt and EduNET@LEARN [1] https://edunet.learn.ac.lk/course/view.php?id=19 (Edited by Mary Cooch - original submission Friday, 22 December 2023, 1:20 AM)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi all In case the video is missing, please go to the Moodle Academy webinar . It is a significantly extended version of this talk. In a sense, one can call this thread CLOSED. ;)

Post title: What non-standard modules/plugins/addons are you using?
Post description: Not sure where this questions fits in under forum topics...but here it is: We are presenting a case to our Moodle admins for additional mods, plugins, filters to be added to our standard release.  I was wondering if anyone would have a moment to tell me what add-ons, third-party mods/filters, plugins they are using in their courses and how they are working for them. We're kind of looking for the top ten essential non-standard features, putting together a "wish list" so to speak. We are currently running 1.5.4 and plan to upgrade to 1.6.3 and later 1.7 over the next semester or so. Any advise is greatly appreciated. Thank you. Jean Hardy Instructional Developer Central Piedmont Community College, North Carolina, USA
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Our list of have-to-have-or-die blocks! 1) HSU gradebook enhancements v2 2) HSU course menu block 3) Dmitry's attendance block 4) HSU quickmail block We really want upload and review as an assignment type, but haven't gotten it to work quite yet. Math people need the tex/algebra filters
Comment 2: Thank you A.T.  We are looking to put the upload and review assignment type on a test server . See how it works for us. I'll let you know how it goes, if we decide to use it. Thank you for your response! Jean
Comment 3: The ones I use are 1) Audun Hauge's Course Layout Editor (drag and drop course content deleitng, moving and copying) Super-duper. 2) Brian Koonzt Course Date Manager (change the start / submission dates for a course all at once). Not in block form at the moment. Essential for me. 3) My really simple Redirect Course type . Does not belong in this list, but it is pretty essential for me, to put courses in multiple categories and keep students registered therein. The ones I am considering are 4) Chardelle Busch 's Forum anonymity - to make some forums anonymous 5) Harry Smith 's quiz auto email - to send mail automatically, to one recipient or another, when students get above or below a passmark in a quiz. I don't think that these are openly available so please contact the authors. I have also always been considering the use of ActivityLocking / Conditional Activities which allows you to set some activities as being accessible dependent upon a quiz or lesson (?) grade and John Ryan 's hack to allow completely seperate groups. Timothy
Comment 4: I almost forgot, I am also using TUI module , demoed here http://tuitest.com which is superb, if you are social or cognitive psychologist, and can do similar-ish things to the Harvard Implict Associations Tests (TM). Moodle for Mobiles which makes some Moodle activities available on mobile phones (in CHTML) I helped to fund these so again, I am biased. Timothy
Comment 5: Thanks Timothy. We are looking at the Course Layout Editor and the Course Date Manager. We may go with the HSU version since we've worked with Michael Penny's other mods.  Thank you for the insights, leads, pointers. The Moodle for Mobiles sounds interesting. I'll take a look at it! jean

Forum Post: 
Post title: Aggregate Quiz Grade -> Completion
Post description: I use a single question quiz after each lecture to mark the attendance by giving the student a pin. If I have 30 lectures and require students to attend at least 27 lectures. How can I manage that with course completion?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You could put all those quizzes in a category in the Gradebook. If each quiz is worth 1 mark, then you can do a completion condition of the category total being 27 or more.
Comment 2: Hi Tim, that's the direction I was taking it. The thing I'm not able to figure out is how to set a separate grade category as a completion requirement. I don't want their attendance factored into their course total grade as that's a separate completion requirement.
Comment 3: Create a new category in the Gradebook, add all of your attendance grade items in that category. Exclude the attendance category from the total grade. Kind Regards
Comment 4: Hi Shirley, I have that done already. The part I'm hung up on is how do I get that into the course completion? I'm not seeing a grade for just one category. Course grade shows the entire course.
Comment 5: Sorry, I didn't read well - Items in the Gradebook and Items required for course completion do not have to match. Does your course activity have an Activity completion requirement? If you are just using this to mark attendance and no grade will be assigned, you could remove the course completion requirement for that activity. Or remove the grade for those items in the Gradebook. Kind Regards
Comment 6: Shirley, I have tests that need to be over 80% for completion. I'm using the quizzes as attendance, and I only need 25/28 of them to be complete/passed. However I have no way of implementing both in the course completion requirements.
Comment 7: Hi Tim, how do I set a completion requirement on a grade category?
Comment 8: Hi Drew, You can't directly set a minimum value in a specific grade category as a completion criteria. AFAIK , you can only require a minimum course grade value in Course completion. If these quizzes are the only graded activities in your course, the course grade would naturally reflect the aggregate of these grades. But an 80% average score over all quizzes is not the same as the 80% passing grade of each individual quiz. There may be another approach to this challenge, if you are willing to use the mod_checklist activity module ( https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_checklist ) in your course. With this, set up to record completions of associated activities, you can track the overall 80% completion of the course as well. And since this is a completion criteria in the Checklist activity you'd use, you're also able to have the its completion as a cource completion criteria: the course is completed once the Checklist activity has a grade value of 80% or higher.
Comment 9: Why can't you select any grade item when creating a completion condition? That sounds like a bug (or at least a missing feature) in the completion system to me. Is there a tracker issue for it?
Comment 10: Probably because one could set the course grade to reflect a specific grade item through calculation formulas and nobody gave it much thought after that? The formula would be something like Course grade = {grade item idnumber} Not many teachers or learning designers would dive that deep into the grade book or the completion settings, I guess. And... you'd have to be really sure of what you're doing when setting a course completion criteria like that.
