Post title: Sharing a Tool to Simplify Assignment Grading for Educators
Post description: Hello, My name is Ismael Trascastro, and I'm a Vocational Training teacher specializing in Computer Science in Barcelona (Catalonia, Spain). I wanted to share with you a tool I've developed that might be beneficial to other teachers. This tool was created at the Institut Obert de Catalunya, where I work. It's a spreadsheet that simplifies the grading of assignments by automating evaluation and feedback generation. It also prepares grades for export to Moodle, streamlining the entire grading process. In the shared folder, you'll find not only the spreadsheet but also a PDF manual that guides you through its use. Additionally, I've written an article that explains the tool in detail and where you can free download the spreadsheet: Article : itrascastro.github.io/moodle-offline-task-grading-spreadsheet/ While the tool supports the use of rubrics, their use is optional. You can evaluate with personalized comments, and although it was designed to integrate with Moodle, it can also be used independently. All you need is the list of students in the corresponding tab. If you find it interesting, please feel free to use it or share it with others who might benefit from it. Warm regards, Ismael Trascastro

Post title: [2.4.6] You are currently not being tracked by completion in this course
Post description: I have an old installation with a course with completions enabled that has been studied by many people, so I can't reset completions without it breaking all manner of dependant systems (external to Moodle; web services, etc). So I'm open to hacks or unusual ideas to cause this user to be complete. Completion is set up like this: Overall criteria aggregation method: any Manual completion by: manager Activities completed, aggregation method: all Activities completion, selection: all activities ticked I have a user who has somehow not had completions work, whereas other users have. The learner has done all the graded activities (6 items) and has been scored with passing grades for each. Activities (all are scorm activities) are showing the attempt, and show the user has achieved the passing score (100%), and completion settings are set to complete on minumum score 80% (but no required status). I'm logged on as the site admin and have course manager role. The completion report is showing grey ticks (e.g. not completed). The grader report shows scores of 100 across all activities for the user. If I manually click the Criteria:Approval/Criteria:Manager tick box for that student, moodle throws the undocumented error: You are currently not being tracked by completion in this course
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tim! In Moodle 2.4 there is this bug ( https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-40241 ) that hasn't been corrected yet. You can fix it adding privilege isincompletionreport to the teacher role. Ciao Sara
Comment 2: Great, explains why it doesn't work, also why in testing on my Moodle 2.8 box it also didn't work. I thought it was me. I added the privilege to the manager role and then checked my own permissions to ensure that I had inherited it, and then tried to complete the user manually. It still didn't work. However, enrolling my manager account manually on the course then did the trick - as a member, I'm then able to complete other users. Odd, but it's a workaround, and no crazy hacks! Cheers, Tim

Post title: Does anyone have a Moodle skills self-assessment for Faculty?
Post description: Hello, I am looking for a quiz/survey/self-assessment tool on Moodle skills to help faculty identify the training that will best meet their needs. Comments associated with the post:

Your self assessment should always start with asking a few basic questions, like: what information would I want to collect, and how will I use this to support my faculty. Is this about pedagogy of online and blended teaching, or is this about knowing where to find appropriate tools in your Moodle instance and then how to use them? Also, you may want to consider upgrading your Moodle to a more current version with actual support and bugfixes. 3.9 is the current LTS version with bug and security fixes until well into 2023.

Post title: moodle quiz timer issue: does not pause in event of client failure
Post description: We had scheduled a quiz activity in Moodle. While student were answering quiz suddenly power went off and it was restored after 10 minutes. When all students re-logged in to Moodle to continue their test, their leftover time was reduced by 10 min. Comments associated with the post:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Learn Moodle 3.7 Basics Feedback and Actions
Post description: Our Learn Moodle 3.7 Basics MOOC has recently ended and Helen and I are busy going through the participant feedback to improve the course for its next run, starting on 13 January 2020. Here’s a short overview of how the course went this time: Some
facts and figures: 3425 people started the course and of these 51% were awarded a Learn Moodle 3.7 participant badge for posting in a forum. 25% (845) went on to complete all 32 activities and obtain a certificate of completion and badge. 36% of participants chose to progress through the course one week at a time, while 64% chose to see all the activities at once. 31% of participants used the Moodle app when accessing the course. In the week 4 final feedback, 92% of participants said that their overall impression of the course was good or outstanding. In the week 4 final feedback, 88% of participants said that the tasks in the course were just the right level for them. What we did well: In control of your learning Participants appreciated being able to choose whether to see the materials all at once or have them revealed one week at a time. They also liked seeing the activity completion boxes and later, the course completion status: For me personally, it was a very good option to choose whether to do the course week by week or when ever I want! That's great because then everyone can decide which time is the best to do the course and I think this increases the number of participants.
Moreover, I liked the ticking boxes next to the tasks! It allows a good overview. Alternative options Presenting the videos both online but also for download , along with the transcripts was welcomed particularly by participants with poor internet connections or where YouTube is banned, and is also recommended for accessibility . Everything was explained very clearly and pedagogically. Absolutely loved the fact that information was given in an audio-visual format! That kept me focused in a way reading wouldn't. Forum participation and collaboration Along
with an Introduce yourself! forum, each week had an Any questions? forum where problems were quickly resolved through discussion with other participants, not just the facilitators. Even though I dislike participating in forums, due to my own insecurities, I really enjoyed the forums in this course. The forums and transparency help to give confidence and show that there are others who are just learning as well. Despite the course being aimed at new Moodlers, experienced Moodlers return regularly to help out, in the spirit of Social constructionism upon which Moodle is based: Super content and great participants. I liked having some experienced folks in the class and appreciated their comments in the forums. Five
participants received “Learn Moodle Basics helper” badges for their invaluable support in the MOOC. Thanks to John Bennett for being our “doorman” welcoming every single participant to the course - some feat! Thanks to Hart Wilson and Domenico Recchia for
patiently responding to queries (in several different languages) and thanks to Twahir Hussein Kassim for motivating participants with his infectious enthusiasm. Grateful thanks finally to Michael Milette for enrolling in and highlighting
a large number of practice courses. Other regular MOOC participants are also appreciated and valued - please come again! How we can improve: Supporting learners in other languages The course is in English, but we make it clear people
are welcome to post in their own languages. This seems to work quite well in Spanish but participants speaking other languages sometimes struggle. The videos have English transcripts which are available to download and read but we do rely on volunteers
to translate them into other languages. If you are reading this and you’re a native speaker of a language other than English, please read our page on Translating Moodle video subtitles. Clarifying workshop instructions We’re getting there,
slowly! This time fewer participants were confused about the different phases of the Workshop activity, but some were uncertain whether they had submitted or not and whether they could edit their submission. We’ll make a short screencast to explain what
to expect as a participant. Big Blue Button help The new Big Blue Button HTML5 option allowing participants to join in our live sessions from their mobile devices was very well received. However, some people still struggled with the settings,
especially sound. We’ll include some simple tips for new users to read before they join the sessions so they get a better live experience, and don’t need to rely on watching the recording afterwards. Bug fixes! For us at Moodle HQ, one of
the benefits of running a large-scale MOOC with the latest version of Moodle is that it highlights bugs and improvements that developers can fix. Here are some of the bugs recently reported or confirmed: MDL-66090 - Confusing analytics upcoming activities due notification email MOBILE-3086 - Title on database not linking correctly MDL-64598 - Emojis are very big when emailed MDL-65803 - Invalid record error message from deleted item in recently accessed items block - already fixed in Moodle 3.7.1! MDL-64935 - Jump to button interferes with activity/resource links - already fixed in Moodle 3.7.1! If you missed the MOOC this time or if you didn’t get to complete it, we’ll be opening the Learn Moodle 3.8 Basics course up for sign up during December ready for our January 2020 launch. Keep an eye on our social media accounts for updates.

Post title: Using moodle for software training
Post description: Hello, I am new to using moodle. I have been watching videos on Lynda.com on moodle training. I still have some questions about what im trying to do. I am wanting to build a training site for my software. Basically, I create some training videos that I want the students to watch and to take a small quiz right after. What is the best way to do that? Thanks for any help, Alex
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi there and welcome to Moodle. Moodle is well suited to this sort of thing. The quiz module would probably be best for you - you can insert a video in a quiz question using the text editor (see documentation here http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Video ) and then use the quiz question  types for your questions -if you wish, Moodle can mark them for you too. See http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Quiz_module
Comment 2: Thanks for getting back to me. I will look at the documentation. Thanks very much!
Comment 3: H there, upload yr video to Youtube - make sure to set it as private. Copy the code for embedding youtube from youtube. Goto Moodle and create a new resource --> web page on yr topic/ weekly topics space. In the "Compose a web page" text box, paste the embed youtube code. This will showcase the video inside moodle. Now its done. Add another resource--> quiz and formulate a quiz for your students. Hope that helps.
Comment 4: Thanks, is there another way to do the quiz part? Like, i want them to watch a video and have a button that says, NEXT STEP or something like that. I don't want it to say Take Quiz, because its not really a quiz. It  will be a yes an no question that asks if they have seen the video and thats it.
Comment 5: Try the Lesson module.
Comment 6: Thanks!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Paper Based Templates
Post description: We have a development team, and need to write in the nex 90 days, 144 lessons. We have been developing these lessons right in Moodle, doing quality control and peer to peer eval, right in moodle. We are finding this cumbersome in some ways. So we ahve ben kicking around the idea of creating templates of sorts in a word processor. If you want to add a forum element, then pull out the template for that, fill in the blanks, share it with your team, get their feedback, polish, and then copy and paste (ot from word) into Moodle. Questions: Anybody try this and find out it just stinks? If you have tried it, could we see samples of the templates for the various activities ?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi David, We've tried lots of different approaches, but in the end we settled with using Moodle for the development, and using a wiki to do review. We create a table in the wiki. Each row includes a URL field, and an issue description, and also a resolved/unresolved value. This way there is a direct URL back to the Moodle page where the issue occurs. You could do similar things in a project management application. I would love a way to add review comments to a Moodle interface, as only visible to a teacher or admin permissions level... that would really enhance content development process. I've experimented with custom database fields to that effect, but couldn't get customers to use them. But for now we find that the Web-based environment allows us to work faster, because more than 1 person can work on the course at 1 time, and so it's worth whatever trouble it brings, for that reason. Better than passing a proprietary file format back and forth over email. Best, A
Comment 2: For in-page comments, you could add an extra HTML block, and use permission overrides so that it is only visible to teachers. For managing issues, you could step up from using a wiki to using proper issue tracking software (like http://tracker.moodle.org/ ). Saadly, Jira, which we use there, is not free. The most popular free alternatives are trac and bugzilla.

Forum Post: 
Post title: differentiate Student Learning
Post description: Hi Brains Trust, Although I am not allowed to use Moodle in my current school, this current problem may show then the potential of Moodle. I have a number of students on special Learning Plans and I have been asked how I  differentiate between their learning. How do Moodle teachers cope with this?. Groups? I also like the idea of using H5P so all class members see a very similar environment but then different Groups may see different levels. Your thoughts and experience please.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle allows for accommodations such as altering time on quizzes as well as the ability to show and hide materials to students based on what group they are in. For instance you can have a 30 minute quiz but allow a student with an IEP 1 hour.  In the course you can have 3 assignments which vary in skill level.  Based on what group the student is in can determine which assignment they see. Using the Group Choice Activity you can allow students to join groups based on a test score such as NWEA.  Then each group might have a course topic which is only viewable by members of that group.  In that topic you would have activities designed to increase their skills so that they can move up to a new level. Moodle is awesome at restricting access based on conditions or sets of conditions defined by the teacher at an entire topic or single activity level.
Comment 2: Hi Chris, Thanks for clearing that up. yes always thought Moodle would be good at  streaming (Choice/Group Activity) but still giving the students a challenge to climb. I have always liked Badges so with this set up they could obtain the same Badge, just at a different Level. I believe this is a good thing but it may devalue the Badge within the class, if 2 students on the complete different ends of the spectrum got the same award/badge. Any thoughts on that issue? I have this very class mix and wonder the best way to handle it.
Comment 3: I'm probably the wrong person to ask this question. A child on the low end is not going to devalue the achievement of your badge in the class.  How much harder is it for an autistic kid or someone with dyslexia to overcome and achieve your silly badge than a kid who functions normally? The idea that a low functioning kid would somehow devalue a silly badge that is to show progress and learning is like saying the kid who starts on the 50 yard line should score the same touchdown as the kid who gets the ball at the goal line. The best way to handle this is to make sure each kid is learning and moving closer to the goal. I don't want to sound mean in this post but I am putting on my parent hat.  I see my child in your post on the low end due to no fault of his own.  He was born this way on the low end of the spectrum and while brilliant in many ways he doesn't always learn the same way other kids do. I guess the thought of my son's teacher thinking he shouldn't be rewarded for learning because it would devalue the badge for the other kids makes my blood boil.
Comment 4: It may have sounded wrong but you have absolutely the wrong end of the stick. I want to bring in Moodle and visual learning to all my students to make it a level playing field. Simple
Comment 5: Good to know John.  Sometimes a forum doesn't convey the meaning behind the words or intent of the writer.  Glad it was my misunderstanding. As I am sure you are aware there are kids who will need accomodations.  Those accommodations provide a level playing field for a wide range of learning needs.  It in no way diminishes the value of your badge. If you mean that every kid should learn the same way and complete the same tasks in order to be a level playing field then I guess we can just agree to disagree. All the best.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How long are my students spending on Moodle?
Post description: I have a corporate client who'd like to get an average amount of time their staff spend on my Moodle courses per month. Does anyone have any suggestions? Is there a plugin which already does this? (The Moodle I'm using is 2.4)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Andrew, This is quite tricky.  The problem is that time on the page doesn't equal time working. You could use a plugin called configurable reports to pull up a time online report, but I'm not sure how valuable that is.  What might be more useful is the Progress Bar - that shows activity completion for each participant and is also good for the learners to give themselves some orientation. Possibly using a combination of the two would give you some useful insight. All the best Andy
Comment 2: Many thanks Andy - configurable reports looks like a good approximation to what my customer wants. Andrew

Forum Post: 
Post title: Gamification: Weekly Team Scorecards!?
Post description: One of the most "on fire" gamifiers at my institution has been motivating students by turning his psychology class into a team-based game. He's finding that students work well for rewards, for each other (as members of "The Team"), and also enjoy their intellectual growth. BUT: He's been doing generating the team scorecards manually for each of his 10 class teams, each of which receives a score for "accomplishments" and "attributes." Accomplishments include winning the (Moodle-integrated) TurningPoint clicker quiz (scores stored in the Gradebook), having the best class attendance (stored in the Gradebook). Attitudes include mindset, grit, knowledge (e.g., each team's Gradebook test scores are summed and added to this figure). WANTED: Moodle-automated score keeping for such team-based gamification. We'd REALLY, really , Really like to see weekly scorecards automatically populated with up-to-date team scores. Much of the required data is in the gradebook. But I am not sure on a conceptual level how to use the data to auto-generate weekly team scorecards. The gradebook does not, by itself, seem like a good tool for aggregating such group scores. Does it? Nor do I know how to build this on a technological level . Hence, I turn to you, Oh Wise Moodle Community, both because of your knowledge and because of your celebration of progressive pedagogy. I look forward to hearing feedback! Sincerely,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have spent a lot of time in the Moodle Gradebook  trying to coerce it into a gamification platform. I can offer a few tips: Use the configurable reports plugin to generate a leaderboard based on criteria Use custom scales (regular intervals) and letters (irregular intervals) Use weighting to convert scores Use exponential scores in the gradebook to level up  Level 1: 40 level 2: 80 Level 3: 160  level 4: 320 level 5: 640 TOTAL: 1240 Use a wiki and allow participants to rate each other  on specific aspects- scores go in the gradebook Use the assignment module with group submission Use subcategories within the gradebook to aggregate results for each level - this forces scores to stay within the current level I teach a few days a week and do Moodle admin/consultancy the other days so I have real students to test out my ideas on. The time involved in keeping scores is laborious and as much as a simple spreadsheet can do it, I am in search of making Moodle do this for me. Wherever I can get students to enter their own scores, or peer assess saves me entering and aggregating the results. The release of Outcome sets in 2.8 (hopefully) will allow us more flexibility in matching activities to outcomes and grades. More tips on plugins are in this guide: http://seoul.directrouter.com/~movies/index.php/downloads/item/196-moodle-for-motivation-tool-guide
Comment 2: Natalie, thank you so much! I am forwarding your snazzy guide to some colleagues, and we will pore over your suggestions here. It sounds like implementation of the functionality still requires a fair bit of technical know-how, plus significant imagination, as well. If we advance significantly on either, we'll report back.
Comment 3: There is an awesome spreadsheet leaderboard script which could be embedded in a Moodle Page - but I am intent on forcing Moodle to bend - It will take imagination and time. Have you seen the new Xp points plugin (for Moodle 2.7) https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=58? It's good to connect with other's going down this road and share our breakthroughs. I have been talking  to Giridharan Dhanashaker, another Moodle Site Developer who has put alot of time and money into their design which they presented at the recent iMoot.
Comment 4: Natalie, you are a well of gamification wealth! I am passing your links and tool-tutorials on to others, and allowing them to tutor my own imagination. Thank you, thank you, thank you!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Setup
Post description: Hi all, I have a general question about Moodle and have searched around and not found much on this. We are still in the initial phases of deciding on a content management system. Here is out proposed setup: We have 5-6 teachers each with 15 or so students in their class. The classes are English 101, English 102, Science 101, and so on. What we'd like to do: Create classes/courses on Moodle so that each class has one teacher and only the students in the class can view the content. Teachers can post messages to students in that class. Students will be in multiple classes and should be able to see English 101 and Science 101. This student not being in English 102 should not be able to see any of the content in it or see messages about it.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Definitely!  This is what Moodle is designed to do.  Create a collaborative community for teachers and students.  Students enrolled in multiple courses can participate independently in each of those courses, yet their individual calendar will show events from all courses in which they participate.  For what you are looking for Moodle is the best thing out there!
Comment 2: How do you create a collaborative community?
Comment 3: What you describe Steve is how Moodle generally operates. I'm not sure what you mean by collaborative community, you might try being more specific as to who you want to collaborate and what they are working on and then post that to teaching strategies. We tend to deal with those issues there, as they are not related to basic Moodle set up as much as to how it is used and what functionality you make available to whom.

Post title: Online Teaching using Moodle
Post description: Hi - I am looking at a Open source LMS/LCMS focussed on academic front to conduct online classroom for my distant students in a syncronous way. Also audio/video features if possible while teaching the students. I visited the following websites Docebo, OLAT, efront and Claroline to get a feel of it. I saw few which are licensed or comes with a subscription charges.. At this moment i am not looking to go with a priced Product. The closest which my requirement fits is wiziq.com. wiziq is not an opensource product. Can Moodle be used in the same way like wiziq. Appreciate if any experts can narrow my searches. Thx in advance
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I can't comment on what wiziq do or offer that you like. I can however suggest that you look carefully at what they offer - the site is full of copied material, some copied from other websites, some blatantly copied from books (for example look at http://www.wiziq.com/tutorial/114892-Elem-Unit-1-WB ) which is a photocopy of a Headway English book, purporting to be an 'educational tutorial'. Looks like just another scammer website to me. What is it, 'like wiziq', you want to do with moodle?
Comment 2: Guys, I am from WiZiQ. Brian, WiZiQ is a user-generated content site, where members upload tutorials like the one you referred to. The content section works very similar to video sharing sites like YouTube, or document sharing sites like Scribd. As you can see, this one has been uploaded by a highly recommended teacher with valid credentials. You can easily attend his synchronous classes and interact with him. So I am sure you would agree that WiZiQ has a transparent system. If you believe that any content on WiZiQ infringes your copyrights, you can simply report to us, using the "Flag" button on top of the content player, with proof, on support@wiziq.com, and the needful shall be done. Dear Arun, Thanks for your interest in WiZiQ. Our engine is not open-source, and although WiZiQ is very different from Moodle, we might well meet your requirements. As an individual teacher, you can explore the "Plans for Individuals" tab on our Premium Services page. If you run an organization, the "Plans for Organizations" tab has detailed information. You are very welcome to contact us here or call us on +919216494947 for any queries about our Premium services. We are based in Mohali, India. Alternatively, if you want to use our Virtual Classroom with Moodle, you can download the module here . After a month's trial, you can choose from a plan that suits your requirements. Best, Jagdeep Singh Pannu @WiZiQ
Comment 3: Thx Mr. Jagdip for your response. I am still evaluating various product to narrow my requirement. I am inclined to opensource at this point which can deliver predominantly syncronous online classes thru remote. Sure, i will reach out to you. Thx Arun
Comment 4: I've used this site (wiziq) once and found it good as one can find great value content here.
Comment 5: My agency uses Moodle for on-line, asynchronous training and registration for classroom training.  For synchronous on-line, web meetings, etc we use WiZiQ.  Previously we used DimDim (DON'T recommend, not even available any longer). So far, we like WiZiQ a lot and appreciate the Moodle plug-in, which allows instructors to set up the link to the virtual classroom in the moodle course.  It is very inexpensive, especially compared to other options (Connect, WebEx, etc).  Tech support has been very quick to respond and resolve any issues we've had, which really isn't very many, and to answer questions. I can't say much about their LMS service, as clearly, I don't use them...but the virtual classroom is very easy to use and those who have used it in my agency love it...they walk in making cranky noises about webinars, etc and walk away making happy noise.  I count that as success.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Importing content from an externa source?
Post description: Is it possible through a built-in tool, plugin, or some hack to populate my course TOPICS and ACTIVITIES via an external source, such as a CSV? I'm finding that creating a dummy course set up like I want all my courses, then IMPORTING it to another course, then deleting out what I don't want to be a time-ineffective method. It takes days. I've used other systems that have csv/excel importers that build course content including activities that automate the building of many complex courses. It's particularly slow to have to edit every single topic to have the same set of activities, completion rules, and conditional release rules, and custom pages, etc. google hasn't brought up anything for me yet, I'm hoping someone might know of a good way to build courses using some kind of automation or external process.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hear, Hear! Batch update from a flatfile is much easier for the user to manipulate. However -- from my own programming experience -- a batch update is much harder for a programmer to implement, particularly if there are as many variables as there are in a course record.   A user record is easy, with only a dozen fields to evaluate.

Forum Post: 
Post title: MS Word force download - how to remove?
Post description: Hi there, I have some downloadable MS Word files in my course. The default setting is a force download that I cannot override. I want my students to be able to see the file before downloading it. What can I do in this situation? Thank you! Nataliya.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Nataliya, Moodle itself does not support viewing files in browser for any up to date productivity suite (MS Office, Office 365, Libre Office, Open Office or similar). There is no plugin available to do that just out of the box, although it may be possible to display .docx files as such with the oEmbed filter turned on and the full Office 365 integration set up. This is, however, something that involves a lot of work from system admins for both Moodle and an Azure infrastructure if you happen to have one. Saving the Word documents as PDF should work in any modern browser, though.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Course that consists of various sections of other courses
Post description: Hi, I would like to create a new "course" that consists of selected topics from existing courses. In fact, all I need is a "List" that guides students through the selected elements and activities (mostly books and quizzes) they have to complete, ideally with progress monitoring. Is there a way to do this elegantly? Thanks! Urs
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Urs, you could set up a course with activities as a 'master' course and publish all of the activities as LTI tools. https://docs.moodle.org/33/en/Publish_as_LTI_tool Then in your 'consumer' courses, just add them in. You should then be able to modify the 'provider' activities and they will update in each instance that you are using them as 'consumer' activities. There may be a better way, but the way I am suggesting would work and be fairly flexible. Good luck!
Comment 2: Hi Bruce, Thanks a lot for your help and support. That was VERY useful! Best, Urs

Forum Post: 
Post title: Designing a course that gives two pathways
Post description: I am currently working on a course which starts with information for everyone and then at a decision point I want to be able to have students take a pathway for elementary teachers and a different pathway for secondary teachers.  The main content difference will be the examples presented.  How can I do this in one Moodle course?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you are able to install plugins then the Group choice plugin is a good way to do this. Students make a choice and are put into a group and then you use Restrict access conditions to display materials for each group so a student only sees the group of their choice. The Learn Moodle 3.7 Basics MOOC running at the moment does this.
Comment 2: Thank you Mary. When I first looked at choice in the Learn Moodle it seemed there was this option. Now it does not seem to be there.
Comment 3: The option to Choose how to progress through the course is still there on the top section of the Learn Moodle 3.7 MOOC Linda.
Comment 4: I see that Mary, and I was referring to the group choice option to use in the design of the practice course, where I am trying to give two pathways for the participants.
Comment 5: Hiya Linda, Something else to consider is the 'Branching Scenario' content that is accessible through the H5P plug-in: https://h5p.org/branching-scenario Thanks, Nige.
Comment 6: Thank you Otaku, I will look into this option.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Sharing completion status of activities between courses
Post description: Hello, I would like to create 2 courses where there are a couple of activities that are common in both courses.  Since the courses are independent of each other but could also be taken by the same person I want to indicate that the activity has been completed in one course if the student enrolls in both. In other words: Course 1, Activity A is completed by the student and when Course 2, Activity A (same as Course 1, Activity A) it already shows completed status. Would badges or competencies be best for this? This is the case where you have multiple corporate trainings where the review of an external document is necessary.  You only need to indicate that the student has clicked on the link but you want to be able to mark as completed between courses. Thank you!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If I understand the scenario you describe, you may want to look at setting up a metacourse where you would display and access your external documents which are required (common) to different (child) courses. I currently use a metacourse in my context to allow students in several child courses to work collaboratively on training related projects and activities. I also use the metacourse as a help desk and student café for site wide discussions and support. Certainly, badges can be issued in this scenario to motivate students to complete activities.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Deferred feedback behaviour ?error
Post description: Ca 10 years ago, I constructed quizzes for the course, including a number of Cloze multichoice questions. Each quiz is designed to be finished before submitting, marked and returned with feedback. I recently moved from Moodle 2.4 to 3.6.  A student has raised a problem which I think is new. The Cloze question is "Choose the appropriate state for the material applied. sand in sand blasting {1:MULTICHOICE:%100%solid#sand is used as a solid~%-100%liquid~%-100%gas} solution of ammonia gas {1:MULTICHOICE:%-100%solid~%100%liquid~%-100%gas#the ammonia gas is dissolved in water, which is a liquid} " + 5 more multichoices. The new (?) error is that a wrong answer not only gets scored 0 but has a penalty of -1. On previewing the question in editing mode, the technical information informs me that the behaviour used is deferred feedback, which results in this behaviour.  There seems to be no way to change the "behaviour" of this question within the question editing screen. If I alter the behaviour in the quiz settings to adaptive mode (no penalties), it has no effect on the behaviour of this question. So- How can I achieve my requirements of Submit all> mark & feedback, plus have no penalty applied? Thank you
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Allowing multiple choice questions with a single right answer to support negative scoring was a very strongly requested feature. If my memory is right, this was done in Moodle 2.1, as part of MDL-20636 (and issue number I can still type from memory 10 years later, I spent so much time working on it.) Anyway, what you are seeing is the expected behaviour, I think (although I don't recall anyone specifically asking about this in the context of Cloze before).
Comment 2: Thank you (I think) I created many of these questions in ca Moodle 1.9.8, presumably before the negative scoring was instituted. My course was updated to 2.4.1 in 2013 (when presumably the new rule was applied to my existing MCQ ) but no-one has reported this error until now. This is not the first time that an existing syntax and output has been modified, so affecting my existing questions and their underlying purpose, without any effective warning or workaround. It would be sensible if a new feature was given a new name and process, so the existing feature in existing courses are not modified. Version control in any programme of work is necessary to avoid glitches such as these. I can see the potential need to support negative scoring of answers, but that is only one of many didactic tactics. As its implementation is so deep in your soul, did you provide a switch so it can also not support negative scoring? It seems as though the deferred feedback facility has got mixed up and confused with negative scoring so I may need a way to separate them. Can you suggest a way forward?
Comment 3: I am sorry, this changed 9 years ago. In line with what you say, we are not going to change this now. If you have a lot of questions that now need to be updated, you can probably fix them in bulk in the database - if you are familiar with with updating data in databases. (Although the fact that these are Cloze questions makes it a bit trickeri.)

Forum Post: 
Post title: 1200 year old Moodle
Post description: Okay, this is my entry for the "Most bizarre use of Moodle" competition.  In 2003, during work at the Cathedral I attend, ( http://www.lichfield-cathedral.org/ , if anyone wants to take a look at it) they discovered part of a stone carving dating from about 800AD buried under the floor.  They appointed a Project Co-ordinator to head up the research and analysis of it, and as the various people involved in the project were spread across the UK but needed to share information and discuss the ongoing work they wanted to pool everything on a website.  It needed to be easy to use, offer secure logons (they wanted to keep some of the stuff away from public eyes until they were ready to publish it), and enable the sharing of files, pictures, etc. As I was already involved in getting an intranet up and running for the Cathedral staff they asked me to look at this, and as I'd been setting up Moodles for the College where I work Moodle seemed like the ideal tool for the job, as it seemed to do everything they wanted and is dead easy to use.  We bought some webspace and a domain name, I installed Moodle on it and set it up, and off they went. Once the research was done and they were ready to go public with their findings they took any remaining sensitive material off the site and asked me to make the remainder publicly accessible.  The Project Co-ordinator tells me that Moodle was a great help in the project, so if anyone wants to see how Moodle helped to uncover the secrets of an object which is well over a thousand years old have a look at http://www.lichfield-angel.net/

Forum Post: 
Post title: Learn Moodle 3.6 Basics: Feedback and actions
Post description: Sunday 3 February was the last day of our latest Learn Moodle Basics MOOC. From this week the course is in read-only mode (using the new Context freezing feature!), and Helen and I are busy preparing for the next run, Learn Moodle 3.7 Basics, starting 10 June 2019. Here’s a short overview of how the MOOC went: Some facts and figures: 3005 people started the course and of these 46% were awarded a Learn Moodle 3.6 participant badge for posting in a forum. 21% (624) went on to complete all 33 activities and obtain a certificate of completion and badge. 32% of participants chose to progress through the course one week at a time, while 68% chose to see all the activities at once. In the week 4 final feedback, 93% of participants said that their overall impression of the course was good or outstanding. In the week 4 final feedback, 86% of participants said that the tasks in the course were just the right level for them. What we did well: Course design The course design was well received, both the short videos and explanations and the social constructionist element. Here’s a summary from one participant in our anonymous feedback: Following are the things which I liked in your course so I am writing this. These were implemented at different points (before, during and at the end of the course): 1. flow and the way you have designed the course which gives scope for both novices and advanced user of moodle to learn many things. 2. learning activities eg course creation which applies the principles of active learning and utilizes the power of peer learning. 3. collaboration and evaluation of content by the participants across the globe. 4. reflection on how the course meets our learning preferences. Thanks for the well-designed course. I hope to learn more from the future course. MOOC management One of the MOOC’s strengths is in its diversity, again something mentioned in our anonymous feedback: Given the large number of participants with different languages, skills, backgrounds and knowledge of Moodle, I think the course went very well indeed. Great support from the tutors and others online. It is always a challenge looking after so many people, but we are grateful to our regular attendees, experienced Moodlers who like to help out. Along with the Participant and Completer badges, we award a “Helper” badge to those participants
we feel have done a great job helping us. This badge is only awarded to a handful of Moodlers. The Learn Moodle 3.6 Basics Helpers are below: many thanks to them all! John Bennett Gisele Croce Joost Elshoff Varenne Riocha Alejandro Vásquez Hart Wilson How we can improve: Clarify the workshop times and instructions Although we try each time to make the deadlines and instructions clearer, participants still get confused. Confusion arises because the activity is not marked complete until the very end of all stages of the Workshop, and there is confusion
amongst some about the final deadline time. We do encourage participants to make sure their timezone is correctly set in their profile, but we plan also to include times as well as dates for the workshop submission and assessment deadlines. We're also changing the instructions for submission from 'Add a picture...' to 'Attach an image...' and setting the maximum number of submission attachments to 1. Notify participants via email about their certificate In future, once participants complete the course, they will be emailed their certificate. This should help people who have struggled to understand the instructions for locating and downloading the certificate on the course page. Make more of Moodle’s new features While the MOOC is designed for complete beginners, people also join to discover the new features of each new version. We’re going to try to highlight these better in the next MOOC, for example with new quiz questions or activities or a dedicated
summary page, to ensure there is something for everyone, new or experienced. Bug fixes! Participants are great at finding the occasional bug in in the web version or the Moodle app. We make sure these bugs are reported so they can be fixed not only for our next MOOC but for all Moodle users. Here are some of the bugs recently reported
or confirmed: CONTRIB-7589 - BBB session times different on timeline from in the course MDL-64571 - Duplicate 'This is a copy of a message sent to you...' in message notification emails MOBILE-2876 - Error in the Moodle app when assessing workshop submissions MDL-64625 Odd display of Book TOC in MS Edge/ IE https://github.com/markn86/moodle-mod_customcert/issues/266 Custom certificate should state the number of certificates awarded In April, we’ll be opening up the site for sign up to the Learn Moodle 3.7 Basics MOOC . Follow us on social media for news of when sign-up will be open!

Forum Post: 
Post title: How can students check which group they're in?
Post description: Hi all, How can students check which group(s) they're in? I'm speaking of groups created by the teacher, not by student's choice. I have no clue what version of Moodle I'm in as I'm a teacher, not an admin. Thanks for your help! Matteo
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: By default, this is visible in the student course-level profile (found under the list of courses they are enrolled in). A student would go to the course participants page, click their name, then scroll to the bottom of their course profile page (alternately, they can go to their site-level profile, then select a course from the list, and that will also bring them to their course-level profile). This ability to see the groups listed here "can" be turned off by admin so only staff can see it, so you'll want to check with your admin on that to see if it's on or off.

Post description: Hi All I have a BTEC engineering department who will be subject to an External verifier, in the last visit the lecturers produced reams of paper for the verification which is costly and time consuming. As many of the assignment s are quiz based that although can give just answers there is an extensive section dedicated to how answers are arrived at - as well as normal uploading of student prepared presentations with notes this will be a huge task. Comment 2: Many thanks for reply and this seems something that we will do going forward

Forum Post: 
Post title: One course (many topics) vs many courses...
Post description: Hi all, I've recently started playing with Moodle (there's been many trials already!) and had a quick question. Background: I teach IB Chemistry which is a 2 year course with 11 standard level topics, 10 higher level topics and a choice of 1 out of 4 option topic (with standard level and higher level aspects). Each of those topics has a number of sub-topics. Some students are SL while others are SL+HL. Question: Would it be better to have 1 course, with all the topics (I was thinking about the collapsed topic plugin or grid plugin) OR to have each topic as a course and break down the sub-topics as topics? Pros and cons that I can see immediately: 1 course: All grading available in one area, but huuugggeee! Plus I will be rolling this out slowly (roughly each topic just before it's started in class). Not sure about hiding HL content from SL students - or whether I'd want to (let them explore further if they're interested in the subject) Many courses: Can keep courses hidden while work in progress. Grading (and other information from plugins) cannot be easily carried between courses? Can restrict access to HL courses (to avoid information overload / confusion... sometimes the HL have a different method due to exceptions that get introduced!) Any thoughts on this? How would you set it up? Thanks Michael
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Michael, My gut feeling is to create small courses based on topic.  However I would look at linking them using a metacourse. https://docs.moodle.org/33/en/Course_meta_link Hope this is some help, Dave
Comment 2: Hi Michael Would it be possible to do 2 courses, one for standard level and one for high? Do you run on semesters or have breaks where it may make sense to chop the course into smaller chunks based on timing?
Comment 3: What is the trigger that would put a student in standard or higher level topics or is it fluid and they move between the two? You can show/hide topics based on group enrollment and have everything in one course. For the 1 out of 4 optional topic you can use the group choice activity which would allow the student to pick a new group which would then in turn reveal the optional topic of their choice. Just some initial thoughts.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Connecting two courses
Post description: Dear Co-moodlers, I am a moodle-newbie and already my first job posses a challenge I am (and possibly moodle is) not prepared to tackle. I want to setup two mostly independent courses on the same (urban issues) topic taking place in two different cities. The students of these classes, however, will be meeting each other in either of the cities on two occasion. At one point both classes will be taught together in city A, while at another point both classes will taught together in city B. For these occasions students need communicate with each other and organize in groups across course-boundaries. Is there a way I can somehow "temporarily connect" the two course schedules and the communication and group functions of the otherwise separate classes? If not, then how would you approach this problem? Thank you very much for your suggestions! Cordially, KB
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You could create one course and in that course you create two groups (in your case two cities). That will give you the opportunity to either separate the two groups (cities) or let them cooperate in the course. read more about groups https://docs.moodle.org/29/en/Groups and groupings https://docs.moodle.org/29/en/Groupings
Comment 2: Okay, thanks for the advice. I will try this tomorrow. Cordially, KB

Post title: How do YOU organize quiz question banks
Post description: I am looking for other educators' experience with organizing question banks and tying the questions to learning objectives.  At the administration level across multiple course, how do YOU keep track of questions that are used across several courses? We started our Moodle journey with each educator working in a vacuum, developing their own banks without a "big picture" long-term plan for organizing and tracking.  Questions items are typically broken down into categories based on the assessment (Quiz 1, Test 2, etc.).  I would like to go through the banks and categorize each item with their accompanying learning objective.  Looking for advice, thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Paul As a faculty member, I usually create categories for each unit or chapter. Many times I will export the banks from the publisher and import them into the LMS. The use of Tags also helps to organize and filter the questions. I don't think our site admin does anything with the question banks.
Comment 2: We do more or less like that, too. We generally organize the question bank around the main units to teach. Then we write some questions at level easy, then medium, then advanced. Then each teacher is free to create quizzes as needed, mixing levels or units or both, or asks the Moodle Admin (me) to cook some quizzes for them. I recommend the competency framework too.
Comment 3: For me, this is a moving target. See Fixing the question bank in Moodle 4.0 - what we are planning . The current way of sharing with the other teachers is called https://docs.moodle.org/en/Question_sharer . We tried it, never took off.
Comment 4: Yes, this is changing, but only half of the relevant changes got into Moodle 4.0, there is more still to come in 4.1 later this year. So, as Visvanath says, it is a moving target. It would still be interesting to hear how people do things using the tools in 3.x

Post title: Research proposal for using Moodle with adults
Post description: Can anyone assist? As part of my M.Ed. coursework studies I am required to submit a research proposal. I am a mature teacher of migrant adults and am enjoying the benefits of Moodle in my classroom. However I find I face many challenges, particularly when obliged to use courses written by others. I have access to the staff and students of two colleges. So this seemed to be a good subject area for a small scale research proposal. Is there a research gap you can identify? What literature (particularly seminal) might you point me towards? David
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Um ... do you think I should have posted this in another part of the Forum? David
Comment 2: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comment 3: Thanks, Alan, for your suggestions.
Comment 4: Hi David I wonder if the issue is about ownership of teaching material/strategies as well as the pressures of learning new technologies? I teach adults literacy and numeracy, and have found moodle most effective when I can make a page my own for a particular group of students. This is especially so as when I use courses over again, I adapt and improve them based on students' responses and on my new learning. I rarely like using other people's materials or ideas without at least some adaptation - whether they are IT based or not. Also -do you think we all reach a point where we've had enough learning - it's just one thing too much. Or we're not motivated because we can't see the benefit (there's a lot of IT for IT's-sake). I can't be doing with programming the video... I'm sure I could learn, but I'm more interested in other technologies than spending time learning how to use that. Interested in what you find out! Lucy

Forum Post: 
Post title: Login to a moodle installation with credentials from a different server
Post description: Hello, I'm brand new to Moodle and I have a very specific question and hopefully someone here has had to deal with something similar before. Our organization has signed a cooperation agreement with a foreign university. Unfortunately we use Canvas and they use Moodle. We want to keep control of our lessons and material, and making sure our course is not replicated without our consent in any way. I'm making myself familiar with Moodle and I don't foresee any problems in the near future getting acquainted with it. My question is: Is there a way to have our course running on our own Moodle installation (our server ) while the foreign university enrolls the students, gives them access to their Moodle server, and then the students use those credentials to access our course without the university being able to have any control over it? The course would never be installed in the university's servers, just ours. Any advice or suggestions will be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Luis, I guess the best way to connect a course from another LMS, or between LMS instances, would be to use Learning Tool Interoperability ( LTI ). As you're using Canvas, you're probably aware of this: Canvas uses LTI a lot to incorporate functionality from other learning tools. How to use this, can be found here: https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/LTI_and_Moodle

Post title: Live classes in mobile app
Post description: Hi, is there a way to facilitate live classes in the moodle mobile app using zoom for example? I know about the zoom plug in but I'm trying to find out how well it works with the mobile app. Does anyone have any experience with this? Any help is much appreciated. Thanks, Andreas
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In order to use the Moodle plugin for Zoom, you need to have purchased a paid Zoom account, or have a verified Credit card on file.  This will enable the API integration. As for live classes, we use Zoom regularly.  One can place the link for the Zoom room on your Moodle site in a label.  When the student opens the mobile app, and clicks on the link, it will ask to open Zoom.  ( I recommend installing the Zoom app first).  The instructor is normally on a computer where if need be they can share their desktop with the class, and yes Moodle can be shared this way.  The preferred way  for students to join is on a computer, but we have students joining by phones and tablets as well. We also use BigBlueButton, but because of BBB dependence on Java and Flash, it impractical for most mobile devices.
Comment 2: Sir, Moodle is the best way for e-learning as accepted world wide.But,do we get the type of feeling as we experience in classroom.According to my views such type of live learning must be used in cases where we are in leave or out for work. Thankyou, Regards, Anish.

Post description: I want to create a single task in Moodle where students can choose between typing their answers or drawing them freely (e.g., using a tablet and stylus). Ideally, the task should combine both input formats—text entry (like the Essay question type) and freehand drawing (using a plugin like Freehand Drawing). Forum Post: 
Post title: Activity Completion in Forums
Post description: I want to set the Activity Completion settings in a simple discussion forum I'm setting up. I'm a little confused by the choices (see below) What's the difference between these options? What is the difference beween the first choice (Posting discussions or replies) and the next two (create discussions, post replies). It seems redundant. Can some one help me? Thanks, Peter Require posts Student must post discussions or replies: Require discussions Student must create discussions: Require replies Student must post replies:
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 1) Student must post discussions or replies means: a student must either start a topic or reply to somebody else's . 2) Student must create discussions - means a student must start a discussion topic themselves 3) Student must post replies means - a student only needs to reply to a discussion someone else has started. So (1) is an either/or whereas for (2) and (3) they do one specific action chosen by you.
Comment 2: Thanks!  so in other words - If I want the students to both post/start a topic AND reply, I should have all 3 checked off, right?  Or is it enough to check off (2) and (3)?
Comment 3: I would do 2 and 3 - making sure it is a forum type where they can start a discussion of course.
Comment 4: Right.  Thanks so much for your help!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Model for consructivist learning design
Post description: Hiya I've been designing a course and trying to apply a structure. I've found that Gagnon/Collay's Constructivist Learning Design offers a particularly useful model which can be adopted easily to Moodle, any other VLE or face to face teaching. It has 6 stages, but I suggest it's worth adding a 7th between 4 and 5, which you could call Construct - construct an artefact (as in constructionism ) to be exhibited, as well as constructing knowledge. Anyone used this? Anyone got anything similar as a model. Cheers Andy D
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thanks Andy, for the link to an interesting site.  I've only skim read it so can't claim to be able to do proper justice to it but having just read (also skim) Kolb on the experiential learning cycle http://www.businessballs.com/kolblearningstyles.htm amongst other links, there seems IMVHO to be a difference that might be worth considering in that G & C's modeI seems more linear, whereas with Kolb's cycle you can enter the learning process at any point, and this might cater more for a variety of learning styles?? Having said this I'm really impressed by your course design aim, Andy, as I'm much better at talking about it than actually doing it! Dick C
Comment 2: Thanks for the link. I guess I was drawn to the linearity of the G & C model as it seemed to offer a introduction through to closure, and lend itself to a series of cycles. However, rather than necessarily entering at different points, I can see benefit in encouraging learners to spend differering amounts of time on different stages, appropriate to their experience -some are showing signs of that by focussing on the 'bridging' content, others marching towards the building stage. I don't pretend I usually think about all these steps - but it's good to try. Andy D
Comment 3: Andy, You didn't mention what would be on- and what would be off-line.  Were you thinking that the 'construction' phase would be classroom-based?  I am interested in ways of supporting online reflection of offline concrete experiences when there is a real reason to do so.  That reason might be that small groups who have been working separately come together to share their experiences and broaden their learning, often in the telling as well as the listening. I have used Kolb's cycle to analyse such a situation, and it helped to show up the different contributions that students could make based in part on their experiences outside the classroom. Frances
Comment 4: Hi Frances The construction phase in my current project is off-line as in not in moodle (the students are actually constructing databases using MS access), but this does result in an artefact (a file) which can be uploaded to a forum, for disucssion and useful feedback/criticism, in the exhibition. Since I am actually supporting my students face to face, the other phases are a mix of oral and online activity. For instance, questioning is a mixture of oral, with a forum as a backup; the exhibition is through a forum but supported by oral discussion, partly to encourage them to record their feedback to each other in a systematic way that can be used to improve their performance. Andy D
Comment 5: Hi, In Learning Design there's a lot of research in pedagogic patterns (1. Patterns and Reuse). There's quite a lot to digest in this field so Moodle collaborative efforts exploring it would certainly be feasible. Cheers, Anders

Post title: drag and drop question taking up a lot of time to drag
Post description: I ran a quiz with a drag and drop question with about 40 answer boxes. Some of the students (using chrome) complained it took too much time to drag each box. And some had chrome crash. Is there a way to avoid this problem?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Joe, Sounds like a bit of a performance issue, but can't be sure with the very limited information you've shared. Could you share the following: Moodle version Question type used (drag-drop text, drag-drop image, ...) If an error message was displayed, which one? On the learning design side of things: I'd recommend having a good look at building a question with 40 (!!) answer boxes in the first place. Unless you wanted to create a jigsaw type of question, 40 distractors and landing spots sounds like too much to me. In those cases it may be better to break the question down into various ones, so your learners have an optimized learning experience.

Post title: Grade participation
Post description: Hello, I wonder if anybody has found a good way to grade participation automatically. For instance, is there a way to attribute a grade to a feedback activity? We are creating a course where any activity generates a grade. This can be a participation grade (100% if completed). Thank you very much for any answer! Ulrike
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ulrike! I don't know about grading activities , but perhaps you could use 'completion tracking'? With completion tracking, you can set specific criteria for any activity to be marked as 'complete' - from something as simple as opening a document, to making a specified number of posts or replies in a forum, to completing a feedback activity. Here's a link to our University guide on completion tracking, in case it is any help: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1S_2JKhndbAVtagV766TrCFPvoYz-kgoQ/view?usp=sharing Cheers!

Post title: I'd like to tidy my Moodle Page
Post description: Hi All, I run a BA Course Moodle Page. My students tell me that they find Moodle hard to use because the Access Page has too much information to sift through to find the relevant sections . I sympathise. I'd like to simplify the presentation by using links from one file to another. For example: A statement might suggest that students read a module descriptor before starting a module. I'd like to make the words "module descriptor" link to the relevant files. ( I suppose I could tweak the Glossary to do this). Other links could include a Quiz or Tool list and so on. I suppose my question is: Is there a way to Hyperlink in Moodle...and can it be used in imported texts? PS I see from this form that there is a chain logo for a link button. Perhaps I should click that and see what happens!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi there. Absolutely you can link to uploaded texts. If you type some text and then highlight it and then click the link/chain icon, you have the  option of going to the repositories and uploading a file directly to that link and that text box. Quite how you do it depends on the version of Moodle you are using.
Comment 2: This sounds as if it could cure a head ache for me.  I have a description that is to be posted into several locations.  I have tried this in other locations but students don't seem to see it unless it is there when they open the assignment.  Not only do I have to go to each location to place it but I also have to go to all those same locations to modify it. In your fix, how easy is it to replace/update the text in the file that is called by the URL ?  I presume that if I keep the same name of the file then I won;t have to update the link in the assignment. Can I have many URLs point to the same file as I can when I have these texts on another server as I presently have. The technique I amusing now is tedious to transfer the files.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to be only a Learner in a Course
Post description: Happy Tuesday Everyone! We can only have one user account for all users of Moodle.  Some of our users have multiple roles such as Manager and Course Owner.  When they enroll in a course as a Learner, some of the permissions from Manager will still be in effect.  How can we have them be able to do nothing but what a Learner should be able to do? Would having them switch to Learner role via Profile do that?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I don't think they easily can - and the "Switch to" feature doesn't work exactly as expected -for example you don't see the submit button for assignments if you just "switch your role" to. Also - this isn't entirely a duplicate of the your forum post: Standard course certificate displays list of earned certificates but it is pretty similar.
Comment 2: Thank you, Mary! I was pretty sure that was what you would say. I wanted your opinion as an authority on the subject. Have a great day!
Comment 3: Hi Jackie, An alternative would be to have separate accounts for users who have higher level organisational roles such as managers and course owners. We encourage organisations to create separate accounts for users who are site admins or managers on a daily basis, but also have to be teachers and/or learners in the same instance. They should only use their admin accounts when they need it, and use the regular account for teaching or participating in a course. A second recommendation would be to assign higher level roles in as narrow a scope as is possible and required.
Comment 4: After many years with Moodle, I recommend to have a second "Student user" for creating and testing courses. And I can recommend to use two browser (not only browser windows) at the same time. I use Firefox for the teacher role login, and Firefox private (incognito) Window for the student role login.

Post title: how to Show teacher announcements on front page?
Post description: how can a teacher tells the students that there is new task? I login as teacher and made announcements, but that announcements not appear anywhere, how is that? when I login as admin, the announcement show on the front page . can teacher announcements show on the front page so the students can see it?? help please
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, Can you please provide more details about it? Where you have added the announcement? what you did?
Comment 2: as administrator, when we go to site home, there is a button to create new topic of announcement. but as course teacher the button is not available. As course teacher, provided Forum Announcement in the course.. Is there a way to show that Forum Announcement text on the front page??. so the student could see it although they are not in the course
Comment 3: Hi Rudy, I think you're looking for the Last announcements block, that can be added in the contexts 'Site home', ' Dashboard ' and 'Course'. When you add the block to Site home or Dashboard, it only lists announcements accessible from there, but not from the courses the user is enrolled in (Or at least, I haven't found a way to make it do that). Depending on your Moodle version and theme, there are a few other ways to display this information to your users. Most used is the Notifications icon available in the top bar of your Moodle, if you're using a Boost-based theme. The course announcements forums have been set up to force subscription, which means all enrolled users will receive notification of posts there, via email or in-site notifications (or both). The notifications box will display a row per post and will send the user directly to the corresponding forum when he/she clicks on it. Alternatively, the user receives the full text of the post in his/her email.
Comment 4: Hi Rudy It sounds like you may be trying to post at the site level instead of the course level. The teacher role is not able to post at the site level with the default role settings. A site admin role can do anything on the site. Teachers will be able to use the Announcement (News) forum to post all course level announcements. Happy Moodling!
Comment 5: yes. that's what I'm trying to do. I want to make that the teacher can write announcement on front page.. is there a way we can do that?

Forum Post: 
Post title: structure for Medical students with courses and cross-course themes
Post description: I wonder if anyone who has set up a site like this can advise me.  This sort of approach seems to be increasingly common for UK undergraduates. Our medical students undertake a number of placements at different hospitals. Each placement covers a different specialty – for example, students go on ‘Surgery placements’ and on ‘Paediatrics placements’. I am planning to set these up as Moodle courses. There are also 'longitudinal' themes that are studied in all three years, and which are relevant to every placement. Examples might be ‘Ethics and Law’ and ‘Leadership and Management’. Course Coordinators want students to have access to all material on all placements and themes, both past and future, at all stages of their course. I could set the Themes up as Blocks.  I wonder if this is the most intuitive way to handle this or if there are other approaches that would make the cross-curricular nature of the Themes more transparent.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think whatever you do...there will be a need to think about how you engage students, this may be page 1.  For example, students will be more likely to be motivated if there is a purpose 'they' recognise/connect with. Once the innovative method for engagement is established, the rest should work itself out, to be honest. I could be wrong. Warm wishes Dawn
Comment 2: I agree with Dawn and Keith. I'm not sure how much of your question is about how students travel around their course/s, but it seems to me that you are setting up a number of courses and students will enrol on the course for their placement specialism when and as they commence it. I think I would have approached this slightly differently, with the longitudinal themes in a meta course, so that students had to complete part of that (the 'fundamentals') before going on to the specialities. You could add key 'issues' in the meta course and send them back to look at 'key issues in Surgery' 'key issues in Paediatrics' from the placement courses. It's probably too late to make a meta course, but you can achieve the same effect by putting links to the longitudinal course (put all of these 'fundamental' themes into just one course - there are interactive) within the placement courses, and set up some forums for discussion about the application of theory/models etc. within the placement courses.
Comment 3: Thanks for all these replies,  it confirms my thought that both Placements and Themes have to be thought of fundamentally as Moodle courses. Christine: if you have a chance to reply, what do you mean by,"put all of these 'fundamental' themes into just one course - there are interactive"?  Why do you recommend putting all the Themes into 1 course?
Comment 4: In your first post, you say "There are also 'longitudinal' themes that are studied in all three years, and which are relevant to every placement. Examples might be ‘Ethics and Law’ and ‘Leadership and Management’." I would say that (for instance) Ethics and Law informs Leadership and Management, and you say yourself that these longitudinal topics are relevant (underpinning) to every placement. It seems sensible to show your students how themes link, and to do so as simply as possible from both the admin, the teacher and the student point of view. So I would suggest putting them into one course. You can, of course, put them into different sections (topics) within one course (when I say 'course' I mean it from the Moodle point of view) I think this is the advice we are all giving you - to think about the curriculum you are teaching in a more unified and joined-up way.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to organize ?
Post description: Hi! I'm starting new site based on Moodle. My plan (for first step) is to put on-line all test for primary school for all 8 years (in Croatia primary school is 8 years) for all subjects. For now, I dont have planned to use Moodle for teaching, only for testing. My question is how to organize all this questions? (Next step will be to add test for secondary school, faculty's, driver school, question about "life" things) Any idea? Sorry, I have no experience with Moodle, thats why is difficult to plan organization of courses, topics, questions Thank you very much for all suggestion! Greetings from Zagreb Josip
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As a reminder. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Question_categories#What_are_question_categories.3F
Comment 2: I don't know if my understanding of what you want to do is correct but I would approach it like this. Set up categories for each of your faculties. Then set up courses for each of your main topic areas (or potentially group topics together). Your decision on this has to do with where you plan to go with it. If you only ever want to stick with assessments on Moodle then I would say group the assessments to keep things central and simple. If you plan to extend later and add course material as well as other collaborative activities (wiki's, forums, databases, etc) then I would say split them out so that later you can easily add material. Then set up your quizzes. Create pools of questions so that they can easily be reused etc. Easiest way to do this is to get all your teachers to work on it. Set a target such as each teacher must contribute 3 questions. This will force them to get involved and create ownership. After you've run a few classes through, go over the results and tweak questions (some will be too hard, others too easy etc).

Forum Post: 
Post title: Setting a deadline for multiple activities
Post description: My course has 4 monthly Parts, each of which has a deadline at the end of the month. Each Part has both quizzes and assignments ca.9 in each. The course runs 3 times a year. I should like to set the 4 separate deadlines for each Part at the start of each interation of the course.  E.g. for the course starting 12th January, deadlines for Parts 1, 2, 3, 4 at 12th February, 12th March, 12th April, 12th May, respectively, at midnight.  At the moment, I can do this only activity by activity.  It is currently not possible to define that submissions are reviewable after a quiz is closed until the quiz is first closed, i.e. after the deadline has passed. There are a couple (or more?) potential methods. Set up the "master" course with the separate deadlines for each Part after 1, 2, 3, 4 elapsed months from the starting date, which is chosen when the iteration is activated. Or less efficiently when the course has been made available to students, bulk edit the deadlines of each activity in a Part to the appropriate date and time. Are either of these possibilities available for Moodle 3.9?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The "Subcourse" plugin can help you organize your course into separate Parts while managing deadlines more efficiently. With this plugin, you can create a "master" course for each Part, and then link them as subcourses in a main course. The deadlines for each Part can be managed individually within their respective "master" courses. Here's how to set it up: Install and enable the Subcourse plugin in your Moodle site if you haven't already. You can download it from the Moodle plugin directory: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_subcourse Create a "master" course for each Part of your main course (4 courses in total). Set deadlines for activities within each "master" course. You can use either the "Restrict access" method or the "Dates report" method described in the previous answer to set deadlines more efficiently. Create your main course where students will enroll, and divide it into 4 sections corresponding to the 4 Parts. In each section of the main course, add a Subcourse activity and link it to the corresponding part Repeat step 5 for all 4 Parts. Now, when you start a new iteration of the course, you only need to update the deadlines in the respective "master" courses. The main course will automatically reflect these changes, as it pulls the content and deadlines from the linked subcourses. Note that the Subcourse plugin only helps in organizing the course structure and linking content and deadlines. It does not provide a direct way to set deadlines based on a variable starting date. You still need to manually update the deadlines in the "master" courses for each iteration. HTH
