Forum Post: 
Post title: Tracking "offline" users
Post description: Hi there, I need to be able to track users for a course that is available as a classroom course, as well as a moodle course. The teachers want all the records for all the students in one place, whether they took the course online or in the classroom. So I know we need to manually 'enrol' them into the course, but how do we go about making sure they get credit for the classroom version? I have activity completion working, and the online users get automatically credited, but if I change that to manual self completion then the online users can 'cheat', can't they? Maybe I'm mistaking here? Thank you! Kate
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Dear Kate, I understand your situation and I do not think there is a technical solution to it.  If you do change it to manual self completetion then the students can 'cheat' unless a teacher operates a separate tick sheet to confirm through questioning that the student has completed the task before they click on the completion and any ticks without teacher confirmation is cheating. The issue here is running two parallel systems, IMHO either you operate the online system or the classroom system for all. However, you could choose to ignore activity completion and set an end of course / topic test as the metric of assessment.  And any students who did not complete the tasks required of them will get lower marks. Cheers, Gareth

Thanks for your consideration on my inquiry. Ann
Comment 4: Should one conclude that there is no merit in grading of forum entries? It seems to be automatic without regard to the content. If this is so, them why the "Rate This" option in the posts? I have use the forum only once for grading points and thought it was peculiar in what I was seeing but did not have the time to check it out so I prevented it from affecting grades. I guess I will have to rethink my choice of fora.

Forum Post: 
Post title: One course, three teachers, 24 students
Post description: Hello everyone, I need to setup one single course that will have three teachers and 24 students. These teachers are not regular employees of our school, they run they own business and just collaborate with us for the time of the training session. Each of them will use her/his own instructional material and they would like to ensure that it will be kept private. In other words : each teacher should not be able to see the two others's teaching resources, but students should be able to access activities of the three. My idea was to create four groups : one for each individual teacher + one for the 24 students, then create one grouping that will include the three separate teachers groups + the students group. Do you think it's a good option, or is there any other way ? I'm not sure my explanations are clear, but if you could give me some advice on how to manage that challenge, I would be very grateful. Thank you in advance. Laurine
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Laurine I know such situations and would like to answer ' don't try to solve a social problem with technology.' 1. Why didn't you create separate courses per teacher Typically a teacher is teacher on course level. This means all elements are visible for the teacher. You can add the teacher as student to the course, prepare a topic per teacher with some activities and give the teacher teacher permissions for this elements Its not possible on topic level. Now comes the trick. Create a group for all students. Define that the teacher topics have limited access to the teachers topice. As long as the teachers are not in the students group they will not see the elements. Hope its clear. Ralf

Forum Post: 
Post title: Page Linking and hide/access question
Post description: Hi I'm creating a course in Moodle 4.2 and have two questions to a course that I'm currently working on. In my course there are several pages with content. Is there a way I can link to the next page at the bottom of the pages as in Moodle 3.9 and Moodle 3.11 (There I have seen the functionality). I'm looking for an option to do a "next" and "back" inside the page, so the students don't have to navigate to side menu all the time. I can't use the URL -function because the course will be set up on different servers from time to time. So I need to link within the Moodle Course and not a URL solution. If there is a fix for my request then I have another question: -  Is there a way for me to hide some of the pages or activities but still for the students to encounter them? some of the content works best as "surprises" for the students. I know there is a Lesson -activity where the content isn't shown in the side menu, but the problem is that I need URL variables for specific content, and I can't seem to get access to them once I start to make the structure of a lesson as I only can put in content or questions.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Federik. Explore Stealth activities (Sorry that the video and screenshots refer to older versions of Moodle, but the functionality is still the same and might help with your second question.)
Comment 2: Hi Frederik! A specific filter might be what you're looking for. From MoodleDocs : "The Activity names auto-linking filter is a site Filter that will create links to an activity whenever the name of the activity is written in texts within the same course in which the activity is located." In more specific terms, you can type the name of an activity and have a link automatically created to that activity .  It can get a little bit tricky with copying from course to course, but you can work with it.  Additionally, the text must match the activity name exactly . This can be enabled by default at the site-level, or made available at the course-level.  For me, it's available under "More" in the course menu at the top of the page, and then selecting "Filters" from the drop-down list. Hope this helps!

Post title: How to do anonymous peer work with students in Moodle?
Post description: Hi! I have a teacher at our university who would like his students to do peer assessments/peer reviews of each others´ work in Moodle. They should be able to write comments/feedback, its not necessary that they can also grade each other. We don´t have the activity "Peerwork" (it has not been updated for a year and we don´t think we should add it now, otherwise that could have been an option). Is there any other ways that you know of that we could use? The teacher would like the students to be anonymous to each other but the teacher should be able to see who has given feedback to who. (So that the teacher can see the names of the students). Is this possible to do in Moodle? We are on Moodle 4.3. Best regards, Ida
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: How about the Workshop activity? It allows for anonymity.
Comment 2: I think the usual case with the workshop activity is that students can see the names of the authors of work that they are viewing, but they cannot see who is giving the feedback. This can be modified by the administrator at site administration >> Users>> Permissions >> Define roles change the permissions in the student role for mod/workshop:viewauthornames and mod/workshop:viewreviewernames It would also be nice to remind students not to identify themselves in the materials they are submitting, so that their anonymity is preserved.

Post title: Tracking activity during a meeting.
Post description: Hi, it would be great if I could be able to set an activity complete once a student enrolled in a course has partecipated in a meeting in ZOOM or Go To Webinar . It would be great if I could set a minimum partecipation time (i.e. at least 40 minutes). There's a way to achieve this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Gabri, No direct way of getting that done, but that would strongly depend on the activity completion settings made available. The only activity using the factor 'time spent' as a completion criteria, is the Lesson one. But that's an entirely different activity. And also note that being in an online meeting doesn't necessarily mean the student actually participated in it. Best way to measure and mark participation ( IMHO ) would be to set up some course activities to synchronously take part in, as part of the online meeting. E-voting, ActiveQuiz, Realtime Quiz or JazzQuiz should be interesting modules for that purpose.
Comment 2: Thank you very much, Joost!

Post title: Moodle use for Clinical Trial Review
Post description: First, thank you to any and all who can assist. I am very new to Moodle so the plan of attack is foggy to me. Situation I am building a clinical trail review website. It will hold images of 15-20 subjects (over 100 images in all) that physicians will view. After they review each subject, they are required to complete three PDF files (the forms will be filled out and electronically submitted to a third party). Once they have seen an image set and completed the PDF files, the Principle Investigator does not want them to have access to the set again. Also, if possible, to randomize the order of the PDFs for each subject (one time PDF1/PDF2/PDF3, then PDF3/PDF1/PDF2, and so on). Terms and Agreements Another issue is the site policy. It is currently in a window, but they want a full page so that the user has to view the entire file prior to submitting a Agree/Disagree choice. I considered a Choice Question as Topic 2, but how can I make it so that the remaining topics (each subject is a topic unless there is a better way) are not viewable until the user Agrees? So I used the Site Policy but the widow thing is not what they want. Current Configuration Currently I have each subject as a topic. Is this the best way? Would a lesson be better suited? If so the some seriousl guidance per the first paragraph would be needed on my part. I have two items per subject/topic: image gallery with the PDF forms and then a Lesson asking if they completed the PDFs. This is not available in following subjects until they have comleted the one previously. The problem is the images are still viewable and there is no way I know of to embed the image gallery into the lesson so they can see it and open the PDFs at the same time. Conceptual Flow Welcome Screen User Agreement Subject 1 Opened Subject 1 Image Review (images available during PDF completion) PDF1 PDF2 PDF3 Subject 1 Closed Subject 2 Opened Subject 2 Image Review (images available during PDF completion) PDF3 PDF2 PDF1 Subject 2 Closed Subject 3 Opened... ...And so on I hope this makes sense. You can reach me through here or at will@pemphigus.org . Thank you Will

Post title: implementing moodle 2.9 in k-12 school
Post description: im implementing moodle 2.9 in a k-12 school , i just need your help in which scenario i have to apply to fit with dividing students into classes and make the course unique for every stage but with different activities for each class .
with taking in consideration that every class have a teacher and every course have a supervisor on these teachers .
all of that just to limit the creation of courses " i just dont want to make a course for each class "
thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I don't understand your question.
Comment 2: sorry i didnt explain the question well . okay , first i want to implement moodle in k-12 school , i want to separate students into classes in each stage , so i want 1 course for each subject for the same stage but  with multiple teachers for each class , and different activities for each class . also i want to keep recording the grades at least for the previous academic years for the students in the same course , is it possible !! . i hope that its clear now
Comment 3: Hi As you rightly found out, the course is the basic unit of Moodle. One tends to underestimate, may be because the term is so familiar, but creating a good course is a subject of its own. How about conducting a course, assisted by Moodle, for a semester and then expand to design a whole college? P. S. You may want to ask the moderator to move this discussion to the Teaching with Moodle https://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=41 forum.
Comment 4: I have moved the thread into the Teaching with Moodle forum. First I'd suggest looking at Moodle site - basic structure . How you organise your students and teachers varies from school to school. In my old school for example we used categories for subjects (eg English, Mathematics) and then had a course per year group - Y7, Y8 ( I am in the UK) and then used Groups to separate the classes in the courses. Students and teachers were added to their groups by a csv file at the start of the year so it was easily managed. So all the Y7 English teachers and classes were working in the same course but if they really wanted to , they could use Restrict access features to only show work to their own classes and hide it from other classes. However ... this is just one way of doing it and hopefully you will learn some other ways of organising your K-12 school Moodle and you will be able to make your own decision. Also take a look at our Admin quick guide and our Teacher quick guide

Post title: Learning paths in Moodle workplace! And how to apply them in Moodle?
Post description: Hi, I'm reading this article in Moodle workplace: How learning paths benefit organisations . And I'm wondering about the availability of this feature in regular Moodle? Regards,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Naaman - In regular Moodle (that is, Moodle LMS), we have learning plans: https://docs.moodle.org/401/en/Learning_plans
Comment 2: Thanks Ravi, I'm familiar with the Learning Plans and it's relation to the competencies. But this feature is much more efficient. I found a new plugin named Programs , which some how is similar to this feature. What do you think about it? Regards,
Comment 3: Does the new plug-in offer reporting for student program progress or program completions? Kind Regards
Comment 4: Are Learning plans in Moodle the same as Learning paths in Moodle WorkPLace? Can Moodle Workplace paths be converted to regular Moodle learning plans if we decide we want to use regular Moodle instead of Moodle Workplace?
Comment 5: Hi Dan, Even if the tools are used for similar purposes, I doubt one can be converted into another. A WP Program consists of one or more courses, whereas the Learning Plan consists of one or more competencies, that can either be assessed directly or through completing course activities . It would be nice to see a feature such as programs in Moodle LMS, but that's probably a roadmap thing for the future. You could, however, use the course custom fields to mark a set of courses as being part of a specific program. That course field can then also be used in the My Courses / Course overview area to filter courses that belong to the same program. Also, you could use the subcourse activity, combined with a course set up to be a 'Program Hub course' to group all the courses in one of those programs.
Comment 6: So, I think I understand that a competency in Moodle LMS can be completed or achieved by completing either one or more activities, or a course. And, you're suggesting that one or more Moodle LMS courses could be considered a program? It sounds like the functionality of WP can be achieved in Moodle LMS, correct?
Comment 7: Hi Dan, I guess you could, but it's a kind of 'low code' approach to getting the same thing done. The only thing you can't do with Moodle LMS is what's called program creation and management. Programs are a context that's only available in WP, but if you like, you could make it work:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Scales and Grades (Quiz Scores)
Post description: Someone explain the relationship between "Scales" and "Grades" if any?  And what is the difference between "Custom Scales" and "Standard" ? Thanks for any assistance, Ken Crabb
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you mean the teacher's administration links, "Grades" is the gradebook which lists all grades of your students, while "Scales" allows you to create your own grading scales to be used in that gradebook. "Standard Scales" are server -wide, i.e. they are created by the site admin and applied to all courses. "Custom Scales" can be created by an individual teacher and they will only be applied in his/her course.

Post title: Looking for a way for students to upload their photos onto Moodle
Post description: Hey everyone I am helping manage a Moodle for an environmental education charity. We would like our learners to upload photos they have taken of nature onto the Moodle. We would like to have a specific area on the Moodle for them to do this. Also, we have low amount of memory so ideally we'd like the photos hosted somewhere else. Does everyone have any recommendations on how we can do this? Thanks in advance Mark
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: upload to www.flickr.com , paste the embed code of each image open the editor , choose html > to insert the code this can be done in forum activity , assignment ......
Comment 2: Thanks Mohammad. The free version of Flickr comes with 1000 photos capacity which might be enough. I have a quick question. So far, I've added Flickr (a private group on it) to a Forum activity and a file activity. Ideally I want a slideshow. I've seen how this can be done by creating a block. But this doesn't seem to work with private groups on Flickr. Do you have any advice? Cheers Mark
Comment 3: Hi Mark - While there are ways to upload photos elsewhere and embed them into Moodle, this might not be the best option if some of your students would have difficulties (or just be uncomfortable) finding the embed code, switching to HTML view in the Moodle editor, and copying that code into the editor. The approach I would suggest is to use a Database activity within your course. Add a field for uploading a picture, and set the maximum file size at something small, say 200 KB. Then ask your learners to resize their images, along with some advice on how to do that using readily available software, before they upload the picture. https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Database_activity https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Database_templates

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to track progress?
Post description: I'm trying to wrap my brain around the logistics of using Moodle for my purposes...I am hoping more experienced Moodlers might be able to help me. I am using the topics within a course as "stations"...but students are not required to do every option within a station (topic)...I do have requirements daily of specific stations that must be completed. So, for example, stations A, C and E might be required on Mondays, A, B and D on Tuesdays, and so on. But within each station they have a variety of options to fulfill that station for the day. And at the end of the week, they will not have completed all options...there's far more than are necessary (intentionally so, to allow for more choices.) I need to figure out a way to make it clear what they've completed already and what is still an option to do. So as the week progresses it's easy for them to easily see at a glance what's still available....and for me to be able to see at a glance what's been completed, as the week progresses. It seems like there should be a way to make the completed assignments just disappear or appear greyed out? I had tried out a checklist plugin but I'm not sure that's the way to go...I don't really like the way it works. I'm also still learning how to configure assignments so that students can mark them completed. How do I do this? Any help is greatly appreciated! Thank you in advance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tina I can't give you an exact howto here, but the two sections you need for this are the Restrict Access and Activity Completion parts of the Assignment or Quiz. Using a mixture of those - in your case it looks like mostly pass mark and dates - you should be able to put something together.  You can restrict access after a certain date, but you will probably have to restrict access to feedback and grades during that time period as well. On my site I created a course just for me called playpen, which I use to test out stuff like this without having to mess around with a real course.  Added to that I have a fake student "Johnny Tester" to make sure that it really does work the way I planned. Hope this helps!

Post title: Can students edit an assignment on their moodle account and save
Post description: Hi, this may seem obvious but Im new to moodle. can students edit a word document on the course and submit the saved edited document, or do they have to upload their own documents as files for marking?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: They would need to submit their own file for marking, though you would be able to share an original template document on the course page, or possibly through Office365, but the student would then need to save their own copy for submission.
Comment 2: Students have to upload their own document. You can put somewhere a link to template, for example, in description of the assignment. I think, depending on overall computer literacy skills of your group, you may consider providing details on what they should do: 1) download , 2) save giving a name to the document, 3) fill it in with data and save, 4) upload.
Comment 3: Many thanks.

Forum Post: 
Post title: In Moodle 4.0, can I publish a message in the course forum by sending an email?
Post description: My university has just installed Moodle 4.0. In the course I teach, I have two forums: one for sending announcements to students, and one for discussions. Can I publish a message in one of these forums without logging into my account, e.g., by sending an email to a specific address associated with the forum?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Erel - I think the answer here is no. It may be possible to reply to a forum message by email if your administrator has enabled "incoming mail processing", but this is switched off by default. You might find it convenient to use the moodle app for writing to forums.
Comment 2: As John already mentioned, this all depends on whether Moodle was set up to also process incoming emails. This is described here: https://docs.moodle.org/400/en/Mail_configuration#Incoming_mail_configuration The best thing you can do, is ask your site admin. If the answer is "we don't have that enabled", connect to your Moodle on your smartphone and post the message directly in the forum.

Post title: What FAQ's do student have??

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: First 'serious' Moodle site I set up was for an RTO environment, and tackled this as follows: Set up a forum on the front page as a FAQ and made sure people were referred there before asking for any other help, and Set up a short intro video using Camtasia which covered (1) how to access the relevant course, (2) how to update a personal profile, (3) how to access the Help FAQ, (4) how to navigate within a course and (5) how to return to the front page if lost (ie. by using the navigation bar). That was enough to get the vast majority of users moving in the right direction. Hope this helps! Mark. Mark Drechsler Netspot Pty Ltd (Australian Moodle Partner)

Post title: Automated learning plan
Post description: Hi All, Here is what I am trying to achieve for my students:- 1) A series of courses (not to be confused by the course term used in moodle).  When a student completes a course they are automatically moved to the next level/ course based on the grades they achieve, if they dont pass, then they remain in this course. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well you say "not to be confused by the course term used in Moodle" If you don't necessarily mean actual Moodle "courses" and are happy to use activities within one Moodle course, then using Conditional Activities in Moodle 2.0 would be just right for your needs. Have you investigated this?
Comment 2: Thanks Mary, still new to the whole "conditional activities". How do I set up conditional activities?, In my scenario I have build a couple of "web page" activities and converted these into text based e-learning paged and also used journal activities as the inbuild assessment modules, how do I set conditions in this? Vijay

Comment 4: Thanks Mary, on a related note, is there a method to do the same for activities in multiple course pages (moodle courses). Pulling this out from other course pages. The reason being that the whole point was to put conditions for courses, so if the contents are in different course pages, then the above method may not work (or will it) ??

Forum Post: 
Post title: Downloading Files,Videos,Audio
Post description: Hie guys.Greetings from lockdown in Zimbabwe, Africa. I would like to upload files, videos, and audios for my students but I do not want them to be able to download them. I just want them to view these activities . Is it also possible for me to enroll a student into a course for a specific period say 24hrs? Please help.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tawanda, The short answer is that, in order to view/listen to media in Moodle, is has to be downloaded into learners' browsers in order for the browser to display/play it to them. It is possible to use a 3rd party media streaming service which would make it more difficult for learners to save copies of the files for themselves. However, even with restrictions such as this, which can introduce a number of other issues that can inhibit learners' ability to study, it is still possible for determined learners to save copies, e.g. with browser extensions or audio output/screen recorders. Sony, Disney, Microsoft, Adobe, etc. put a lot of time, resources, & effort into preventing people from copying media & they haven't been able to find a way yet. All they've managed to achieve so far is to make it more difficult & inconvenient for people to view their media legitimately. In short, there just isn't any way to prevent copying media from the internet. I hope this answers your question. All the best,

Forum Post: 
Post title: Grade to pass not respected by rubric
Post description: This seems to be quite complicated. We would like to grade an assignment between 1 (one) and 10 (ten). That seems to be pretty complex as is, because Moodle does not allow you to set a minimum grade for an assignment. So Moodle grades between 0-10 always. We use rubrics to catch that problem. For example, if you make sure the minimal score of your rubric will always be 10% of the total, you will always grade between 1-10. But this leaves us with another problem. The rubric does not respect the 'grade to pass' setting. A rubric will always set the grade to pass to 55% no matter what you set it. I have created a tracker for this 2 years ago: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-66105 Unfortunately it has not been picked up. Does anyone have a work around for this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Grade calculation doesn't happen in the activity itself, but in the Gradebook. Here you can work process the raw activity grade with an Offset (n-term, normally between 0 and 2) and a Multiplier.
Comment 2: I know this works, but we are sending the assignment grade to Osiris (SIS). Therefor the grade at the assignment must represent the correct grade. The gradebook has a couple of major league bugs as well. It doesn't respect attempts like it should for example.

Forum Post: 
Post title: What kind of activity (no grades wanted)?
Post description: I have a Moodle installed (1.9.5). I have some course material based on a book about job search. There are assessments in the book that I'm trying to replicate in the digital world. Questions like 'what topics do you enjoy reading about', 'list the titles of jobs you had through out your career', etc, personal review questions. I want to capture the answers and allow the students to come back to them at a later time and make changes, and if they choose to work with a consultant, I would like to allow the consultant (in the teacher role) to see the answers. I don't want grading. Most of them are essay type questions for personal reflection, though there are a few that lend themselves to multiple answer. Does anyone have any suggestions for which activity type(s) would work for this? I thought about the online text assignment, but a coworker suggested that having the students copy and paste the questions into the submission field was a little hokey. I've tried the quiz activity, but the proliferation of buttons seems to confuse some of the older students (by older I mean some in their 50s and 60s), and I really don't want grades, so there isn't any reason for them to ever "submit" their answers. Am I missing something, or do I really just need to hack the quiz thing to show fewer buttons and try to get rid of the grading?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Lissa, There are probably quite a few ways you could do this; I'll suggest one: You could set up an individual wiki for each person (student/no groups). On the their main page, you could list the questions, and then put these [ ] around each sentence. That will open a daughter page for an answer to each question rather like the questions are the 'table of contents' page. The student can go to each daughter page and edit each answer any time.
Comment 2: Hi Andrea, This sounds very useful for some of my sections , do you know whether there is a way to have a sort of template wiki that could be duplicated for each new student? I need to automate as much as I can, as there may be large groups entering at one time. Thank you! Lissa
Comment 3: Hi Lissa, The wiki does provide a way to upload a template to do this. I read the documentation on it, but it sounded to technical for me, so I have never used it. There is an easier alternative for non-techies like me: When you describe the wiki activity in the first box, tell the students: please copy the following into your wiki, and then provide them with the list of questions with the [ ] around the questions. Do a practice to make sure it works okay. Just 2 points about using this contents type page: Don't use '&' in the questions as the daughter page does not save properly. Also make sure that no one alters any thing inside the [ ] or all the info on the daughter page will be utterly lost forever (and guess how I found that out)! Andrea
Comment 4: Hi Lissa, Sounds like for some of those questions you could use a database (depending on whether you want other students to see the answers or not). Doing it this way would allow you to set fields for each of the pieces of data you wanted. There is an activity module called Focuspad ( http://focuspad.mintranet.com.au ) that may do what you want also. It allows for templates, multiple entries, can go back and edit etc. A blog could be useful for general reflection.

Forum Post: 
Post title: User Accounts
Post description: I was wondering if there was any way to send an e-mail to every student who is enrolled in a course? I can't seem to figure this out. It would be helpful if I needed to cancel class and needed to inform them. Also, I presented this to my class, and one individual failed to follow through with the registration e-mail, meaning he never logged in. His user account is there, but when I view his profile...I see this: Last access: Thursday, 1 January 1970, 05:00 AM (11935 days 9 hrs) Any insight to this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: To post to everyone just post a new topic to the "News" forum. By default the News forum should be set so that everyone is "subscribed" to it, so they'll all get a copy in their mail.
Comment 2: When you say you've viewed his profile, I'm assuming that you found his name in the Admin list of users, but that his name does not appear in the list of course participants and that he has not enrolled in your course yet ... is that right? The date you see is a "zero" date for most computers - all the dates in Moodle are stored as seconds from this point in time. It just means he has not confirmed his account yet via the email and has never used his account.
Comment 3: Yes, I did find his name in the User List, but not enrolled in the course. I just expected to see something there like "Last Access: Never", rather than "Last Access: 'some date in 1970'". Thanks for your response, and your advice about posting to the news forum.
Comment 4: > I just expected to see something there like "Last Access: Never" Of course. I've fixed it in CVS and it will be in the next release. Cheers!

Post title: Best Activity to Use for this project - HELP
Post description: I have 17 faculty that are required to fill out a questionnaire that I will create and submit the exact same form every 11 weeks.  I am looking for the best options to create and hold all this information in Moodle - Suggestions?????  any help would be appreciated
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Trisha, the Feedback activity is the most suitable for the task you describe. You can download the data as Excel and you also have some results display on the activity itself. Regarding the recurrence, I'd save an "empty" activity as a template and duplicate it as many times as needed. Ideally, users should be informed by email that a new questionnaire is available. I think this can be achieved with the event monitoring rules , but I've never tried it with a feedback. Or you can inform them manually each time faculty members have to submit a new questionnaire. Cheers,

Forum Post: 
Post title: Am I wrong or simply stupid
Post description: During the first week of July I got a request from some one to add his name in my Skype.  Subsequently he introduced himself as a moodle developer and came to know about my work on Moodle waitlisting by a search of moodle forum.  He has committed to complete the project by the first of AQugust for a religious organization and he pleadedly persuasively to help him. I agreed the time line and the fee for the work.  He suggested to me to open a user account in Guru.com and the payment will be made in the escrow account I engaged the developer who earlier worked on waitlisting feaqture in moodle to modify the code.Every day he came through Skype and I guided him to upgrade his current moodle version to 1.8.2 and set up moodle sites in two of my test servers and demonstrated the working of the program He further insisted that I have to part with paypal integration and shopping cart code for his use.  Added to this he wanted me to upload his moodle instance in my test server and incorporate the code with his code that he already added to certain files. When the work was completed, I asked him to send a mail to Guru to say that the work is completed to and the money be released to me. But he kept quite and stopped contacting me. Next I got a mail from Guru saying that the project was closed by the client with a request to release the money back to him. Guru further asked me to go for a dispute resolution and later arbitration I sent Guru the entire trascript of the conversation between me and the developer where he admitted that he is new to moodle. Now the matter is pending for dispute resolution.  I have his full site perfectly working in my test server. Every day he is sending a message to me to remove his moodle instance from the test server This is my first experience I am in a fix and I wish to know whether I am wrong or simply stupid Nagarajan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: No, you're not stupid, you've been taken advantage of by an unscrupulous operator.  It happens to us all at some point - I've just won a court judgment against someone for whom I created a (non-Moodle) website but who then declined to pay me. If his Moodle is on your webserver, and there's traffic coming to it, then I'd modify it by putting a big banner on the front page saying that the person you helped to set it up is refusing to pay you so all his potential customers see that he's a con man. I don't know how the law works in India, but if he's in the same country as you I'd be inclined to take him to court as well if you can.  You can make life difficult for him, damage his reputation so others will be warned from making the same mistake, and possibly affect his ability to borrow money if he needs to. To avoid being ripped off in future then rather than waiting till the end of the project and then trying to get the money I'd insist on staged payments, ie you do part of the job, you get part of the money, you do another bit and you get some more, and so on. HTH Chris

Forum Post: 
Post title: Limiting the number of topics people can see
Post description: How can I limit the number of topics the students can see? e.g. if I wanted Topic 1 to be visible for two days, and then Topic 2 to be visible for the next two days, and at the same time I want Topic 1 to disappear. Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I agree that some kind of "visibility" setting for topics would be very useful. For example, if a teacher wants the students to see only some of the topics in the course, the only way (I think) is to set the number of visible topics on the course settings page. This solution, however, has two disadvantages - 1/ the teacher cannot see the other topics, either, so s/he cannot add content to invisible topics, and 2/ the tools from the hidden topics are still accessible via the " Activities " menu on the left. I think the teacher should be able to hide/show topics to students (they would still be visible to the teacher) using time (date) criteria or on demand. Naturally, the tools located in invisible topics should not be accessible through the "Activities" menu on the left. What do you think, Martin?
Comment 2: I think this is a good idea, also, would there be a way to set the minimum grade before the student can move to the next topic?
Comment 3: That would me nice. As an easy inmprovement one could just allow access to a week to students who have at list visited all items in the previous one,
Comment 4: For now I think we might end up dividing the course into separate "courses" and giving an enrollment key for each one. So a 10 chapter course will have ten mini-courses, each with its own enrollment key. This would be the fastest way, but not the prettiest. Bill
Comment 5: This is something that I put in as a feature request: http://bugs.moodle.org/bug.php?op=show&bugid=267&pos=2 Martin has said that he thinks that maybe it would be helpful for students to look ahead in courses, and he has a point, so I suppose that it is something that depends very much on the way you run your existing courses in the real world. Vote for the above entry in bugs, and if enough people vote, it might get implemented.

Post title: Course with Topics format
Post description: Good day, I have set-up a course in Moodle using Topics format. The course has 5 topics/ sections . I have few questions: 1. How to allow the instructor/teacher to add activities /resources only in the last topic? 2.  Let say the course has  two groups with two different instructors. Each instructor will have their own forum. If I (the administrator) want to replace the  the 2nd instructor, what will happen to the forum postings from this instructor? If the postings will be removed, how to maintain it? 3.  If the students want to keep track new postings in the forum, they need to specify it manually. How the administrator can do it for all the students. Thank you..
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello, 1. I don't think you can restrict a teacher to only adding activities in the last topic. Can you explain why you'd want to? There may be an alternative approach that you can take. 2. If the 2nd instructor is unenrolled from the course, their forum posts will remain as part of discussion threads. (This happens here on moodle.org; participants become unenrolled when they are inactive and their posts remain.) 3. The admin can set the default for forum tracking to 'Yes' in Site admin > Users > Accounts > User default preferences (though this will only affect new users). (Tip for future reference when posting on moodle.org to increase the chance of your questions being answered: If you have several questions, make several forum posts, each with one question per post and with a subject line describing the question topic.)
Comment 2: Thank you for your reply. Really appreciate it! Regarding (1), actually there are five sections. First section contained forum, section 2 contained quizes, section 3 contained course chapters in pdf arranged according to the topics, section 4 contained video lecturers also arranged according to the topics. The last section (section 5) is "Useful Resources" whereby the instructor can add their own resources/activities.
Comment 3: Hi, Have you considered the plugin subcourse ? I haven't used it so far. So you need to test it first whether you can restrict a subcourse to groups and how this works with resources. With kind regards, Hartmut
Comment 4: Rather than preventing teachers from adding items to the first four sections, you could just add hidden labels (that only teachers will see) to these sections saying 'Please don't add activities or resources here; add them in the last section.'

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to design a course that involves reading lots of external links?
Post description: Hello! I'm designing a course that will be mostly self paced with little teacher involvement. Probably about 6 units/topics. The majority of the material students need to study is on an external website. Perhaps 30-40 links. I want to be able to provide some context for each link (meaning information in written form). I also want students to be able to tick off each link as they read it. At first I thought I would use the book resource so I could have a page introducing a link and then have the link at the bottom of the book page. Each book would be including about 4-5 pages like this. But... There is no way for students to keep track of where they are in the book. To me this is a mind boggling shortcoming of the book resource. Bookmarks are not new technology! Anyhow, for that reason, I feel like the book is quite useless if the students need to keep track of what they have read. So I thought about using the Link resource and including my intro/context in the description of the link. That would allow students to check off what they have read. If I wanted to give a general intro to a topic, I could have a page resource at the top of the list of activities . Is this the best way to do this, keeping in mind that I want students to tick off the links as they read them?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moving to Teaching with Moodle forum...
Comment 2: If they have to read a lot of external links then yes, using the URL resource would work. Set Activity completion to manual if you want them to tick each one off as they have read it. Or set it to automatic if you don't mind the tick appearing when they simply click on it.
Comment 3: To add a little more to what Mary has said, a URL Resource can have a description that shows below the link. In my case, I prefer to set "Appearance, Display = New window" which causes Moodle to display the external web page on a new tab. I believe the "new window" option is not turned on by default, so if you like this feature, make sure to enable it in your Moodle. Another thing about URL resources is that "groups" are supported. For example, you might have three links to newspaper articles, and divide your class into three groups, giving each group a different URL to go to. This is a powerful feature of Moodle that does not exist in other LMSs. I once gave a MoodleMoot presentation about how I use external resources. As a reference, here it is: MoodleMoot2016, "Expanding your MoodleCloud Storage to Fill the "Entire Sky""
Comment 4: > I believe the "new window" option is not turned on by default, so if you like this feature, make sure to enable it in your Moodle. Thanks for that! I hadn't remembered to set them to open in a new tab, and who knows how long it would have taken me to figure that out. How odd that it's not enabled by default.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Year N to N+1
Post description: Hi, I would like to know how we are supposed to manage the following "problem" : my teachers have their respective courses (say begining in september 2003 and ending in june 2004), they have filled their courses with tons of infos, quizzes, choices, ressources, etc. Next year (2004-2005) they will do quite the same work, so they will want to use the work of the previous year (2003-2004). We could change the course end date (and make the courses last 2 years)
so the teachers could peek/pick past work and use it in the present. Anyway, I don't like this solution : you'll have to hide everything
concerning the past year, and it will display useless empty weeks. Is it necessary to create a brand new course and duplicate almost everything ? I don't like this either : a given course should remain "one", it should not be cloned each year... (imho) Of course, from one year to another, students may understand some points more quickly, or more slowly. The teacher should be able to adapt the way the course goes.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: One of the important things that hasn't been implemented yet is a really easy way to "empty" courses of user data. Right now I think you will have to "clone" your course (using the backup/restore tools) and "leave out" the user data.  Restore it as a new course and the teachers will have a starting point from which they can develop the next year's course.  You can always delete the old course if you don't want it around (you may want to archive a backup of it somewhere, though).
Comment 2: Martin, I have only recently implemented Moodle with my classes.  Please correct me if I am wrong with these assertions. If I make a backup of a course w/student data and then delete the course; it would be possible for me to: Re-create that course using the backup. Empty my server of "expired" students. "Revive" the course from the backup, if a student protests a grade or other problems arise. If I make a backup of a course w/o student data I can then: Make a new course from the backup by restoring to a new course.  That course will have all the resources that were in the original class, sans student files. I must then remove all students individually from the new "restored" class to create the "fresh" class. Are these assertions correct?  If they are I think I finally have a grasp on this aspect of the program.  If not HELP!!!  I have new students starting 6 January 2004. Thanks for EVERYTHING you do! Marc Dastous Computer Applications Teacher Lovejoy Middle School Lovejoy, Georgia USA
Comment 3: When you make a backup, you can choose what to include. When you restore a backup you can choose what to restore. So, it's generally best to make a backup and include everything , then when restoring you will be able to be selective about restoring just those parts you need (such as students etc)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Best practices of using different types of Moodle forums
Post description: Dear all: I'm creating some teaching training documents recently and just wondering whether folks here could share some "best practices" of using different types of Moodle forums. We all know that Moodle has 4 types of forums: "A standard forum for general use" "A single simple discussion" "Each person posts one discussion" "Question and Answer forum" For example, for "ice-breaker" type of "introduce yourself" type of activity, I found that using "Each person posts one discussion" would probably be most effective (each student "owns" their own "thread" and other students could comment it, etc.). Also for "larger" discussions, "a standard forum for general use" probably would be better. How about other types of forums? Could anyone please post your stories of using different types of forums to achieve your "instructional goals" or "learning objectives"? Thanks a bunch!! Wen
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I teach younger students - from 9 years old to 16 and even with the 16 year olds for my purposes I find the "single simple discussion" works best because it enables the teacher to set the topic of discussion and the students cannot get distracted by starting their own topics. This isn't suitable for everyone of course but when you want one discussion only and you want your younger students to be focused then this is the one I prefer. I also like this single simple discussion for sharing resources -playing games. I have seen on the internet an excellent example of the so-called Photoshop Tennis using this type of forum - one person posts a photo which is then changed slightly and reposted by another student and then another student continues the story by editing the photo yet again... and so on..
Comment 2: Hi Wen, Yes, I've often started the same as you with and Introduction Forum where "Each person posts one discussion".But I've found is that whatever type of forum you use first, students will assume that all the others will be the same. So later when I want everybody to have a "conversation" and reply to each other in discussing a subject, they ignore each others' contributions and start a new discussion. But in the last few weeks I've stopped using the standard Moodle forums because of all the advantages of the Open University's ForumNG developed by Sam Marshall. There are a few disadvantages because it's not fully integrated into Moodle (for example, the forum search engine doesn't find ForumNG posts) but these are minor compared to the all the plusses. Cheers, Glenys

Forum Post: 
Post title: Creating a consent form
Post description: We would like to create a consent form for students to either consent or refuse consent for class recording.  Ideally we would like to have all courses be able to access a common consent form.  Faculty in individual courses will need to have the consent of all students, so they will need to be able to track individual students (our classes are very small).  We have considered using the feedback activity, but don't know of a way to make that activity publicly available so that the language of the form is standard.  Any suggestions would be appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Pat, You could use the Site Policy function in Site Admin| Server to set up something like that. All the best Andy
Comment 2: Hi Pat, You've mentioned that you've considered using the Feedback activity for the consent form. Have you tried to put this activity on your Moodle site home page? In this case it will be available to all registered users on the site, not just people in one class. If you use My home as the default home page on your site and not Site home (Appearance -> Navigation -> Default home page for users), many students might never visit the Site home page. To work around this, you can give a link to the site-wide consent form by putting in an HTML block with a link to the form in the default My home page layout, and of course the link can be shared in different courses all over the site. Ravi
Comment 3: What about an assignment activity? The school creates a standard
electronic form. The teacher creates an Assignment and attaches the
form.  I know I can create a standard form with Adobe Acrobat or for
that matter MS Word.  I am sure there are other options.  The student
has to put their name on the form and check the box, "I agree" or "I do
not agree" and submits it. The teacher grades it for tracking purposes and downloads each completed form. Another way would be to use a quiz, with question category available on a site wide basis.  The teacher requiring a consent form would build a quiz.  Hint: If you put a number in the question title they will always import in alpha order into a quiz.   The first question could be the instruction.   The second question "Do you agree to being recorded?" Get clever with you custom scores.  One answer might be "I agree to being recorded" and it gets 5 points. A second answer might be "I do not agree to being recorded" and that gets zero.   You could also give some feedback with the second answer and allow the student to take it again.  Then there is the assignment module. Another way would be to use the questionnaire plugin.  As  I recall,
questionnaire will allow it to be saved as "public", allowing one
teacher to use another teacher questionnaire. I like the opening page HTML where a student has to agree to as part of their site registration process.   However, I am not sure how to retroactive that agreement on an existing site.   I also think a legal expert needs to be consulted if that or any similar agreement has a  "reasonable" time limit associated with it. Why do companies remind me of their privacy policy every year? Lots of options.  For a small class, I would opt for the form.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Instructional Design Issues
Post description: I'm planning to create an on-line course on writing and editing, and would seek your opinions on the best way to deliver/present the course materials.The students would be working professionals. Right now, I'm toying with the following approaches: 1.  Present each lesson with a powerpoint or html set, interspersed with HotPot tests. At the end of each lesson, the student can download the full "lecture notes" and do quizzes and assignemnts. The powerpoint or html "lecture" only covers the key points, but students are required to go throguh the lecture notes. 2.  Present each lecture in full (page turner) and end with quizzes and assignments. 3.  Do an audio-streaming lecture with powerpoints Given the subject matter and student profile, I'd welcome your views and perspectives on which would be the best delivery method. Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Abdul, IMHO the priority list for an e-learning course design: 1. Robust 2. intuiative navigation 3. Design around what students are going to DO rather than what content you want to deliver 4. Whizzy things I would therefore go for '2' in your option list if I have to choose:  streaming stuff leads to complications (suddenly not robust).  Number 1 sounds as if you are thinking how to deliver content to them and are a bit vague about what they will 'do' (hotpot tests', '..go through lecture'). Can I suggest another approach?  Since this is about writing you could really do some great things with forum work, e.g. give students some text to edit, have them post their different versions in a forum.  When they are used to this do the exercise with another bit of writing and, publish thier edits and then get them to assess each others edits.  This is a very powerful teaching technique - you will have to police their feedback carefully though - make sure they know how to feedback politely to each otherwise you could have some flaming wars on your hands. The advantages of the above:  Forums are v robust and simple, students will engage carefully with the 'doing', you should get some interesting results which can be further discussed with the students.  For further reading Gilly Salmons books should be of use. I hope I've understood you well enough for that to be of use All the best Richard
Comment 2: Thanks Richard I guess my main concern isn't so much what I want to present as how the students will best receive it. I've heard a lot about adult learners dropping out before the end of their e-courses because they found the content boring. I agree we have to get a lot more activities into the course. It's interesting that you advocate the 'page-turner' model ... I thought  that's what would kill student interest. .Your idea about using forums to discuss student work is very interesting. How would that be different or better than the workshop module? rahman
Comment 3: USe the key in your course: ADULTS. Adults have experience so do two things. 1. Make a group of them, stress the importance of filling the personal profile, organise in the beginning forums to get to know each other, etc. 2. Use their EXPERIENCE, organise forums where they can share these experiences, try to organise the streams by organising discussions topics, related to your course. (Look in the course of Art Ladder, he does this in a nice way.)
Comment 4: Two suggestions 1. create a case studies with real situations 2.Go see breeze in the www.macromedia.com website . Breeze transform your powerpoint presentation in flash format which is more appeling. Philippe Ramette

Post title: How to change text in a default forum notification?

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello, What is the exact text that you would like to change?

Comment 3: The forum email templates are in /mod/forum/templates on your server , but editing the core code files is not a good idea unless you really know what you’re doing. You’ll also need to replicate any changes each time you upgrade.
Comment 4: OK. Thank you, Jon!
Comment 5: Jon, is this something we can raise a tracker for? Meaning, to add a administration menu link to edit some basic content of the forum emails? My concern is I can't style the emails - the font size changes from post to post depending on if anyone added images into the text editor versus the file upload spot making it challenging to read on the phone (have to keep expanding to zoom in to be able read some posts, then have to pinch to zoom out to read others. wondering if anyone else would find it useful to be able to made some minor changes, such as even have the school logo at the top of the email. Comment 6: Hi John, You're welcome to create a tracker issue suggesting a new feature (after searching to make sure nobody has suggested it already). Please see the guide New feature ideas for suggestions of how to maximize the chance of your idea being implemented.
Comment 7: Yes, it probably would be a useful feature - but is suspect it’s fairly low on the list of priorities for the forum as there is a bit of an overhaul of forum activity thanks to the work commissioned by the MUA (changes introduced in 3.7 and there are more planned for 3.8). I had to change the templates on my sites because of legal notices, GDPR statements and opt out links that had to go out on all emails 🤯
Comment 8: Templates are actually made to be overridden so that you can safely edit them and not have them overwritten by an upgrade by placing them in your theme. To override the forum templates, create a subdirectory in your theme's templates directory named mod_forum, copy the template files you want to change in mod/forum/templates to this new directory, and edit the new files. The new files will be used instead of the core ones. If you use git for upgrades or unzip over the top of the old version when upgrading these files will not be affected. Otherwise just make sure to copy the new directory files when you upgrade.

Comment 8: Hi Jose, Personally, I aim to design learning activities that aren't dependent on any particular platform or technology. That way, if software changes or is no longer supported/available, it's easy to find an alternative. BTW , here's a free and open source screen recorder (for Windows only): http://camstudio.org/ It outputs to MPEG video files and Flash. You can compress the MPEG files further and output them to web friendly formats with this free and open source video encoder/transcoder: http://handbrake.fr/ It includes a task scheduler to encode lists of video files unattended; line them up, hit start, and go and do something else. Oh, and don't do too much video recording and encoding/transcoding on laptop computers, it's very demanding and tends to put excessive wear on GPUs (They overheat and eventually break down). I wrecked a couple of laptops like this before I found this out.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quiz is only showing as Preview
Post description: Hello!  Using Moodle 3.10.  We have users who are assigned a system role such as Teacher or Editing Teacher but need to be a Student in a course where there is a quiz.  Any user with an elevated system role can only preview the quiz.  How can we get these users to actually take the quiz. In the course, they show as Student, Editing Teacher for instance.  Picking up the Student role when being enrolled in the course and carrying the Teacher or Editing Teacher role from system assignment. thank you.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Jackie - give them a completely different account to use as a student. If they have a system role as teacher etc then a separate account is the only way to achieve this.
Comment 2: Thank you, Mary. That's what I was assuming but wanted to confirm. You're the best!! Thank you for sharing all your knowledge with us.
Comment 3: Mary. Do you recommend that other than system administrators users not be given system and/or tenant roles so that you don't have to have duplicate accounts?
Comment 4: Hi Jackie - If I may chip in and reflect on my own experience as a site admin of a large Moodle site, users who have a system-level role as a teacher (or manager) sometimes get confused about why they can't experience a course as a student would. This confusion is more likely to arise if they're not a regular user of the Moodle site. On the other hand, if they use the site regularly they might remember that they have a high-level role across the site, and what the privileges and drawbacks are of having this level of access. I agree with Mary about asking high-level users to use a completely different account for student rights, and perhaps they could use a slightly different name on their account profile just so they know this is their student account, eg, John Doe (student). If they need an account with student rights simply to test things out and not actually be a student, the profile name could explicitly identify this as a test account, eg, John Test Account. Cheers, Ravi

Post title: English and digital literacy for refugees
Post description: I hope I am posting my question on the appropriate forum. If not, let me know. Pax Populi, which is Latin for "the People's Peace," is the people-to-people peace-building program of the US-based nonprofit organization, Applied Ethics, Inc. For 11 years, the main work of Pax Populi was its peace-through-education program in which fluent English speakers would provide English tutoring to students in Afghanistan via videoconferencing. After the takeover of Afghanistan by the Taliban, we have suspended our work in Afghanistan as we were concerned that if it continued we could put our students at risk. Instead, we are in the process of setting up a tutoring program for the influx of Afghan immigrants arriving in the USA every day. To act on this we need an English language curriculum that is specifically geared to newly arriving immigrants. It would cover such basics as going grocery shopping, counting money, telling time, etc. Does anyone know if there is an open-source curriculum for teaching ESL to members of a refugee community? Similarly, we presume we are going to need to teach some of them how to use a computer and the internet. Is there an open-source curriculum that would teach the very basics of how to use a computer and the internet. Thank you.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Robert. To the best of my knowledge there are no open source Moodle courses for teaching immigrants English. And I would probably know. But there are a number of organizations that focus on similar problems and that use Moodle. I suggest that you contact them directly and arrange to speak with them about some form of collaboration. I will send you a direct message about this here on Moodle.org.
Comment 2: Hi Robert These two question types https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_gapfill and https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_wordselect Ship with about 800 example English language questions that are freely reusable and might be helpful in such a project.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Learning paths, adaptive
Post description: Is there a possibility to use  in Moodle adaptive learning paths, like you can in Chamilo? Example: when a pupil  scores high, the level of questions will become automatically higher, same the other way around. For example using the categorization of Bloom (revised)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: By using a combination of Activity completion and Restrict access you can direct the learning path of a student to different activities according to how well they perform in a certain quiz, yes. Alternatively you can use the Lesson activity to tailor questions depending on previous answers.
Comment 2: I have interest in this area as well. I wouldn't say that adaptive learning is native in Moodle, but the tools in Moodle and in course build tools outside of Moodle that can work natively within Moodle can be adapted to that use with some strategy in the design stage of the course. Captivate 9 can build SCORM lessons that can be used in Moodle. You can build in pretests with the results controlling what sections are skipped or complete by the student. The nice thing about this option is that it goes beyond just quiz questions and lets you customize the lesson too. Infosemantic is coming out with some new HTML plug ins that also let you pass custom data to the browser cache to be held and picked up in the next SCORM lesson. I plan on using this to even bypass some of the pre-testing because student level data can be carried forward into the next SCORM. As far as how to customize within Moodle with tools that already exist within it, we have put the random/pools, hint levels, and redo feature to good use toward a psuedo adaptive learning method. It has taken a lot of work to reorganize all of our questions by type (over 40,000 of them), but it is worth it and would have to be done in a fully adaptive learning environment anyway. Once the question banks are organized by question type, we start to build the quizzes themselves. We label the sections using information labels so the students know what question type they are working with. A student that knows the question type well will get the question correct and move on to the next type. If a student misses, they have two hint levels with point reductions of half at each miss. The second hint where all the points are gone will show a work through for the student to study and they are directed to click try again and then redo to replace that question with a new one of the same type to take what they learned from the walk through and try again for full points. They can keep working at new problems of that type all that they need to until they can get at least one question correct from the pool. Even if they do get a question correct, they can still select the redo for added practice to nail it down. We set a required 80% mastery (activity completion) on practice assignments, so even lazy students that might not take advantage of the redo feature at will find they must do so just to move on. If they do not pass at 80%, they must retake the practice and that retake will be a new random combination of questions from the question sets, so they cannot just copy and paste answers in from their last try. Students are also encouraged to retake the practice assignments as part of their exam study. Even if they passed, the retakes are valuable. We have ours set to highest grade so students are not fearful of retakes possible dropping their score. Note that at the moment there is a bug in activity completion where teacher score over-rides or hand-scoring does not automatically show the next assignment. There is a work around even if it isn't an elegant one. You just enter the student that got a score over-ride into the exceptions in the next assignment and then they can see it. There is a feature that let's you show and hide activities by groups. We looked to split out students into groups by overall skill this last year in a course or two and use that to add an additional layer of customizing the course to fit the student. It didn't seem to extend into the grade book though, unless we did something wrong. We found that the grade book expected both levels of the assignment to be done instead of just the one they were assigned. It has caused some confusion. To really make good use of restricted access as an adaptive learning tool, the grade book would have to show only the assigned activity and ignore the alternate. Good design: When you set the question pools up, organize by type and difficulty. For instance, in chemistry I have questions of the same type broken out into a formula used directly as being grouped into an easy level, medium would be using that formula but solving for a variable that will require some algebraic shuffling, and hard would require students to realize they need that equation in combination with something else they have learned forming a multi-step problem beyond rote procedural knowledge. All three types would be in the quiz for all student, so it isn't 100% like an adaptive quiz which would have kept lower performing students in the simpler questions, but we have found that it has worked well for us nonetheless. I do like that the lower performing students do get a glimpse of how the next levels up differ so they know what they are aiming toward with growth. The walk through at hint 2 lets them immediately study how it is done so that they can grow with each attempt. They can get extra live teacher help if they are still struggling and student and teacher know exactly what to target when they look at the questions that were missed (thanks to each type and level being labeled).

Post title: Can the access to students be restricted?
Post description: We are wondering if the moodle access for the students can be restricted to a specific time during the day? Basically, we installed moodle to be used as a e-learning tool for the students while they are still in the school and we don't want the kids to access Moodle when they at home. Is this possible? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Juan, you can certainly cut off access to quizzes and such by setting a closing time, although if you want students to have access the following day again, you'd have to set manually, to the best of my experience. My bigger concern though is, why would you want to restrict access to only during the school day??? That seems to defeat the purpose of using Moodle in the first place. You might think about what you don't want students to do after hours and lock that down, but in my work we use Moodle in part as a file server , delivering information on what to do by when to the students, and I want them to have access to that all the time (and their parents, too, depending on the age of the student).
Comment 2: Thanks a lot Irmgard

Post title: Effective use of Meta-Course - Moodle 3.9
Post description: Hi all, I've set up a meta-course made up of 5 courses.  In the meta-course I've added URL links to the other courses.  Is there any way to mark these as completed once each of the courses is complete. Hope that makes sense, Dave

Comment 4: Haven't done a meta course for some time. But I have the feeling you got the "hierarchy" upside down. The content is in the parent course, that is where progress is done. The child courses just bring the groups of participants to the parent course.

Post title: Alphabetical listing of course participants
Post description: I would like to see the participants in my course listed alphabetically by their last names so I can find them more easily. How do I do that? Even here on Moodle.org, when you sort by name, what comes up is a listing by FIRST name. How do I get a listing by LAST name? thanks Lorraine Eden, MGMT, Texas A&M
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I agree with you that it would be nice if one could sort by lastname on the participants page. Having witnessed in the past at what an amazing speed suggestions for improvements have been taken up by the Moodle developers, I am sure that now that you have suggested this feature it will not take long before it becomes reality. For the time being you could help yourself by using the Grades table. It is sorted by last name. You get to it by clicking on "Grades" in the Administration box on the course homepage (provided of course you have not turned the Grades feature off).
Comment 2: If you have version 1.1 of Moodle, you can modify line 165 in moodle/user/index.php from: $dsort = "u.firstname"; to: $dsort = "u.lastname";
Comment 3: Scott, Thanks for the tip. I would also suggest that the a similar modification be applied for the "Edit Users" listing under the admin menu.  To implement this, change the following line in admin/user.php: 
```text
if ($sort == "name") {


    $sort = "firstname";


}
```
 to 
```text
if ($sort == "name") {


    $sort = "laststname";


}
```
 I think this shoud be the default in both cases. Surely sorting by last name is preferable in most circumstances to sorting by first name.
Comment 4: Reading this thread with interest - and I agree  - lastname sorting is usually the norm.  Presumably, if I edit the index.php & user.php scripts, I'll need to re-apply amendments at each update. Maybe scope for sitewide config var methinks.............
Comment 5: With regards to ordering users by their lastname, I would also like to have my users lastnames displayed first. I'm in Japan, and here it is custom to have ones family name written first, thus it looks odd for users to have their given name displayed first. Of course, when registering students I could just switch their names, however when they looked at their own registration information, they would see their family name in the place of 'given name'. Is there a simple change I can make to the php files, as there is with the changes needed to order users by last name? Your help will be much appreciated.
Comment 6: The names are actually referred to throughout the code as firstname and lastname, so really it isn't hardcoded as given/family name. All you need to do is change the Japanese translation (in lang/ja/moodle.php) so that the string for "firstname" is actually "Family Name" (in Japanese) and "lastname" is actually "Given Name". That should then work correctly everywhere in Moodle, I think (assuming you don't have too many existing users to fix).
Comment 7: Thank you. I made the changes as you suggested and things work fine. The only problem now is that I've changed the index.php files in both the user and admin directories so that names are listed in alphabetical order according to users 'lastnames'. So, now western names are ordered by family name (=last name) and Japanese names are ordered by given name (=last name), whereas they should be ordered by their family names (=firstname). This is a minor problem, and since most of my users will be Japanese people I will change things so that Western names also have family names as 'firstname'.
Comment 8: Thanks for the tip re GRADES. I will check that right away. Re changing the text in the /user/index.php line, my guess is our webmaster as Administrator has access to this and I'll ask him to change it.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Questions about which is the best method
Post description: Hi, Im using 1.9 I have the typical  leesons to build with multimedia components comprising video, images, mp3 and text. My weekly lesson may have 4 or 5 short videos, pdfs etc Ive looked at each resource and tried to determine what its best used for.   Ive built/structured my weeks units like this.  Can you please comment if you know better methods or for-see any problems with what im doing. On the main lessons page that lists all weeks of the course, im using brief text with headings, This page is basically a launching pad to strings of webpages that interlink with weblinks at bottom.  (BACK and NEXT) Im adding my video link, text and images etc in the page itself using the links function in the text editor along with image insertion. Q1 On a webpage, you cannot create a resource...like add a label.  As i see it that is only available on the main lessons page.  WHy would some-one create a "label" as opposed to just writing the text on the page?  How do you use Labels? Q2 Is this the best way of doing this.  ie Covering/teaching by a series of  interlinked webpages? Q3 When i add a video, via a text link etc  How can i get this to embed in the page itself instead of opening in a whole new page.  A new page, when it finishes playing has no naviagational way to return to the webpage it launched from.  Can it be embedded.  Is there a plug in for this.  Any recommendations? I appreciate any thoughts given.  Its taking me forever to build, and id like to minimise having to redo chunks becuase i used the wrong resource to achieve somethings.  All the best, John
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello John. I will have a go at your questions; Q1.  A label is basically just a piece of white space that acts as a separator between activities /resources. So you might for instance on your main page (ie the course main page which in your instances is weekly format) have a pdf link, a link to a website and then a directory of files. You can insert a label with some explanatory text or even an embedded image and put it in between the link to a website and the directory of files to give some detail about the files. So you could use a label to split up your weekly/topic section into subsections for example. You can set up your webpage as you wish so you don't need the label's bit of white  space. Q2: Your way seems fine to me although it's not necessary to have weblinks "next"/"back" if you set the webpages to open in new windows and explain to the student that they close the page with the "X" to return to the main course page. The other option is a Lesson which actually gives you a series of linked pages which has its own built in navigation. It is however quite complex to use as a beginner. (I did a video demo of a lesson in 1.9 here http:// ) There is also the contributed Book module which is simper - just linked pages again with its own navigation. You can embed video/audio and images into that too. My school's archives are all done as Moodle books - see here But you would have to download and add this as a plugin; it is not standard Moodle 1.9 ) Q3: If you go to Site administration>Modules>Filters>Manage filters and ensure Multimedia plugins are enabled and then to the Multimedia plugins page you can enabled embedding of a variety of video and audio formats. The when you add them via a text link in the page they embed automatically on the webpage.
Comment 2: Hello Mary, What a wonderful and info packed reply.  Thank you so much for the answers and suggestions.  The build a lesson actvity is excellent, watched the youtube clip and have started to rebuild my first week using this method. Thank you for taking the time. all the best John happy festive season
