Forum Post: 
Post title: Lesson Plans
Post description: Hi Guys, I have been asked to develop a lesson planning tool for Moodle. It would be used my teaching staff to create their lessons and schemes of work on the tool. I was wondering if anything similar as been created before? Can anyone help? Sapan.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: At this point, AFAIK , the only tools that might be available may be found in the Downloads area. However, I suspect that this is an area that is largely ignored, mainly because the Moodle Community seems to be either techies interested in the tech stuff or neophytes who are still learning the ways and means of Moodle. Unless there is an existing regime of use most schools are relatively newcomers to Moodle and still working out the best ways in which to use it. So far, to my knowledge, it has been largely the efforts of individuals who have found Moodle, liked it and has used it, and waited until the rest of their colleagues have caught up.
Comment 2: Sapan, Not quite sure what you are thinking of as a lesson plan.  We just have a document that teachers post on their classes that is the plan of what they are going to do, materials they need, objectives, etc. This is the teachers plan. Some of the elements may be moved into other aspects of the course for students...such as a list of objectives, but the plan itself is for the teachers to lay out their thinking. With more info, I may be able to help more.
Comment 3: Hi Sapan, I agree with Colin's points although I think this might well be changing. Moodle is so new that there's not really a body of material to cover every case. What we do, as you have done, is to post to the forum and let the collective wisdom take over. Can you please tell me more about what you are trying to achieve? If you want a template for courses then build a dummy course and have others copy and rename/populate it although I sense you might be after more than this simple method. Paul
Comment 4: Guys,Thank you so mUch for your input. At the moment i have created an electronic lesson planner software where by teachers can access their lessons online. The lessons will include their aims, objectives, activities , schemes of work, weather they need to have special facilities of disables students, etc. Its a bespoke system that i have created for the college that i work for. The original idea was to ebolish paper material also word documents and to have it all in one centeralised area on a back end database and a web front end. Now, we use moodle as a "second point of call" between students and teachers. The teachers can upload their course material (lecture notes, assignments, etc) on to moodle and students can then download the course material. What i am wondering is if i can take my lesson planning web application and create something into moodle, or if anything similar has been created. Sapan.
Comment 5: I don't see why not if it is php, html and javscript, which can be integrated into Moodle fairly easily. You might have some difficulty if it is cgi or some esoteric language and I just do not know how Java would work - but it should. You may want to think about it as a block in which case you will have to follow some guidelines about integration. What you have suggested is an excellent idea, it really would help teachers to focus their thinking and develop their professionalism by formalizing learning outcomes and goals and without restricting them. I would certainly like to see it working.
Comment 6: Hi Sapan, the guys from LAMS (Learning activity management system) are just finoishing thefirsrt stable versiuon of LAMS Activity Planner . The idea based on lots of UK work about teacher support to create good concepts. The activity planner is based on a path where a teacher decides about his concept for a course and goes from step to step to a basic course concept for her/his needs. In the final step the teacher has a grid with all the elements, can edit them and create the course. LAMS is very much based on the ideas of Learning Design working with course patterns that are abstracted from real courses. It would be fine to create a similar modell for Moodle.
Comment 7: At one level Ralf, I suppose it could be argued that good teaching practice is good teaching practice any where in the world, but the reality is that if it is too specific, that is, tied to UK learning outcomes, it will not suit what is happening in Cadiz or Rio or Bophal, but it might in Boston or even Adelaide. If it is too generic, then it may be to vague to be useful. Be very interesting to look at though, and perhaps, can have a greater application than just a LAMS course.
Comment 8: Hello Sapan, I am interested in this kind of tool. Someone worked on it before but for an earlier version of moodle (v. 1.6).  These are the threads. http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=37444 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=48445 Salvador
Comment 9: http://sourceforge.net/projects/teacherplan/ This is what someone developed some time ago How is your development getting on..

Post title: We need your feedback to improve the activity chooser!
Post description: Hi everyone, I’m Sabina Abellan, UX Designer at one of the Educational Solutions team at Moodle. Our team is working on improving the activity chooser in order to enhance the current experience, and we need your help! We’ll be conducting a round of usability testing sessions to understand how well our design proposals meets your needs as a user, and we're looking for Educators and Content creator users. The session will be an online test of 15-20 minutes maximum, and will consist of some general tasks and questions, and exploration of two different design options. Feedback from our Community members and active users would be extremely valuable to this project, so we hope we can count on your participation. If you or someone you know would be interested in participating, please send them the below link so they can perform the testing exercise. Activity chooser · Usability test link Many thanks for your participation, Kind regards Sabina

Forum Post: Post title: Unable to import gift file: wrong file type (but is not!) Post description: Hello, I am encountering a problem when importing a (perfectly valid) gift file: it fails to import at the very first step. I use my institutions instance (still couldn't figure out how I can get the Moodle version... Checked source, but didn't see the version, I expected a "meta" mention or something, but...no) The error message says that the file I am trying to import is of type text/html and does not match the expected type: text/plain (original message is in french). The gift file has indeed a lot of html in it, but AFAIK this is perfectly valid: ```text ::q123::[html] This is my question\: { =abc } ``` I am using Ubuntu, and what I don't understand is that it appears to be ok from the OS part: ```text $ xdg-mime query filetype myfile.gift text/plain $ file myfile.gift myfile.gift: moodle gift file, UTF-8 Unicode text ``` So? Is there some kind of file analysis by Moodle itself, before uploading? I must say that this happens only on Linux platform, same file with Windows imports fine. So it could be an OS-related issue, but I just can't understand what is going on here. At what step is the file type checked, and what part does that? The OS or Moodle? Thanks for any clue you might have (or further stuff to check). Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: I think Moodle is just looking at the file extension. Try renaming to myfile.txt. Comment 2: As far as I can tell Moodle relies on PHP's FileInfo extension to determine the MIME type. So it looks like: The file is uploaded by the browser in a POST request to the Moodle web server . Moodle's PHP source code writes the file and uses FileInfo to get its MIME type. Moodle adds an mdl_files row for the file with mimetype set accordingly. Exactly how FileInfo determines the MIME type could be affected by changes to the server configuration, such as operating system files such as /usr/share/file/magic or PHP's configuration. But In my tests on both Fedora and Ubuntu your file is detected as text/plain: when I upload your file named myfile.gift from my Fedora workstation to Moodle the question import works as expected. And that's what is returned if I use the attached test script to get the MIME type of that file. But you say that there is different behaviour depending on whether the browser is on a different operating system? Perhaps you could use your browser's developer tools to check that the POSTed file is the same in both systems. If it's exactly the same file that you're uploading in both cases (and remember Microsoft Windows text editors will use CRLF instead of Linux's LFs) then you could check to see whether the uploaded file has the same hash, for example: ```text SELECT filename, contenthash, mimetype FROM mdl_files WHERE filename = 'myfile.gift'; +-------------+------------------------------------------+------------+ | filename    | contenthash                              | mimetype   | +-------------+------------------------------------------+------------+ | myfile.gift | 9f0b7dd0fc4fd778306945d336364c6d86a3a406 | text/plain | +-------------+------------------------------------------+------------+ ``` Also: file types can be overridden in config.php by setting $CFG->customfiletypes . Also: to determine Moodle's version from the source code check the $release value in version.php in the top-level of your Moodle source code folder. Comment 3: Thanks to both of you for your answers. I can't check at present, but yes, didn't think of checking with the developper tools to see what exactly is uploaded, good idea. About the Moodle version: I use an instance provided by my university, so unfortunately I have no control, and https://mycustomurl.fr/version.php is not readable. (same for config.php) But I can ask the IT people, of course. I will be able to do more checking this evening, I'll come back here to report. Thanks again. Comment 4: The specific code for working out what can be imported is https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/question/format.php#L94 , so it does seem to be mime-type based. Comment 5: Thank you for your answers, and sorry for the delay. I just got back to this problem, ... that seems to have vanished ! What I forgot to mention in my initial post is that I did indeed create a new "magic" type for gift files, before posting. The problem was probably related to some "reloading" of that new type in some OS database . A couple of days later (maybe I rebooted? Can't tell...), I am now able to upload the same file without any problems. For those who ran into the same issue (and as the format of .magic files is barely documented), I just created a file ~/.magic holding: ```text 0 search/16 CATEGORY moodle gift file !:mime text/plain ``` (I use CATEGORY because all my gift files hold that item on the first line for easy handling of questions sets.) What puzzles me is that you mention that Moodle uses the mime-type (as provided by xdg-mime query), and that command identified the file as "text/plain" from the beginning ! I don't know what happened... So, I guess, as it works now, I'll stop my investigations and leave that mystery floating. Comment 6: Thanks for reporting back to let us know it is now working, even if the reason why is still a mystery! Label:

Post title: Moodle for the NHS
Post description: Has anyone started using Moodle for the NHS or non profit organisation in the UK. I am part of the Learning and Development Directorate of the Health Informatics Service in Kent and would love to hear from anyone whose proposing to use it or has used it. Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Shona Sorry - did not see your post before I did mine. We are using Moodle in Somerset - patient safety, medical education modules, manadatory training and IT training so far. It is working well although it does take a long time for us to generate content as all 'teachers' also have other demanding day jobs! Happy to share other experience Tim Jobson
Comment 2: Hi there Thanks for replying. I almost gave up it was such a long time ago. I think there is a Moodle fever out there now the words got round about Moodle and how valuable it is. I am curious though from a technical perspective; have you gone down the hosting route or did you install in-house? I'm wondering if I need any further specific skills to say I can support it as I am an IT Trainer moving into e-Learning. It seems all too easy. I started about 5 years ago looking at it, more as a personal development but its become something of an obsession. I have got a working version of Moodle that I keep 'tweaking'. Of course its developing all the time too so getting into practice with upgrading between versions. Good to know that there are NHS people using it! Best wishes. Shona
Comment 3: Hi We installed 'in house'. Our IT department did the installation (although I had tried for myself on my PC at home to see how easy it was) - and as I don't have direct access to the server I periodically ask our network manager to add files  updates. I tend to do all the system admin myself after that - but keep things as simple as possible, and try things at home if i am unsure. All seems to work OK - at the moment. I havent got a handle on how much is used out there - there are only a few reigstered NHS sites, but I wonder how many others like us have an intranet based one which won't be visible. Tim
Comment 4: Hi to you both, I'm in the process of rolling out Moodle as our primary LMS for managing mandatory training activity. I work for a Mental Health Trust in the South East and have providing eLearning for more than three years and Moodle seems the natural progression from this. The trigger for this has largely been to find a recording/reporting solution for the NHSLA requirements and when it looked like OLM would not provide what we needed I switched to concentrate on Moodle. Currently it acts as our training catalogue, enrolment tool, eLearning content and tracking for managers reviewing their staffs activities . I know that we are not the only Moodlers in the NHS, I believe Southampton have progressed and there are others using in a variety of ways but happy to share and interested to learn about your application. Regards, Jeff
Comment 5: Hi Jeff, I was interested to read in your post that you are using Moodle as a training catalogue and enrolment tool. How did you got about this? Did you find interesting modules or customize it to your needs? I work for the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, in Geneva - I am currently evaluating how Moodle could meet our needs. Best regards, Abel
Comment 6: Hi Abel, My post in here will give you some information but we continue to develop Moodle for our needs and at present the existing modules satisfy this. Prior to using Moodle we had a very convoluted and unreliable application and enrolment process and the accuracy of our reporting was questionable. Moodle has heloed us move on significantly in this regard. I'd be happy to provide further detail if you have any specific questions so please feel free to contact me. Regards, Jeff
Comment 7: Well we are Moodle virgins up here in Scotland and enjoying the ride! This September saw the launch of the national vaccination programme against the human papillomavirus (HPV). In NHS Borders we decided we needed a fresh approach to education. In the past we relied on key professionals attending a seminar to discuss new vaccine developments. This was augmented by a powerpoint presentation and endless email updates. They ticked boxes for us in the Public Health Dept as having tried to enlighten colleagues but in truth their impact was questionable. Small numbers of health visitors, even less practice nurses and next to no GP's attended. Phone calls kept coming in for answers to q's that were addressed in the seminars. With the new HPV programme Moodle came to the rescue. With the help of E-Learn Design Ltd (a Moodle partner in Scotland) we planned an interactive programme to better engage people with the topic. It consists of three modules covering key topics, forums, quizzes. It also acts as a repository for important documents that all too easily get lost when delivered as email attachments. Well watch this space to see how it is received. So far so good. Lots of positive feedback. One or two grumbles from some who took a dislike to being offered this free resource without being asked first. Well you rarely can please everyone! Several hundred people were sent enrollment details. We can track the uptake as well as get a handle on how much of the content has been absorbed through the quizzes. More programmes planned for the near future........
Comment 8: Hi everyone, we are using moodle in an Aust area health service to building learning communities and also we are now building programs for clinical knowledge and skills. As there are not many people trained in converting learning packages to elearning, the process is slower that I had hoped, but practice is making it quicker. We are also developing a breastfeeding blog for lactation consultants to provide up to date information to health professionals in forums or FAQs. This one we hope will be more interactive. It is great to see where others are using Moodle in health
Comment 9: Hi everyone My educational charity the Open Learning Partnership is working with a number of NHS Trusts on Moodle. The Trusts include Princess Alexandra Hospital in Harlow, Hillingdon hospital, Medway Trust and PCT, Chelsea and Westminster, Portsmouth and North Cheshire hospitals. We are planning to hold a one day conference in January so that people can meet. Please reply if you would like to come.
Comment 10: Hi there. We are developing a moodle site for Cornwall. V. exciting!
Comment 11: Details of he Moodling for Health conference can be found here . The conference is on 21 January in London. Already 15 NHS Trusts using Moodle have signed up and the day promises to be highly engaging.
Comment 12: Hi Doug I work in the voluntary sector with a UK cancer charity and we have been using Moodle for over 3 years to support the workforce development needs of health care staff involved in delivering end of life care. I was really interested to see that a Moodling for health care conference held earlier this year. Are there plans to repeat this event in the future? Shaun Kinghorn Online Learning Developments Lead Marie Curie Cancer Care
Comment 13: Hi Shaun There will be a further Moodling for Health conference in the autumn and I will make sure you get an invite. If this is of interest to you please contact me for a discussion - doug.gowan@olp.org.uk.

Post title: Best Way To Set Up a Simple Web Quest in Moodle?
Post description: Hi there, An instructor we work with wants to set up a simple directed web quest in Moodle  where students visit a web page and fill out some short text responses that will not be graded.  What is the best activity to use for this? We tried Lesson but that wants to be adaptive, and we don't need adaptive.  Survey doesn't let you enter your own questions, and Quiz seems like a bit of overkill for this.  Any recommendations? Thanks, Kristen
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comment 2: Kristen, Have you thought about using the Feedback activity? It is similar to the Survey activity but you create/add your own questions. It allows for multiple ungraded submissions.  Questions can be multiple choice, multiple choice rated, short text answer, longer text answer, or numerical. It has some analysis capability built in and can also export to a spreadsheet. You can even set up conditions to control which questions get shown based on previous answers. Hope this helps, AL
Comment 3: I will look into the Feedback activity for this - thanks for the suggestion! -Kristen
Comment 4: As you can see Kristen, there probably isn't a 'best' activity. It depends what you want the students to gain from it. If it is for revision notes, try individual (or collaborative) wiki, or even blog . If it is not being graded then feedback activity would be fine, but you could use the quiz still. It depends on the purpose of what you are asking the pupils to do. If there is no grade, will the teacher be giving comment based feedback? Will a teacher look at it at all, or just check it is done? You could set up the questions as individual Q&A Forums for students to post what they find out then carry on the discussion. If you want them to 'submit' something you could do it would be via an Assignment (online text) - which would be one of the easiest to set up. Hope that helps. Vinny

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle as adult education portal
Post description: We have use Moodle as educational portal in North Carelian province, Finland. Site's main purpose is to provide information about adult education, organized by local educational institutes. Site contents are made in cooperation with several institutes, as well as local labour administration. Site is also used as a our project's intranet. In our website planning (links, texts, navigation) we have modified some of Florida State University's user- and need-based website planning guidelines (Sampson et al. 2001, Panke et al. 2002; see http://www.career.fsu.edu/techcenter/ ) for user-friendly site structure. Site itself has been builded using Moodle's courses, modules and blocks. Moodle courses has been used as "user profiles" to provide different contents and links for different user groups. Expect intranet, all courses are open to guest user - logging in is not needed. Most of Moodle's functions are hided to keep user interface as simply as possible. In front page and inside side each profile (course), most of the contents has been made by Nwiki. Nwiki provides great blocks like content block and search block. There has been some technical problems in Nwikis backup/restore in Moodle 1.6.x, but otherwise it's a great tool for our purposes. We have reported these problems to Wiki discussion as well as to Moodle Tracker . Our Moodlesite called Akkuna (a Finnish word for window) is http://www.akkuna.fi . Unfortunaly, it's in Finnish only... Please feel free to add any comments here or with email jani.lemmetyinen@joensuu.fi

Post title: Using Moodle for Language Translation
Post description: I have this request to setup a system where subject matter experts read through certain course modules in one language and simultaneously translate the content to another language say local language. Say from English to a local language. The original language to be translated (English) are saved in PDF format. We should be able to save out the translated (final language) language to html or ms word format after the translation and this will be distributed in hard copy or plug into another system. We are looking at split screen approach where the language to be translated in PDF appears in the upper part of the screen and a space for translation appears at the bottom part. As the Subject Matter Experts read through the pdf in the upper part they translate in the lower part. Any idea from anyone will be appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ademola, Moodle was not designed for the type of activity you describe. The only split-screen part of Moodle I can think of is the grading form for online text assignments.  But that is not a good solution for your situation - there is no way to save the translated text externally. If the purpose of the activity is to create document translations, then I suggest using a word processor in split screen mode.  Or, you could post the original PDF document in Moodle and instruct the SMEs to open MS Word for their translation (resize the Moodle/MS Word windows so both can be seen). Floyd

Post title: New to moodle ... can I do this?
Post description: Hi, I perused the forum blocks and this seems most pertinent so I'm posting here. I've got a few questions. I'm set up on a windows box and went with Apache . Could I have run IIS for this? I want to create a school, but instead of scoring, I want to offer them feedback and redirect to more reading they may need to do (they scored wrong on #20, so direct to some relevant links)... Is this possible? Tips? I also want to show a progress on the course. A gauge control that updates itself as the student answers questions in the course. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Welcome, Adam. If you know the term noob, you're less of a noob than many of us. I can't address the platform question. But you could look at the Install notes in the documentation. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Installing_Moodle You can use activity locking (for now) and conditional activities (coming in 2.0?) to send students to relevant links. I've never heard of a custom plugin or block showing learner progress. Maybe someone else knows of something. I very much like the idea. While it requires a linear course, certain courses/learners could really benefit from it. SCORM courses (composed of several elements), when loaded into Moodle, do this automatically, in the sense that they show a checkbox with checkmark beside all completed activities. The gradebook will also show this if your landmark activities are graded activities. The student can view his or her own progress, but no one else's. Post title: Delivering training on Moodle using translation
Post description: Hi, we are planning to deliver a Moodle course in Mongolia. The trainer will be based in England, and will be speaking only English. All materials and instructions will be translated into Mongolian. In fact, most participants are not English speakers, and will be working on the Wikis, in the Forum, and on the assignments in Mongolian. We were thinking of hiring a facilitator who can speak both Mongolian and English, and ask her at the end of the day to summarize the key points made by participants, and translate them into English for the trainer. A 6 hours difference would also allow her to translate the trainer's inputs before the participants meet the next day. Have you ever had to address a similar language issue? If so, how did you do it? Thank you so much!! Fabiana
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Surely you are not teaching English using such a method. Apart from an introduction in your 1st language, English is best taught English through English from beginner level.
Comment 2: Hi John, It doesn't look like they are teaching English - the issue here seems to be that the trainer is English and doesn't speak Mongolian, and the participants don't have a great command of English. Using a translator to improve the feedback from the trainer is going to be essential here, and using the time difference to turn around the material will help, but this will be a tough task for the trainer. The only suggestion I would make to the OP is to make sure that the translator is also very familiar with the subject matter.  If not, a lot of small but significant points could be missed which will make the trainer's job even harder, and the experience for the learners will be deprecated. I always look for translators who have qualifications in the material they are working on - otherwise they are just translating words.
Comment 3: I do believe that as online courses continue to grow in demand internationally, there will be a growing need for course translators. For example, I'm British born giving English lessons in Russia and I wouldn't have had any success in my business without my Russian wife who is a linguist and an English to Russian translator. There must be a heavy demand for professional course translators, and it's very important that you get this translation right.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Seeking Guidance: Tracking Attendance in SCORM with Embedded Streaming Video (HLS) – Without Forcing User Actions
Post description: Hello Moodle Community, I’m reaching out for help regarding an issue I’ve encountered with tracking attendance for videos inside SCORM when using HLS or embed stream links from a third-party video hosting service. The Issue I’ve noticed that if I embed a video stream link (HLS or iframe) from an external video hosting service (e.g., Bunny.net, Vimeo, AWS S3) inside a SCORM package, Moodle does not track whether the learner actually watched the video. The SCORM package seems to have no way of detecting: •If the video was played •If the learner watched the full video •If they skipped or fast-forwarded Since the video is hosted externally and not inside the SCORM package itself, SCORM only tracks whether the module was opened, not the video completion. What I Need Help With •I do not want to add logic conditions like “Click to Confirm Completion.” •I only want the video to be watched, and SCORM should automatically mark it as completed when the video ends. The Dilemma: Should I Upload Videos Directly into SCORM? To ensure proper tracking, one option is to upload the video file directly inside the SCORM package, instead of embedding a streaming link. However, this raises concerns: •LMS Performance Issues: Large video files inside SCORM may slow down Moodle. •Storage Consumption: Hosting videos inside SCORM increases the size of backups and restores. •Streaming Performance: SCORM loads the entire video, unlike HLS which streams efficiently. Questions for the Community 1.Is there any way for SCORM to automatically track video completion when using an HLS streaming link? •I do not want students to manually click any “I’ve completed this video” button. •I just want SCORM to detect when the video ends and record it as completed. 2.Should I upload the videos directly into SCORM, despite performance concerns? •Will Moodle handle large SCORM packages efficiently if videos are embedded directly? •How do other users manage video-based SCORM tracking without affecting LMS performance? 3.Are there alternative methods to track video completion while keeping the SCORM structure intact? •Has anyone successfully used xAPI/Tin Can API for tracking externally streamed videos? • also I don’t want to integrating an H5P Interactive Video inside SCORM be a possible solution I really appreciate any insights, solutions, or best practices from those who have tackled this before. Thanks in advance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Makseem Mak! Tracking video completion inside a SCORM package with external streaming can be tricky, but nothing that a good technical adjustment can't solve! If you want to keep the video inside SCORM, the most effective solution is to create logic that listens to playback events from the video player. Some players allow triggering JavaScript events when the video starts, pauses, or ends. With this, you can send these events to SCORM using `SCORM 1.2` or `SCORM 2004 API` ( `setValue('cmi.core.lesson_status', 'completed')` ). This approach requires the video player to support this JavaScript communication. On the other hand, if you don’t need the video to be inside SCORM, I recommend using the SuperVideo plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_supervideo ). It allows for more efficient control over student progress, ensuring that the video is watched before unlocking the next content. SuperVideo offers advanced options, such as mandatory full viewing, progress blocking, and integration with detailed reports within Moodle itself. This way, you keep the experience smooth without compromising LMS performance! If you need any more help, we’re here for that! 🚀 Eduardo Kraus Innovation and new products

Post title: Assigning readings
Post description: This is sort of basic, but how do you put a reading schedule in your class? I have been posting assigned chapters as text on the home page, within each week. The problem with that is that if we push a reading back by a week, then I have to adjust the text on each week's page, which involves odius amounts of cutting and pasting. Thanks for any tips!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Mark, we have a lot of readings for each week.  Textbook chapters were inserted as a label, for example "Shortliffe Chapter 8" .  If we decide to move readings, I will have to go through the move function with the arrows.  That's tediuos compared to drag and drop, but not impossible.  Other readings were uploaded as pdf files, and also move with arrows.  I'm not sure that helps, you might look at our Orientation Course, which is open to guests.  Go to moodle.shis.uth.tmc.edu, login as guest and enroll in  the New Student Orientation.  It has examples of lectures, files and videos, readings are treated the same way.  Hope this helps, Irmi
Comment 2: "I have been posting assigned chapters as text on the home page, within
each week. The problem with that is that if we push a reading back by a
week, then I have to adjust the text on each week's page, which
involves odius amounts of cutting and pasting." We treat readings somewhat differently, as they are usually associated with an assignment. Therefore, in order to keep the main Moodle page from being overwhelmed with reading items, as well as to make sure students see that the readings are related to assignments, we put the readings directly into the assignments. I have a CSS class that I use to highlight the readings so they are always displayed in a separate colored box. This way, when I move assignments around, the readings go with them. This may not respond to your specific context if your readings are attached to a topic rather than assignment, although you might also think about creating a single assignment called "reading" and then putting all of your readings in that one assignment.

Post title: Not allowing access to activity once grade is passed
Post description: Hello! I am lookng for some help with the following: Once the learner receives a passing grade, then the learner can no longer access the SCORM activity.  Attempts are set to unlimited.  Moodle 4.1.4
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: So, what I am actually looking for is a way to not allow the learner to access the SCORM activity once they have gotten a passing grade. Anyone???
Comment 2: You can set activity completion for the scorm to require a pass. It looks like activity completion restrictions only work for other activities though -- one way around this would be to put the activity in it's own section, and use the section restrictions to only allow access when the scorm isn't complete. Seems a bit round about and not really satisfactory, but ymmv.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Create Once - Write Many
Post description: I am fairly new to moodle, so I am sure the solution is staring me in the face. I want to create one module (let's say a Choice module) and then have it show up in all 10 of my classes. Is there way to do that? To see all 10 of my classes feel free to visit www.hmstechnology.com/moodle . Your answer is greatly appreciated, Phil
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Phil, You might try creating it in one of your courses and then backup that course (including only that item - I think this can be done) then restoring that course into one of the others that you want.
Comment 2: If I tried that, I am afraid I would break something. Yes, while in editing mode I believe there should be a way to copy and paste an assignment, or duplicate it to another class. Maybe someday. Thanks for your help, Phil
Comment 3: Moodle is tough to "break." It might be worth creating a test course and do all your copying (restoring) into it. Just a thought. Jeff
Comment 4: Jeff, That is a very good thought. Thank you. I will definitely do this. Phil
Comment 5: Or, the other way round, you could import the one choice into the target course(s) from the source course. Rgrds, Paul.
Comment 6: Paul, Where can I LEARN more about how to do this. I have 10 courses, and I am going nuts creating the same thing 10 times!!! Thank you, Phil
Comment 7: If you are using version 1.8 or 1.9, then do the following: 1. Log into the course you want to import something into 2. Click "Import" under the course admin block 3. Select the course to import from and press "Use this course" Then rest should be pretty self-explanatory...just follow the prompts. Steve
Comment 8: Wow! I get it! You have saved me many hours over the course of a week. Thank you, Phil

Forum Post: 
Post title: Pls assist me on Grouping
Post description: Dear Sir/Madam, Appreciate your guidance to direct me on how to do the following in grouping ? I want to assign 2 teachers to a course and make a grouping of students for each teacher (group 1 and group 2). I want to assign teacher 1 for group 1 and teacher 2 for group 2. A teacher sharing a course with other teachers should be able to filter one's activities and grade book. so teacher 1 doesn't see the students from teacher 2 classes. Even i tried to follow the documentation I couldn't do the following. [( https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Groups_FAQ#How_do_I_assign_a_teacher_to_a_group.3F_Can_a_teacher_be_in_more_than_one_group.3F )] How do I assign a teacher to a group? (documentation says similar to assigning students i can assign teachers to a group. But when i use add/remove members i can only locate students. Teachers are not visible to select.) How do I restrict a teacher to view only information about the groups that they are in? Really appreciate your step by step guidance please..... Thank you in advance. Kushan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Kushan, The documentation is correct. You can actually add anyone enroled in the course to groups. Student, Non-editing teacher, or Teacher. So, you need to make sure what you are calling "teachers" are actually enroled in the course. It will not work for roles that are not enroled, even if they have access to the course, such as the Manager role has.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quality Control in a course - Moodle 3.3
Post description: Hi all, In a course with a lot of students we want to provide feedback to teachers on the quality of their feedback to students.  Ideally within the course itself. Has anyone done this?  If so how? Feedback to each teacher needs to be separate and confidential. Cheers Dave
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Dave, I have used questionnaires for each course I've taught. I normally use the feedback activity. You can include ratings for all teachers in one single feedback or create one feedback activity for each teacher. You can also configure the access rights so that teacher cannot access the questionnaire. Since you can export the results as a file, you can edit the file, include only the responses about a specific trainer and create several reports, one for each teacher.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle and accessibility
Post description: We are a group of students from an HND Computing and Internet Technology course at Yeovil College in the UK, and as part of our final project have decided to develop an intranet for the higher education college network and we have decided to use Moodle. Here in the UK, websites to be used by students in a college have to follow the Special Educational Needs Disability Act (SENDA), and we would like to know what measures have been taken to ensure Moodle is suitable for people with special needs? Would Moodle work on devices like touch screens and screen readers? Could Moodle be navigated with a head pointer, rather than a mouse? Documentation regarding SENDA can be found here . Many thanks, Laura Challis
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I would obviously like Moodle to be as accessible as possible. My layout design technique incorporates simplicity and a general awareness of page rendering order, as well as using ALT images where possible, so it should be fairly good, but I haven't conciously conformed to any particular accessibility criteria such as SENDA, Section 508, WAI etc, nor has it ever been tested on screen readers as far as I know. There are some plans for XHTML -compliance in the near future which may help. One way your group could help this project is to perform an audit and report back here with your findings, highlighting specific things that could be done to improve accessibility.
Comment 2: We are concerned about accessibility too, and as a test I tried accessing our moodle site using the "lynx" and "links" text mode web browsers. It *was* possible to use most of the site sucessfully in pure text mode, so I would guess that screen readers would not have much of a problem. The only bit that I haven't manage to get to work so far is submitting quizzes, because of the javascript check at the end, which the text mode browsers don't support. I'll report back with other findings when I have them.
Comment 3: I've also sat up to the latest laws in the UK about accessibility. I looked in to Jaws as a text reader, and used it to test some websites. Going from memory, it basically doesn't have a problem, until you hit frames, and then it only reads one, until the user navigates to the next. It isn't always clear when there is more than one frame. Looking at some parts of moodle, there was a frame, which I stumbled on. This could be replaced with includes, which PHP does quite nicely.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Automatic grading for participating in forum
Post description: So there doesn't seem to be a way to grade a student for posting at least once in a discussion forum. You have to manually "rate" each individual post. I have over 50 students, who all post thoughtful stuff, but it is the few who occasionally forget to post at all one week. I know I can review their activity reports, but then what's the point of even having a gradebook. In last year's class, I didn't even use the gradebook at all, I don't see the use.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Doug I have 180 students that I monitor and rate the posts. I find it easiest to rate them as I read them (if using a point system Moodle will not allow more points than what was assigned). You can set up the rating system for a numerical grade and do the sum of all posts, or simply a satisfactory scale. I find the system very easy to use. What specifically are you trying to accomplish with your forums?
Comment 2: Doug, My instructions will work for the new Moodle gradebook (Moodle 1.9) where you can create a graded item entry independent of a Moodle activity. To accomplish what you wanted to do (kind of like a completion grade for the forum) I would select in the Forum settings to have "no grade" (since it's not capable of just being a completion grade). That way it doesn't show up in the gradebook. I would put in a graded item in the gradebook named the same as the Forum (that way students think it is the same thing) and make it worth however many points you want.
Comment 3: Brett Very helpful and great screen video. thank you kaz

Forum Post: 
Post title: course format
Post description: Hi there
in Moodle 1.9 I was using a course format called simple course. To me it was the best format designed on pedagogical principles. I am working with a school and I want to show them this format but can't find it. Could someone please help me?

The format was more topic based. It presented the content in pages with back and forward buttons that allowed you to work in it more like a book. An added advantage was that as you built up the learning activities on each page, a menu on the left hand side was generated. When the student worked through the activities, the relevant page title on this menu was highlighted so they could see where they were. The menu allowed students to work through each page or go directly to the page they wanted.

Each 'page' could support video and all the course activities could be added. I liked that learning could be presented more flexibly and sequentially to assist with scaffolding, revision, etc.

Hope someone can help.

Andrea

Forum Post: 
Post title: test of level on knowlegment
Post description: ```text
Good morning, my moodle version is 3.5.10.

I wanted to know if there is any tool to make a questionnaire to the students asking them the level they have in each part of the course and after that score for each part, which automatically redirects them to the modules they have to address.

I will give an example, assuming that my course is English reading, writing and listening.

I ask students to tell me their level, let's say a scale of one to five.

After the student scores, he gives a result for each part and a general one.

It then tells you the modules you have to study.

Thank you.
```
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Raul, The Questionnaire plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_questionnaire ) allows for conditional questions, so you can create a type of branching scenario. Alternatively, you could try to create something like this with the Lesson module ( https://docs.moodle.org/en/Lesson_activity ). It'll take some tweaking before you get the proper results, but I think these would be the best options. Or consider using H5P Branching Scenario ( https://h5p.org/branching-scenario ).
Comment 2: Many thanks Joost! One question more: why do you prefer Lesson module to make branch than h5p or questionnaire?
Comment 3: It's not really a preference, honestly. Lesson is probably the oldest activity for this purpose and allows for registration of results in your course's gradebook so they can be used for followup activities or reports. Questionnaire is a purely formative option, and H5P branching scenario is really pretty, but may have a steep learning curve.

Post title: audio player costumization
Post description: Hello, I was searching web for a while to create a custom audio player. My sister is a teacher and she wants to make a listening exam to her students at Moodle. The audio player will not have a seek-bar, so students won’t be able to fast forward the audio. How can we build an audioplayer with these conditions?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ibrahim, Have a look at the Poodll Twice Audio Player which is part of the Poodll filter (not free). https://demo.poodll.com/mod/page/view.php?id=244 The same template is in the VideoEasy filter which you can get and read more about here: https://moodle.org/plugins/filter_videoeasy Because they are templates they are pretty easy to tweak and customize from the settings page for the template. That is where you would add the exam-link display.

Post title: Some Courses only for user in specific group
Post description: Hello Is it possible to allow self-enrollement to a specific course for users that are in a specific Group? thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Andrea, That would be a possibility, provided the group was created as a 'cohort'. The answer ho to get this done, can be found in the Moodle Docs , here: https://docs.moodle.org/403/en/Self_enrolment#Allowing_only_cohort_members_to_self-enrol . You'd have to create and fill the cohort or site-level group, and the Moodle Docs on how to do that, can be found here: https://docs.moodle.org/403/en/Cohorts
Comment 2: thanks I will see that
Comment 3: If you are not using cohorts yet there is an option to have courses where student and teachers can use the Self enrolment feature. There is an option for Adding a group enrolment key to a course which will also work. You just need to keep track of all the different enrollment keys. We typically use a pattern for enrollment keys and then with each school's key include the school's 3 letter initials.
Comment 4: Challenge with just using enrolment keys is that they have a tendency to end up in the hands of people who shouldn't have them in your Moodle. Once you created an enrolment key, there's no way to control who is entering your course with it: you are only aware of the fact they know the key and used it, but have no means to identify by that where they came from.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Can I get your advice about choosing a course structure?
Post description: Hello, I am preparing a 14-hour course in Moodle. I have learned about the resource Book and wonder whether to use Pages/Quizes/Assignments or Books instead. Could anyone share their feedback on these two alternatives? With using Pages, Quizes, Glossary, and Assignments Currently, I have the following course outline that looks a bit like the following (I won't repeat the lessons, but there are 10 lessons). Module: Course introduction Page: Welcome to this course Page: Learning objectives Page: Most asked questions Glossary: Terms you will read about Module: Lesson 1: XXX Page: What you will learn in this lesson Page: Introduction to X Page: History of X Page: How to use in practice Quiz: Test your knowledge Assignment: Put X in practice (The lessons repeat 9 more times) Module: Course closing Page: What you have learned Page: Next steps Quiz: Final quiz Page: Course certificate With using Books The same course structure could look something like the following when using Books. Module: Course introduction Book: Chapter for (Welcome to this course; Learning objectives; Most asked questions) Glossary: Terms you will read about Module: Lesson 1: XXX Book: Chapter for (What you will learn in this lesson; Introduction to X; History of X; How to use in practice) Quiz: Test your knowledge Assignment: Put X in practice (The lessons repeat 9 more times) Module: Course closing Book: Chapter for (What you have learned; Next steps) Quiz: Final quiz Page: Course certificate Could anyone share their feedback about structuring courses, also when deciding between using the Book resource? How would you structure the courses? Thank you !
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Jessica, I would recommend you to follow the guidelines provided by ABC Learning Design. Details are available in this introductory course . I think your plan may cover 3 of the 6 recommended types of activity. At the moment your course looks like it is lacking opportunities for the students to collaborate, do their own research and to discuss the material.
Comment 2: Hi John, Thanks for your reply. I will have a look at the ABC Learning Design. More globally, would you recommend to use the Book resource, or multiple pages (Page resource) with Quizes and Assignment resources instead?
Comment 3: I think the choice between Book or Page resources will depend on the context and what your students might want to do with the material. In both cases, you will use the built-in moodle editor to add audio-visual elements or H5P exercises. But, for example, the book has an easy way for students to take the whole text and print it out. From the point of view of ABC learning design, "book" or "page" are both ways for students to ACQUIRE content... that is only one of the . six types of learning activity.
Comment 4: I'd say it depends on the nature of the intended learning outcomes (ILOs) & the tasks you use to achieve them. For example, why impose the additional overhead (& cognitive load) of online collaboration, as well as the assessment issues that such tasks raise, when the ILOs can be achieved more quickly & efficiently with quizzes & assignments? However, there may be advantages to including social elements, such as shared tasks on discussion forums, for example to reduce the perceived social distance among cohorts of learners, improve teacher presence, & to improve course completion rates. For a course that is intended to last 14 hours, I doubt that there'd be much time for effective "community building" & it's unlikely that the students would feel that it's worthwhile unless the course is part of a larger programme in which whole cohorts are studying together. Even for "Carnegie unit" courses (i.e. 12-14 weeks), community building tends to be brief, shallow, & not all that beneficial in terms of students acting as useful resources for each other, e.g. recommending useful resources & helping each other with academic issues. Just my 0.02€!
Comment 5: Books have the advantage of grouping related material in the single resource; it makes the overall course outline easier to grasp. The corollary is that if students have to go back and find information, if the books are large it might be harder to zero in. If you're using activity completion, individual pages will give you greater granularity in terms of seeing who has looked at what. This often isn't necessary. You can have your cake and eat it though-- using Activity names auto linking allows you to refer to linked pages (like an SOP or reference document) within a book, while having it as a separate resource as well.
Comment 6: Hi Matt, I don't have an answer for you, but I am wondering how you use the outcomes feature in your class. My college is trying to start using Moodle Outcomes . Do you find it easy  to track outcomes for your classes?
Comment 7: Hi Muareen, I don't use Moodle Outcomes much. They're essentially a more general version of rubrics but are more flexible. I was referring to intended learning outcomes (ILOs) that curriculum developers typically define during the course design/development process & which may or may not be communicated to students, i.e. the ILOs should be implicit in the course assessments anyway. The main drawback of ILOs is that they're, by nature, quite abstract & difficult for students to interpret. When I have the choice, I prefer to use "success criteria," which are examples or models that demonstrate expected performance/products from students by the end of the course or instructional sequence. John Hattie has re-popularised success criteria in recent years.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Using a Scale and a Rubric for Grading
Post description: Hi, I use a scale instead of points with my rubric and have a question. My scale is "pass, fail, absent, excused" and I only want to use the scale for those students who have actually handed in something. The problem is that with this combination when I open an assignment to grade I only see the rubric and there is not way to choose from the scale, Moodle obviously chooses automatically from the scale. Is that the expected/ intended behavior? Is there any way to choose from the rubric (just the way I can when there is no rubric) AND still have the rubric? Thank you!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Yves, That is expected and intended behaviour. If you're using an advanced grading method such as Rubric or Marking guide, the aggregated score will be as follows: points scored / points total. This leads to a percentage score, which in turn is translated to a scale value. Let's say your 'Pass, Fail, Absent, Excused' scale is being used, it'll work as follows: No score = 0/4 points Pass = 1/4 points (25%) Fail = 2/4 points (50%) Absent = 3/4 points (75%) Excused = 4/4 points (100%)
Comment 2: Thank you Joost! This was really insightful. Yes, in a nutshell, I want to use a rubric in a strictly formative fashion without points or grades/ values. I tried your suggestion ("set up the rubric to not score any points (0 points value for all cells and rows") but this does not work, unfortunately, Moodle returns an error that says that the maximum of points value need to be > 0 and that different criteria cannot have the same points value. Is there any other way to use the rubric without awarding points? Thank you!

Post title: Evaluation by Teacher
Post description: Is there a way for a teacher to evaluate their course when it is finished? Within Moodle itself as a multiple choice questionnaire.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well, "for a teacher to evaluate their course" is really something that happens inside the teacher's head. Any use of technology is secondary. But, if you wanted to guide their refection, then you could make something to help, which could be as simple as one page of text, with a few bullet points they might like to consider. (What those points should be is a very interesting question.) Then, if it seems that more technology might contribute something, then some sort of questionnaire or survey might be worth the effort.
Comment 2: Typically it is either the https://docs.moodle.org/en/Feedback_activity (part of Moodle) or the https://docs.moodle.org/en/Questionnaire_module , a plug-in which you have to install.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Information Page not a Course
Post description: Hello, what is the best way to set up an information/toolkit page for learners to access once they have completed a course? So not a course page, like an information page with documents and links. Thank you. Lyneece
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Lyneece If you want to use "Core" features, you can add the "Main Menu" block to your frontpage: https://docs.moodle.org/403/en/Main_menu_block ,  and then add "Page" activities into this -- these will live at the 'site' level and be accessible to all. If you want to try a plugin, give the Static Pages plugin a try: https://moodle.org/plugins/local_staticpage - this lets you create HTML pages that live 'outside' of a course and you can define who has access to it. More info here: https://github.com/moodle-an-hochschulen/moodle-local_staticpage/blob/master/README.md
Comment 2: You can also create a moodle course to hold all the public information, and enable guest enrolment method without password. Site auto login guests setting should be on as well. Then you can put whatever resources you want there.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Course Content Vs Different Classes
Post description: In a scenario that i am teaching a particular course   'X'  for a class, then, in the following year i teach  same course('X') to another class, I would usually import the class material from the previous Moodle course page to the new one. This is a great tool in Moodle, but also creates another challenge, which is " Having the same files in two Moodle Courses ". If i tought the course 10 times, i could potentially have the same content 10 times in Moodle in 10 different courses. This takes up space. Now i cannot use the same Moodle Course page to teach different classes as it may contain assignments marks and possibly exams marks and files from the previous class which must be maintained for 3 years per the University policies. Is there a place in Moodle where the Teaching materials can be hosted and then just linked to the Moodle course pages? Or any alternatives??? Thank you
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The way I handle this situation, is to make a full backup at the end of a course. For extra assurance, I download a copy of the backup to my local hard drive. I then reset the course, deleting all discussion posts, assignment submissions and enrolled users. The cleaned course is now ready to enrol the new cohort of users. Should I need to retrieve information, such as students' forum posts, assignment submissions, or grades, I can reconstitute a course from three years earlier, and view the course exactly as it was.
Comment 2: Another alternative would be to use Cohorts, Metacourses or Groups/Groupings. Any of these configurations would do. Depending on the scenario, one is more appropriate than the other.
Comment 3: Could you share more about Metacourses? I've heard about it before but couldnt qt figure how to use it, both in concept and where to find it in settings page.
Comment 4: Hi Ming, I've just tried once but I never used it because it didn't fit my scenarios, so I cannot help you that much. You might want to read some guidelines here: https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Metacourse_examples_of_use https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Course_meta_link However, when I was trying to understand it, I got the information from the forum that Cohorts were supposed to replace the Meta course link: https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Cohorts
Comment 5: Hi Beatrice, thank you for pointing me to the meta-course documentation. It is a very useful page. I was also reading on cohort function, it seems if I were to use Cohort function and enrol various cohorts into the same course (normal course, not meta course), the course enrolment could become rather large, and the course participants regardless of the cohorts will be mixed together, will that understanding be correct?
Comment 6: We use it for our Social Emotional Learning (SEL) course for grades 3 to 5. Each elementary teacher has their own individual course in moodle and we just meta-enroll each of the teachers individual courses into their respective grade level (SEL) course. Of course we have adjusted teacher permissions in these grade level (SEL) courses so the teacher role is more like a non-editing teacher. That way when using seperate groups the teachers will only have access to their own students. Otherwise it would be too confusing for 45 teachers having access to over 1000 students, which is usually the number of students in each Meta-Course for (SEL)

Forum Post: 
Post title: how to assign random piece of info to students
Post description: Case: For the practical exam, each students need to get assigned a random IP range to use in their virtual lab setup (I teach computer networking). In the exam instructions published on Moodle, it says "use the randomly assigned IP range to you". So now I wanted to create a quiz with just 1 random question of type "description". I created tons of these description questions, each with another IP range mentioned in it. But that is not working, questions of that type cannot be randomly included in a quiz. I tried a multiple choice question where the IP range is in the question, and where there is only 1 answer option (= "I understood, and will use this IP range"), but question type multiple choice requires at least two answers. I would prefer that student does not need to type or click anything as answer, since I do not need an answer from them. I just need a way to assign them a random piece of info that they need to use in their lab. I tried the essay question type, but also an answer IS required (either text or an attachment) I tried the Cloze question type without any answers, but that is also not accepted by Moodle. I do not have site admin rights to add new activities to our exam Moodle. Otherwise I could try to create groups (their names would be the different IP ranges) and assign students randomly to those groups and use the group choice activity to show them their assigned IP range. But that group choice activity is not present in out exam Moodle. Who has any suggestions to achieve what I am trying to do????
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: So the IP range is just a bit of 'text' (e.g., 127.0.0.1) each user should see based on some randomisation? How about doing the following: Go to Participants > Groups and use the Auto-create groups feature to randomly create groups of 1 student each Create a new section in your course Add a Text and media zone (Label up to Moodle 4.0) that contains 1 IP address, until you have distributed al IP addresses Restrict each of these Text and media zones to only be available to 1 of the groups of one and set them to hidden otherwise It's still a lot of work, but it should be doable!
Comment 2: Hello Joost, I had thought of that already, but with a very large group of students that is an awful lot of clicking to set up. It would then be easier to just hand each student a piece of paper with the IP range they should use for their exam when they enter the auditorium. I am of the opinion that a platform such as Moodle should make life easier on lecturers, not more complicated by draining away extra time in setting up stuff like this. I found another workaround: as a teacher I only have a limited set of activities that hae some kind of random function built-in. Such as the generation of groups and assigning members to these. But there is also a random aspect to the question types formula and calculated multiple choice. I have solved my dilemma (although not as elegant as I would like) by creating 1 calculated multiple choice question with the variables x and y in them in the following string which has the same font color as the background (ergo white): 172.{x}.{y}.0 The question also contains the text (in black): Below you can find the IP range you have to use during this exam. Please check that you have been informed of this IP range. Answer option 1 is then set to: 172.{x}.{y}.0 with mask /24 (incorrect answer) Answer option is set to: I have been informed that my IP range is 172.{x}.{y}.0 with mask /24 (correct answer) And I have set the variable x and y so that is x randomized between 16 and 31 and y between 1 and 254 I then created a quiz with this 1 calculated multiple choice question with the display name "click here to know the IP range that needs to be used". Thanks for thinking along with me. It is appreciated.
Comment 3: > set the variable x and y so that is x randomized between 16 and 31 and y between 1 and 254 So these "strings" (the IP ranges) don't have to be unique?
Comment 4: By doing this randomization of x and y between those values, I can generate a dataset with that one question that contains over 4000 unique IP ranges. When 100 students take the exam, there is indeed a small chance that two student will get the same IP range assigned by Moodle. But they would need to know that of each other, be able to see each others laptop screen, communicate with each other in some way for this to be a problem. So it serves my purpose of giving my students a range that is not hard coded on the exam instructions but is given on the spot by Moodle. Thus reducing the risk of fraude. I have other systems in place to, to make sure that each student has a unique set of configuration parameters for their virtualized network components. Each student a unique IP range for them alone would be nice, but is not necessary for my purposes.
Comment 5: Yes, it looks like you want to assign a unique IP to each student which would be "shuffled" rather than random. Perhaps some way of automatically assigning students to groups, i.e. one student per group, & activities than show unique info, i.e. an IP address, to each group?

Post title: Groups in Groups (double post, sorry)
Post description: I'm posting here and in moodlecloud, because that's what I'm on, but this is appropriate for teaching, so I wasn't sure. Sorry for that. I've always been confused about groups and groupings. I am teaching a course that has two classes. Within each class, I'd like to assign students to work in consistent groups throughout the semester. These in-class groups will share their work among themselves, but not with other groups. How do I set it up so that I can see and grade each class separately and also have groups within each class? Thank you so much in advance. Sarra Lev
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Sarra Lev, I don't know whether this was answered already in the MoodleCloud forum, but: A group contains 1 or more students in your course A student can be a member of 1 or more groups in the same course A grouping is basically a group of groups, e.g. the grouping Project work will contain the groups Project A , Project B and Project C . Or the grouping Classes will contain two groups Class A and Class B . You'd use this grouping to manage class forums, like the Announcements one, where erveryone in the class has access, but the students aren't distributed into groups for this activity. You'd also need to set up a grouping for the Project work or In-class groups. Any activities where these groups are relevant, need to be set up to 'separate groups' with a grouping listing the In-class or Project groups. This would make sense for Assignments or Wikis in particular. The Moodle Docs on groups and groupings is a good point of departure for what you're looking for: https://docs.moodle.org/405/en/Groups
Comment 2: Hello Sarra - I removed your post in the MoodleCloud forum as your question applies to Moodle in general and not just MoodleCloud - thanks to Joost for replying here. 👍
Comment 3: Dear Joost, Again, thank you for your reply. Have been reading through the lit again, and still quite confused. My task is this: One course with 20 students Two sections (Section 1 and Section 2) of that course with ten students each (these students DON'T need to work together as a group) Five pairs of students in each class who DO need to work together (same pairs all the way through the semester) as a "group". One class may include an additional student, making one group of three. How would I set this up using groupings and groups? I'm really having a tough time with this despite having watched endless videos and read lots of documents.
Comment 4: There's a lot of power with groups and groupings, so don't be discouraged by trying to understand them. It took me around 8 years before I started using them. You might want to consider the Moodle "activities" that you will be using and why you might need to separate students. For example, if you are designing a course quiz with randomly picked questions, you probably don't need groups. If you want to use separate "discussions," Moodle's Forum activity, and you don't only want group discussions to show, they you probably want to use groups.
Comment 5: Thanks for answering Rick. I hadn't considered adding all that info. They are in two sections because the school has divided them that way. I teach a subject that has traditionally been studied in pairs and part of the goal is to have them form relationships through studying together. The team will have to solve problems together throughout the semester (nobody switches around into other configurations). The only thing I'd like them to be able to do is to submit activities in their group of two and for both to be able to access and update the activity after they submit. They will also present together at the end of the semester and will receive one grade for the team. Is this enough information for you to advise me how to configure this? Thanks again. Sarra
Comment 6: Okay, let me focus on the "sections" first. I would create two "groups." You can name them whatever you want, such as Section A and Section B. Then, put the appropriate students into each section. That's about it. If you want to, you could create a grouping called "Sections," but I don't see it doing much. Maybe someone else will see an advantage of creating a grouping for these two sections. For your "teams of two" I would create a "group" for each team, such as TeamA, TeamB, TeamC, etc. Then I would also create a grouping called "Teams" and add all these Teams to the Teams grouping. See if you have success doing this. You can create a bogus course with bogus students to experiment. Sometimes it's a little awkward when I do this because I think you create the Grouping first, then create the teams. I'll let you experiment on your own because this will give you good practice. One advantage of having these Teams is that you can create discussion forums for each team to share ideas, and the other teams can be excluded from seeing individual team discussions. So each team can have "private" discussions, yet you can see what they are discussing and even participate. I haven't used group "Assignments" (meaning submittals), but you will want to explore this on your own to better understand how it works. I also haven't used "group" quizzes. I don't know if this would work. Others here on Moodle.org might provide other approaches to your situation. I do want to warn you that Groups and Grouping are pretty powerful features in Moodle, perhaps an advanced topic, so make sure to practice with your bogus course and bogus students. Sometimes, you will have to log in as a specific student (not switching to a student as admin or teacher) to see how your Moodle really behaves. Many of Moodle's Activities and Resources provide group features. Here's a suggestion for your end-of-semester team presentations.  Use the Pecha Kucha method and limit each presentation to 6:40 minutes.  Use voice-on-PowerPoint, and have students upload their presentations.  Then create a discussion forum and require the other teams to view and comment on each teams presentation.  This is all done asynchronously, so give students a week or so for the final discussion.  I know I have overloaded you with this idea, but I have had great success with it.  I would even convert their voice-on-PowerPoint to 6:40-minute videos.
Comment 7: Thank you so much Rick! That's extremely helpful!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Hiding courses but showing grades
Post description: HI all, I'm not sure if this has a really simple however I can't seem to work it out. We have HR courses which get updated each year, and I want to still allow students to view their grades from the previous course, but not make any changes within the course and have access to only their grades. I have previously hidden the older courses, but that hides them from the students profile. I have tried hiding the enrolment methods and this seems to do the same thing. I have also tried putting an end date on the course, but students still have access to the course content. Is there a way to show only grades? Thanks Leticia
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Leticia, If you accept the fact that a user is allowed to access his/her completed course as read-only (no new interactions can be logged), you should be able to manage these courses through setting op Course Completion criteria. A user will remain enrolled, will be able to see the Past course in the Course Overview block on Dashboard and will be able to access grades from the user menu, or through accessing the completed course and opening the Grades interface from the navigation bar. Hiding old courses would work for teaching and management staff, but not for students, who by default have the permission 'moodle/course:viewhiddencourses' disabled.
Comment 2: Hi Joost, Thank you for your reply. Which settings can I turn on/off? Leticia

Forum Post: 
Post title: Viewing and rating all student forum posts on one page
Post description: I want to be able to go to a page that shows me all the forum posts, answers, discussions, responses, whatever, that a student has made, in reverse chronological order (i.e., select posts where student = "Bob Smith" order by post-date desc).  I want to be able to grade these posts on that page. This was totally doable in Moodle 1 and was a great aid for grading participation.  In Moodle 2, neither I nor our school's Moodle administrator can figure out how to do this.  If I go to the list of participants, I can eventually drill down to some of the student's posts but not all of them by any means, and when I see them, I can't grade them. Is this feature still available in Moodle 2 but we can't find it?  Or was it removed?  If it's the latter, please bring it back.  I don't know what language Moodle is written in but if it is in Java , and you can point me to the code that used to do what I want in Moodle 1, maybe I can retrofit in into my school's Moodle 2.  That would be hard to do correctly however, so I'd much rather that the Moodle developers do it.  Thanks. Ken Litwak
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ken, Moodle 2 also has a page showing all posts a student has made, which a user with appropriate capabilities, such as a teacher, can grade. You can access this page via the list of participants in a course - click on a student's name to access their course profile page, then in the navigation block you should find Current course > Course101 > Participants > Sam Student > Forum posts > Posts .
Comment 2: I think Moodle fixed what was not broken in Moodle 2 with changing the discussion forums grading.  I do NOT want to see ALL a students posts for the entire class.  Sometimes I have two or three forums a week for students to do classwork on.  I want to see that ONE board and ALL the students posts.  Moreover I want to be able to give private feedback to that student about that particular forum.  That option is gone.  Imagine the end of the semester and I am in participant and scrolling through ALL of their posts... Whoever has power in Moodle - tell them to revert this Advanced Forum back... they have just tripled my workload in grading to grade individually instead of the way it was.  When I realized this change - I was livid.  I think Moodle needs to TALK to teachers prior to making changes so drastic like this.  Taking away an appropriate grading feature like this makes the forum useless and pointless.  Discussions in the online world are VITAL to creating a dynamic and interactive course.  To force teachers to go into each post and blindly grade EACH submission with the drop down is INSANE.  I cannot see if that student posted another time, or what kind of responses.  I need them ALL in one place as they were in Moodle 1 - Now I am having to figure out - is there some other discussion forum I can use outside of Moodle that will help me see ONE student on ONE forum and ALL of their posts and be able to grade and comment.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Best practice for courses offered multiple times without duplicating courses
Post description: Hello, We offer online wine courses with lots of content in each course (scorms, videos, live webinars, etc) and, so far. We run each course 5 or 6 times a year and so far did not find a better solution than duplicate a course each time there is a new intake. I understand that using cohorts (ex: spring 2024 cohort, summer 2024 cohort...) might be a way to go for us. But I anticipate it to be extraordinarely complexe to manage each activity (synchronous and assynchronous ones... including live webinars whose recordings then gets posted for those who light have missed it live) in one course when you have different cohorts of students, all at a different step in the course. Would there be someone here very much used to these situations and could offer support? We'd be open to having someone come on board as a consultant... Thank you! Julien
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You could just run the same course, but set up to work with separate groups (forced). You'd enroll new participants in groups for every edition of the course, with the content still in one place. Results and reports can then be filtered by group. To provide access to missed webinars, you could post a link to the recording in a forum (announcements maybe?) set up to work with separate groups, so only the group attending has access.
Comment 2: Thank you Joost for taking the time to answer! I guess posting the recordings to the forum could work. But ideally they would go as a file activity within the tile that corresponds to it. Example: the Champagne lecture recording in the Champagne tile (we use the tile format of Moodle). I guess I need to play around with groups as it indeed seems to be the way to go... Thank you Joost! Julien
